Ugh, okay. Here we go. This is…still kinda raw, honestly. People always want to know *why*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn't.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, okay? That's what a lot of people seem to think. It was about wanting the baby to have everything *I* couldn't give it.

I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being. I was failing Shop class, for crying out loud. My life was…not exactly stable.

My mom is amazing, but she's already got her hands full. And my dad…well, he's my dad. He'd try, but he's not exactly equipped to change diapers and deal with teenage hormones.

I just…I didn't want to bring a kid into a situation where it wouldn't get everything it deserved. A stable home, a good education, opportunities…things I wasn't sure I could provide.

Mark, the dad…he was nice, but he was also sixteen. And he was planning on going to college far away. It wasn't a good situation for anyone.

Vanessa and Mark, they were…perfect. They were ready. They were excited. They had a beautiful home and a loving relationship. They could give the baby a life I just couldn't.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still hurts sometimes. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. It wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby.

And honestly? Knowing that the baby is going to be loved and cared for…that makes it a little bit easier. A little bit. It doesn't erase the sadness, but it gives it…purpose, I guess.

It's complicated. It's messy. It's not a fairytale. But it's my story. And I'm okay with it. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, so you want the deep stuff, huh? Love and responsibility. It's not exactly a topic I was prepared for, let me tell you. I was more focused on avoiding drama and finding the perfect mix CD. But yeah, I learned a lot. The hard way, mostly.

See, before all this baby stuff, I thought love was just…romantic comedies. You meet a cute guy, you fall in love, you live happily ever after. Turns out, it's way more complicated than that. It's not always butterflies and grand gestures. Sometimes it's just…being there for someone. Even when they're being a total mess.

I learned that love isn't just about *feeling* something, it's about *doing* something. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own. It's about making sacrifices. And it's about being honest, even when it's hard.

Paul…he wasn't the guy I thought I wanted. He wasn't cool or edgy or anything. But he was kind and genuine and he actually *listened* to me. And I realized that sometimes, the best kind of love is the quiet kind. The kind that just…is.

And then there's Mark and Vanessa. They weren't looking for a baby, but they were willing to open their hearts and their home to one. That taught me a lot about responsibility. It's not just about providing for a child financially, it's about giving them love, support, and a stable environment. It's about being there for them, no matter what.

I thought giving the baby up would be easy. Like, I'd just hand her over and everything would be fine. But it wasn't. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew it was the right thing to do. Because I wanted her to have a life that I couldn't give her.

So, yeah. I learned that love and responsibility are intertwined. They're not always easy, and they're not always what you expect. But they're worth it. And sometimes, the most responsible thing you can do is let go.

It's still kinda confusing, honestly. But I think I'm starting to get it. A little bit. And that's good enough for now.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…reflective? Fine. But don't expect a heartfelt monologue. I'm not exactly known for my emotional vulnerability.

Look, when life throws a grenade at you – and let me tell you, getting pregnant at sixteen felt like a grenade – you kinda have two choices. You can fall apart and cry about it, or you can make a joke. I chose the joke. Mostly because crying felt…exhausting.

It wasn't like I *planned* to be funny. It just kinda…happened. It was a defense mechanism, I guess. A way to distance myself from the whole mess. If I could make people laugh, then maybe they wouldn't see how scared I was. Maybe they wouldn't see how completely lost I felt.

And honestly, it helped. It helped me process things. It helped me deal with the awkward conversations with my parents, with Mark, with everyone. It was a way to take control of the situation, even if it was just a little bit.

Plus, it was a way to connect with people. Paul and Vanessa, they got my humor. They didn't judge me for it. They laughed *with* me, not *at* me. And that meant a lot.

It wasn't always easy, though. Sometimes, the jokes felt…empty. Like I was just pretending everything was okay when it wasn't. But even then, it was better than saying nothing at all.

So yeah, my wit. It wasn't a cure-all, but it was a coping mechanism. It was a way to survive. It was a way to stay sane. And it was a way to remind myself that even in the darkest of times, there's always room for a little bit of humor.

It's just…how I deal. Don't overthink it.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…deep? Fine. But don't expect a perfectly polished answer. I'm not exactly known for my eloquent speeches.

Look, I put up a pretty good front, right? Sarcastic, quick-witted, kinda tough. It was a defense mechanism, honestly. A way to keep people at arm's length. Because underneath all that, I was a total mess.

I was a kid, dealing with something *huge*. Something I wasn't prepared for. And I didn't want anyone to see how scared I was. How lost. How…vulnerable.

But pretending to be okay only got me so far. It was exhausting. And it didn't actually solve anything.

The whole pregnancy thing forced me to confront who I was, or who I *thought* I was. I had this whole plan for my life, and then suddenly, everything was different. I had to figure out what I really wanted, not just what everyone else expected of me.

And that was terrifying.

My vulnerability, admitting that I didn't have all the answers, that I was scared and confused…that's what allowed me to connect with people. With Paul, with Vanessa, even with Mark and Bren. They saw past the sarcasm and the attitude and saw the real me.

And that connection, that support, that's what gave me the strength to make the decision I made. To give the baby up for adoption. It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was the right thing.

My search for identity wasn't about finding some perfect version of myself. It was about accepting all the messy, complicated parts. It was about realizing that it's okay to not have everything figured out. It was about learning to be true to myself, even when it's scary.

It's still a work in progress, you know? I'm still figuring things out. But I'm a little less afraid now. A little more willing to be vulnerable. And a little more confident in who I am.

So yeah, my vulnerability and my search for identity shaped my journey in a pretty big way. It wasn't always pretty, but it was real. And that's all that matters, I guess.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…emotional? Fine. But don't expect a perfectly polished answer. It's still kinda weird talking about this stuff.

Honestly, if I hadn't had the people I had around me, I would have completely fallen apart. Like, spectacularly. I thought I was all independent and tough, and I *am* pretty good at putting up a front, but underneath it all, I was a total mess.

My dad, Paul…he was the best. He wasn't perfect, obviously. He's kinda clueless sometimes. But he always listened, even when I was being a total jerk. And he never judged me. He just wanted me to be happy. And he supported my decision, even though it was, like, the hardest thing I've ever had to do.

And then there was Leah. My best friend. She was the one who kept me grounded. She called me out on my BS, and she made me laugh when I wanted to cry. She didn't try to fix things for me, she just…was there. And that was enough.

And even Mark, even though he was kinda annoying at first, he actually ended up being really supportive. He showed me that it was okay to be vulnerable, and that it was okay to ask for help.

And then there was Vanessa and Annie. They were…unexpected. But they understood what I was going through in a way that no one else could. They gave me a sense of hope, and they showed me that there were good people out there who wanted to give my baby a good life.

It wasn't just about them telling me what to do, though. It was about them believing in me. About them giving me the space to figure things out on my own. About them reminding me that I was strong enough to make the right decision, even when it was hard.

I thought I had to do everything myself. I thought I had to be tough and independent. But I learned that it's okay to lean on people. It's okay to ask for help. And it's okay to let people love you.

They didn't *make* my decisions for me. They just gave me the strength to make them myself. And that made all the difference. It's kinda cheesy to say, but it's true. I wouldn't be who I am today without them.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It's not like a rom-com moment, you know? It wasn't all sparkly and cute. It was…a lot.

Honestly? My first thought was, "Seriously?" Like, of all the things that could happen, *this* happened? I was sixteen. I had plans. Okay, not *detailed* plans, but I was thinking about college and art school and maybe getting a job at a record store. And then…bam. Positive pregnancy test.

I was mostly just…shocked. And then scared. Really scared. I mean, I barely knew what to do with my own life, let alone a baby. And my parents…I was terrified to tell them.

There was a lot of denial at first. Like, maybe the test was wrong. Maybe it was a fluke. But it wasn't. It was real.

And then, after the initial shock wore off, I just felt…overwhelmed. It was like my whole world had been turned upside down. Everything was different.

It wasn't a happy moment, not at first. It was just…complicated. And confusing. And a little bit terrifying.

But then I started thinking about it more, and I realized that I had a choice. And that was…empowering, in a way. I could choose to keep the baby and try to raise it, or I could choose to give it up for adoption and let someone else give it a good life.

It was a really hard decision, but it was my decision. And that's what mattered.

It wasn't a fairytale. It was messy and complicated and real. And it changed my life forever. But it also made me stronger. And it taught me a lot about myself.



It's hard to explain, you know? It was a lot of feelings all at once. And it's still something I think about, even now.

Ugh, okay, that's…a loaded question. It was messy. Really messy. It wasn't like a movie, where everyone's suddenly super supportive and understanding. It was…complicated.

With my dad, it was…weird at first. He was trying to be supportive, but he's my dad. He wanted to fix everything, you know? Like, offer to pay for everything, or find a "better" solution. Which, no. Just…no. Eventually, he got it. He realized I needed him to just *listen*, not to solve. We actually ended up bonding a little bit, which was surprising.

My mom…she was a mess. Not in a bad way, just…overwhelmed. She wanted to be there for me, but she was also scared. She kept trying to give me advice, which I mostly ignored. But I knew she loved me, and that meant a lot.

And then there were Leah and Ben. My best friends. That was the hardest part. Leah was…distant at first. I think she didn't know how to react. She was worried about me, but she was also kinda jealous, I think. Like, my life was suddenly way more dramatic than hers. It took a while for us to reconnect. We had some really tough conversations.

Ben was…Ben. He was supportive, but also kinda clueless. He kept trying to make jokes to lighten the mood, which sometimes worked, but sometimes just made things worse. But he was always there for me, and I knew I could count on him.

Honestly, my pregnancy tested all my relationships. It showed me who my real friends were, and who weren't. It forced me to be honest with myself and with the people I cared about.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears, a lot of arguments, and a lot of awkward silences. But in the end, it made my relationships stronger. I learned that even when things are tough, you can always rely on the people who love you.

And that's a pretty good lesson to learn, you know? Even if it took a pregnancy to learn it.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a picnic, you know? It was more like a really awkward, uncomfortable, and terrifying rollercoaster.

Honestly? I mostly just tried to pretend it wasn't happening. I was really good at sarcasm and deflecting, so I used that a lot. Just making jokes about everything, trying to make light of it. It was a coping mechanism, I guess. A really unhealthy one, probably.

But underneath all the snark, I was totally freaking out. I was a kid, having a kid. It didn't make any sense. I was scared about everything – school, my future, what my parents would think, what everyone would think.

Talking to Paul helped. A lot. He was…surprisingly supportive. And Leah, my friend, she was a good listener. She didn't judge me, which was important.

And then there was Vanessa, the social worker. She was…intense. But she also helped me sort through my feelings and figure out what I wanted. She helped me realize that giving the baby up for adoption wasn't a failure, it was a brave and selfless thing to do.

But mostly, I just tried to focus on the present. One day at a time. I listened to music, I watched movies, I hung out with my friends. I tried to keep things as normal as possible, even though nothing was normal.

It was hard. Really hard. There were a lot of tears, a lot of anxiety, and a lot of self-doubt. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process.

I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. I learned that it's okay to ask for help. And I learned that even when things are really, really hard, there's always hope.

It wasn't easy, but I wouldn't trade the experience for anything. It made me who I am today. A little bit jaded, maybe. But also a little bit wiser. And definitely a lot more resilient.



It's still…complicated. Even now. But I'm okay. I think. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always asks about that. It's not like I just flipped a coin, you know? It wasn't a casual decision. It was…complicated.

Havenbrooke was all…polished. And quiet. And everyone was really nice, almost *too* nice. It felt…sterile. Like a doctor's office in a movie. And Mr. and Mrs. Loring, they seemed really eager. Like they were already picking out names and decorating a nursery. It freaked me out a little, honestly. It felt like they were more excited about the baby than about me making a really hard decision.

Women Now was…different. It was louder. And busier. And Dr. Anderson, she was…real. She didn't try to sugarcoat anything. She just explained everything clearly and let me ask questions. And she didn't make me feel guilty. Which was a big deal.

Plus, the protesters outside Women Now were…intense. And seeing them, it just solidified my decision. It made me realize how important it was to do what *I* wanted, regardless of what anyone else thought.

It wasn't about finding the "best" place, it was about finding the place where I felt the most comfortable and respected. And at Women Now, I felt like I was being treated like a person, not just a statistic.

It was a hard day, obviously. But I'm glad I chose Women Now. It felt…right. And that's all that really mattered.

It's my life, my decision. And I needed to make it on my own terms. And Women Now let me do that.



It's not something I like to talk about a lot, but I understand why people are curious. It was a big part of my story. And it's important to remember that everyone's experience is different.

Ugh. Okay. Wow. That's…direct. And honestly? Still kinda raw, even after all this time. It's not something I talk about a lot.

Look, it wasn't some grand romantic gesture, okay? It wasn't like in the movies. It wasn't even…planned. It just *happened*.

I was scared, obviously. I was pregnant, and my life was completely changing. I was trying to be all strong and independent, but inside I was a mess. And Bleeker…he was just…there. He was always there. Quietly supportive. Not judging.

I think I just…needed to feel something. Something real. Something that wasn't about the baby or the adoption or all the other complicated stuff. I needed to feel connected to someone. And with Bleeker, it was easy. It was comfortable.

It wasn't about love, not really. It was about…comfort. And maybe a little bit of desperation.

I regret it? Not exactly. It was a mistake, yeah. A messy, complicated mistake. But it was *my* mistake. And it made me realize that I needed to figure out what *I* wanted, not what everyone else thought I should want.

It was a turning point, I guess. It made me realize that I wasn't just a vessel for a baby. I was a person with feelings and needs and desires. And I deserved to be happy, even if it was just for a little while.

It's complicated. It's not a story I tell a lot of people. But you asked. And I try to be honest, even when it's hard.



It's just…it was a moment. A messy, imperfect moment. And it's part of my story.

Ugh. Okay, Bleeker. That's…complicated. Everyone always wants to know about Bleeker. Like he's some kind of fascinating anthropological specimen.

Look, he's…sweet. Really sweet. And he's a good guy. He's just…not exactly the sharpest tool in the shed, you know? He's kinda oblivious. And he plays guitar…a lot. Which is fine, I guess. If you're into that sort of thing.

At first, it was just…convenient. He was there. He was nice. He didn't judge me. And he was a good distraction from everything that was going on with the baby. He was safe.

But then…things got weird. He started, like, really *wanting* things. And I wasn't sure I wanted the same things. I was trying to figure out my own life, and he was trying to figure out how to build a life *with* me. And that felt…suffocating.

I think I liked the idea of him liking me. It was nice to be wanted. But I don't know if I ever actually *liked* him, like, *liked* him.

He's a good person. He deserves someone who's totally into him. And I just…wasn't. I was too messed up, too confused, too focused on everything else.

It's not that I regret anything. He helped me through a really tough time. But we just weren't meant to be. We were two different people, on two different paths.

It's just…sad. Because he's a good kid. And he didn't deserve to be caught in the middle of my mess.

So, how do I truly feel about Bleeker? I feel…grateful. And a little bit guilty. And mostly just…confused. It's a whole thing. Don't even get me started.

Ugh, okay, here we go. This is…the big question, isn't it? Everyone always wants to know *why*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn't. It was the hardest thing I've ever had to do.

Look, I was seventeen. Seventeen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone raise a human being. I wasn't ready. I didn't have a job, I was still in high school, and my parents…well, they were trying, but they had their own stuff going on.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have everything. A stable home, parents who were ready and able to provide for them, a good education…things I just couldn't offer at that point in my life.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They had a beautiful home and a lot of love to give. I knew they would give the baby a life I couldn't.

It wasn't like I was just giving the baby away. It was about choosing the best possible life for them. It was about being selfless, even though it was the hardest thing I've ever had to be.

And honestly? It was scary. Really scary. Letting go. But I knew it was the right thing to do.

It doesn't mean I didn't love the baby. It doesn't mean I didn't grieve. I did. I still do, sometimes. But I also feel good about the decision I made. I know the baby is happy and loved. And that's all that really matters.

It wasn't a perfect solution. It was just…the best one. For everyone involved. And sometimes, that's all you can ask for.



It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple story with a happy ending. It's messy and real and heartbreaking and hopeful all at the same time. And it's my story.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a moment. A really awkward, messy, kinda terrifying moment.

Honestly? I was a total wreck. I mean, I'd been trying to be all cool and collected about everything, you know? Like, "Yeah, I'm pregnant. No big deal." But when I actually had to *tell* Bleeker…it hit me. Like a ton of bricks.

He was just…Bleeker. Sitting there, being all quiet and artistic and oblivious. And I was just blurting it out, all fast and nervous. I think I said something like, "So, um, I'm having a baby." Smooth, right?

And his face. Oh god, his face. It was like someone had short-circuited his brain. He just stared at me, completely speechless. It was the longest five seconds of my life.

I was bracing for, like, total freak-out mode. I thought he was gonna run screaming. Or just…disappear. Which, honestly, wouldn't have surprised me.

But he didn't. He just…kept staring. And then he asked, like, a million questions. All really practical questions. Like, "Are you okay?" and "What are you gonna do?" and "Do your parents know?"

It wasn't the reaction I expected. It wasn't romantic or dramatic or anything. It was just…Bleeker being Bleeker. Supportive and kinda clueless.

And that actually made it…better. It made it feel less scary. Because he wasn't judging me. He was just trying to understand.

I was still terrified, obviously. But in that moment, I felt a little bit less alone. And I knew, even though things were gonna be really complicated, that he was gonna be there for me. In his own, quiet, Bleeker-y way.

It was a disaster, but a…good disaster? Does that make sense? It was awful, but it was also kinda perfect. Because it was *us*. And that's all that mattered.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, isn't it? Everyone keeps asking me about it, like it's some fascinating sociological experiment. It's not. It's my life.

Honestly? It's terrifying. Like, seriously terrifying. I'm sixteen. I'm supposed to be worrying about college applications and whether or not Mark is gonna text me back, not…raising a human being.

It's not what I planned. Not even close. I had plans. I was gonna go to art school, maybe move to New York, become a famous graphic novelist. Now…now I'm thinking about diapers and daycare and whether I can even afford to keep my vintage record collection.

But it's not all bad. I mean, I'm not exactly thrilled about the whole thing, but…it's growing inside me. And that's kinda weirdly amazing. It's a little person, and it needs me. And I think, deep down, I want to be a good mom.

I just…I don't want to mess it up. I don't want to be one of those moms who ruins their kid's life. I want to give this baby a good life, a happy life. And I'm scared I'm not ready for that.

It's complicated. It's scary. It's overwhelming. But it's also…real. And I'm trying to deal with it, one day at a time.

I'm giving the baby up, yeah. But that doesn't mean I don't care. It means I want it to have a life I can't give it right now. And that's a hard decision, but it's the right one.

So, how do I feel about it? Scared. Confused. Overwhelmed. But also…a little bit hopeful. And a whole lot determined to do the best I can. Even if I have no idea what I'm doing.

Ugh. Okay, Bleeker. That's…a whole thing. Honestly, thinking about Bleeker and a baby is kinda terrifying. Like, a double dose of awkward.

Before all this happened, it was easy. We just…hung out. He played guitar, I made sarcastic comments, we didn't really *talk* about anything important. It was comfortable, in a weird, quiet way.

Now? Everything's different. I mean, we're about to be parents. That's a pretty big deal. And it requires, like, actual communication and responsibility and…adulting. Which neither of us are particularly good at.

I think it's gonna force us to grow up, whether we want to or not. He's already trying, which is…sweet, I guess. He's been reading baby books and stuff. It's kinda adorable, and kinda pathetic.

I think we'll have to learn to rely on each other more. I can't do this alone, and he definitely can't either. We're both kinda clueless, so we'll have to figure things out together.

It's gonna be messy. There will be arguments. There will be moments where we both want to run away. But I think, underneath all the awkwardness, there's something real there. He's a good guy, Bleeker. He's just…quiet.

I think this baby will bring us closer, but it's also gonna test us. It's gonna force us to confront our own issues and figure out what we want out of life.

Honestly, I'm scared. But I'm also…hopeful. Maybe, just maybe, we can actually make this work. Maybe we can be good parents. And maybe, just maybe, Bleeker and I can actually have a real relationship.

It's gonna be a long road. And it's gonna be weird. But I think we can handle it. We have to. For the baby. And for ourselves.



Ugh. I need a snack. Thinking about the future is exhausting.

Ugh, okay, so the judgment. Yeah, that was…a lot. Like, suddenly everyone had an opinion on my life, and none of them were asking for one. It was seriously annoying.

But underneath all the sarcasm and pretending, it *did* hurt. People whispering, staring, making little comments…it just felt like everyone was looking at me like I was some kind of freak.

What helped, surprisingly, was Paul. He was just…chill about it. He didn't judge me, he didn't try to fix things, he just…was there. And that made a huge difference.

I also found a weird sort of solidarity with Bleeker. He was always kind of an outcast, and he understood what it was like to be judged. We just…hung out and listened to music and didn't talk about it. Sometimes, that's all you need.

It wasn't easy. There were definitely days when I just wanted to hide under the covers and never come out. But I learned that you can't control what other people think. You can only control how you react to it.

And honestly, a little bit of defiance helped too. I wasn't going to let other people define me. I was still Juno MacGuff, and I was going to get through this, on my own terms.

So, yeah. Eye rolls, grilled cheese sandwiches, supportive friends, and a whole lot of pretending. That's how I coped. It wasn't perfect, but it worked for me.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And it's not always easy to talk about.

I'm not ready. I'm still figuring out who *I* am. I'm still trying to decide what I want to do with my life. And I want my baby to have parents who are ready. Parents who can give them everything they need.

It's still hard. I have moments where I just…cry. And I worry. And I wonder if I'm making the right decision. But then I remember why I'm doing this. And I know that it's the best thing for everyone involved.

It's not a perfect solution. It's messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it's my solution. And I'm okay with that. I think. Mostly.

It's just…it's a lot to process. And I'm still processing. But I'm trying to be strong. And I'm trying to focus on the future. And I'm hoping that my baby will have a good life. That's all I want.

Ugh. Okay, so, the whole pregnancy thing? It was…a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. Before, I was just Juno. You know? I liked records, I hung out with Paulie, I was kinda sarcastic and avoided anything remotely resembling feelings. I'm still Juno, I guess. I still like records and I'm still sarcastic. But I'm also…more. I'm more mature, more thoughtful, and more aware of the world around me. And honestly? I think I'm okay with that. It's still kinda weird, but…okay.

Ugh, okay, so being a lab partner…it’s a whole thing. Let me tell you. I’m not exactly the “enthusiastic beaker-cleaner” type, okay? I’m more of a “get-it-done-efficiently-and-with-minimal-awkwardness” kind of lab partner.

I’m usually the one who actually *reads* the instructions beforehand. Which, shockingly, a lot of people don’t do. So I end up being the de facto leader, even though I actively try to avoid leadership positions. It’s exhausting.

I’m good at the actual science part, though. I can follow directions, I can analyze data, and I can write a decent lab report. I just…don’t need to talk about it the whole time. 

My partners are usually either super-eager-beavers who are way too excited about titration, or total space cadets who are more interested in flirting with people across the room. Either way, it’s a challenge.

I try to be fair and contribute my share, but I also don’t suffer fools gladly. If someone’s being a complete idiot, I will call them out on it. Politely, but firmly.

I’m not gonna lie, I’ve definitely accidentally broken a few things in the lab. It’s not intentional, okay? It just happens. I’m a little clumsy. And sometimes, science is just messy.

So, yeah. I’m a competent, efficient, and slightly sarcastic lab partner. I get the job done, and I try not to make things too weird. Which, honestly, is a win in my book.

Ugh. Okay, so you're talking about *that* ad. The one with the, like, super cheerful font and the little cartoon baby feet? Yeah, I saw it. It was wedged between the coupons for carpet cleaning and a used car sale. Real classy.

It's…complicated. On the one hand, it's good that there are places like that, you know? For people who need them. It's not always a simple decision, and everyone deserves to have options.

But on the other hand, it feels…icky. Like they're trying to sell something. And it's not a toaster oven. It's a really big, life-altering decision. And the whole "Women's Choice" thing feels kinda manipulative. Like they're trying to make you feel guilty if you *don't* choose them.

And the cartoon baby feet? Seriously? That's just…tacky. It's like they're trying to tug at your heartstrings, even if you're trying to be rational.

I mean, I'm going through this myself, right? And it's not about picking the cutest ad. It's about finding a good family for the baby. And making the best decision for everyone involved.

So, yeah. The ad? It's…not my favorite. It feels disingenuous. And honestly, it just makes me feel a little bit more confused and overwhelmed. Which is exactly what I *didn't* need right now.

It's just…ugh. It's a lot.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People *still* ask me about the hamburger phone. It was a moment, alright? A statement. A cry for help disguised as a quirky accessory.

Look, it wasn't about the phone actually *working*. It was about…everything. It was about feeling awkward and out of place and wanting to just disappear. It was about being a weirdo and owning it.

Paul, he was kinda…perfect. And I was, well, me. A mess. And I was trying to impress him, but also trying to be myself. And the hamburger phone was a way to do both. It was ridiculous, it was attention-grabbing, and it was undeniably *me*.

It was also a way to deflect. Like, if he was gonna judge me, he was gonna judge me for the phone, not for, you know, the whole pregnant teenager thing. It was a distraction. A really dumb, delicious-looking distraction.

Plus, it was funny. And sometimes, you just need to laugh. Especially when your life is falling apart.

So yeah, I chose the hamburger phone because it was weird, it was memorable, and it was a perfect representation of my chaotic, slightly-off-kilter existence. It was a symbol of my…everything.

Don't overthink it. It was a hamburger phone. It was silly. And it worked. Sort of. Mostly it just made people stare. But that was the point.

Ugh, okay, here we go. This is…the big one, right? Everyone always wants to know *why*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn't.

Look, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone what I wanted to do with the rest of my life. I was failing Shop class, obsessed with records, and generally just trying to survive high school. I was not equipped to be a mom.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have the best life possible. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give that to him. Or her. I hadn't even picked out a name yet, because it felt…too real.

Mark, the dad, he was…Mark. Sweet, but kinda clueless. He was leaving for college and wasn't exactly ready to be a father either. We both knew it.

Vanessa and Mark, the couple who adopted him, they were amazing. They were stable, they were loving, they were *ready*. They had a beautiful home and a plan. They could give the baby everything I couldn't.

It was the hardest decision I ever made. It still is. It felt like giving away a piece of myself. But it was the right decision. For everyone.

I wanted him to have parents who could give him everything he deserved. A good education, a safe home, a loving family. I wanted him to have a life better than the one I could offer him at that point.

It wasn't about giving up. It was about giving *him* a chance. And honestly, it was about being honest with myself. I wasn't ready. And that's okay.

It still hurts sometimes, thinking about him. But I know he's happy. And that's all that matters.



It's complicated. It's messy. It's not a fairytale. But it was my story. And I wouldn't change it. Even if I could.

Ugh, okay, family. That's…a whole thing. It's not like we're the Waltons or anything. My mom, Bren, she's amazing, don't get me wrong. She's just…a free spirit. And my stepdad, Mac, he's a good guy, but kinda quiet. They're both artists, which means they're really good at expressing themselves through pottery and paintings, but not so much with, like, actual feelings.

And my dad? He's…gone. He left a long time ago. Which, honestly, made things easier in some ways. Less drama. But also, it left a hole. A big one.

So, when I found out I was pregnant, it wasn't like I could go to them for, like, traditional advice. Bren was supportive, in her own way. She was all, "Whatever you decide, honey, I'll support you." Which is nice, but not exactly helpful. Mac just kinda nodded and made me tea.

The thing is, I looked at their life, and I realized…it's not stable. It's not predictable. They're always chasing their next inspiration, their next project. And I didn't want that for a kid. I didn't want a kid growing up in a house where dinner might be gourmet or it might be cereal, depending on whether Bren felt like painting or cooking.

I wanted a kid to have a *real* family. A family that could provide stability and security. A family that could give them everything I couldn't.

And honestly, I wasn't sure I could be that person. I was sixteen. I was still figuring out who *I* was. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I needed to finish school, go to college, figure out my life.

So, seeing my family, seeing how they lived, it made me realize that giving the baby up for adoption wasn't a selfish decision. It was the most selfless thing I could do. It was about giving the baby the best possible life, even if that life wasn't with me.

It wasn't easy, obviously. But knowing that I was doing it for the right reasons, knowing that I was giving the baby a chance at a good life…that made it a little bit easier. And Bren and Mac, they eventually understood. They supported my decision, even if they didn't fully get it. They're my family, and they love me. And that's all that really matters.

Ugh, okay, so the adoption process. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like in the movies where everything just magically works out. It was...complicated. And emotionally draining.

First of all, there was the whole *finding* the right couple thing. It wasn't just about picking someone who had a nice house and a stable job. It was about finding people who I felt good about raising my kid. People who would love them and support them and give them a good life. That was a lot of pressure.

And then there was the paperwork. Oh. My. God. The paperwork. It was endless. Forms and applications and background checks and legal documents. It felt like I was filling out my entire life story, over and over again.

But the biggest challenge, honestly, was the emotional stuff. It was hard to admit to myself that I wasn't going to raise this baby. It was hard to think about someone else being their mom and dad. Even though I knew it was the right thing to do, it still hurt. A lot.

And then there was the judgment. People had opinions, you know? Some people thought I was selfish for giving the baby up. Others thought I was irresponsible for getting pregnant in the first place. It was hard to ignore the negativity.

But I had a really good social worker, and my friend Paul was super supportive. And Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted my baby, were amazing. They were so kind and understanding, and they really helped me through the whole process.

It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. Knowing that my baby was going to have a loving and stable home made it all okay. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it was also the most selfless. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

It just…it made me grow up, you know? It forced me to face some really tough decisions and to take responsibility for my actions. And it taught me a lot about love and loss and the importance of family. Even if that family looks a little different than I expected.

Ugh, okay, so you want the deep dive, huh? The whole messy, complicated story? Fine. It's not exactly a walk in the park, reliving it, but…here we go.

Before all this happened, I was just…Juno. A sarcastic, movie-obsessed kid who mostly just wanted to avoid drama and eat tater tots. I didn't really think about the future, or who I was, or what I wanted out of life. I just kinda…existed.

Then, boom. Pregnant. And suddenly, everything changed. It wasn't just about me anymore. There was this little person growing inside me, and I had to figure out what was best for *them*. And that forced me to grow up, like, really fast.

It wasn't easy. There was a lot of fear, a lot of confusion, a lot of feeling totally lost. But it also forced me to be honest with myself, and with everyone around me. I couldn't hide behind sarcasm and pop culture references anymore. I had to face reality.

Giving up the baby…that was the hardest thing I've ever done. It was heartbreaking. But it was also the right thing to do. I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom, and I wanted to give the baby the best possible life. And that meant finding parents who could give them everything I couldn't.

Through the whole process, I learned a lot about myself. I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. I learned that I was capable of making difficult decisions, even when they were painful. I learned that I was capable of love, even if it meant letting go.

And I learned that my identity wasn't just about being a teenager, or being sarcastic, or liking movies. It was about being a good person, and doing the right thing, even when it was hard.

It definitely changed my plans for the future. I had to rethink everything. But it also gave me a sense of purpose. It made me realize that I wanted to do something meaningful with my life.

I'm still figuring things out, honestly. I'm still trying to figure out who I am, and what I want to be. But I'm not the same person I was before. I'm more mature, more responsible, and more aware of the world around me.

It was a really hard experience, but it was also a really important one. It shaped me into the person I am today. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the tater tots. (Okay, maybe I'd trade it for a lifetime supply of tater tots. But just barely.)

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with that. That guy. Seriously. It was…awful.

It wasn't the yelling, okay? I'm used to people yelling at me. It wasn't even the signs. It was…the fingers thing. And the pain thing. He said it so casually, like he knew something I didn't. Like he knew this little…person…was already fully formed and suffering.

And it messed with my head, okay? I'd been trying to keep it all compartmentalized. Like, this wasn't a *baby* yet. It was…a situation. A thing I needed to deal with. But he made it feel…real.

I remember just staring at him, and feeling this weird mix of anger and…panic. And this horrible, sinking feeling in my stomach. Like I was doing something terribly wrong.

I tried to be all sarcastic and dismissive, you know? "Oh, it has fingers? Cool." But inside, I was totally freaking out. I was questioning everything. Was I a bad person? Was I hurting something that could feel?

It was the hardest part of the whole thing, honestly. Way harder than telling my parents, or dealing with Paul and Vanessa. It was that moment, with that guy, that made me really realize the weight of what I was doing.

It didn't change my decision, okay? I still knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. But it made me feel…sad. And guilty. And really, really confused.

It just…stuck with me. For a long time. It still does, sometimes. It's not something you just forget.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me relive that. It wasn't exactly a spa day, you know?

Honestly? It was…numb. Mostly. Like, my brain was trying to disconnect from everything that was happening. It was all very official and clinical, and it felt so…adult. And I was *not* feeling adult. I was still trying to figure out how to properly apply eyeliner, let alone make life-altering decisions.

There was a lot of paperwork. So. Much. Paperwork. And every question felt like a judgment. Like they were trying to trick me into changing my mind. Which, honestly, I was kinda hoping they would. A little part of me wanted someone to just tell me what to do.

I remember feeling really, really small. Like I was shrinking into the chair. And really, really alone. Even though Leah was there, it felt like I was the only person in the world who was going through this.

There was a weird mix of relief and terror. Relief that I was actually doing something, taking control of the situation. But also terror about what that meant. About giving up a baby. About what everyone would think.

I kept looking at the forms, trying to understand all the legal jargon. It felt so…final. Like once I signed those papers, there was no going back.

And I remember just wanting it to be over. Just wanting to fast-forward to a time when everything felt normal again. But I knew that wasn't going to happen. Not for a long time.

It wasn't a dramatic crying scene or anything. I'm not really one for public displays of emotion. It was more of a quiet, internal struggle. A lot of thinking. A lot of trying to be brave. And a lot of hoping I was making the right decision.

It was…a lot. And I don't really like talking about it. But you asked. So there you have it.

Ugh, okay, so that's…a big question. It's not like I woke up one morning suddenly all maternal and glowing, you know? It was a process. A really messy, complicated process.

At first, it was just…a problem. A huge, life-altering problem. Like, my life was already kinda weird and awkward, and then BAM! Pregnant. It felt like everything was spiraling out of control. I was mostly just focused on getting rid of it, honestly. Giving it to someone who actually *wanted* it. It felt like the responsible thing to do.

But then, as things went on, and I started feeling the baby kick, and going to the doctor appointments with Vanessa and Mark…it started to feel…different. It wasn't just a problem anymore. It was a *person*. A tiny little person growing inside me.

I started thinking about what it would be like to be a mom. And it scared me. A lot. I wasn't ready for that. I wasn't even sure I *wanted* to be a mom. I was still figuring out who *I* was, you know?

But then I started to see how much Vanessa and Mark wanted this baby. How much they loved it already. And I realized that giving it to them wasn't giving something *up*. It was giving them a gift. A chance to be parents.

And honestly, seeing them become parents…it was beautiful. It made me realize that motherhood isn't just about giving birth. It's about love and commitment and sacrifice. And it doesn't have to look a certain way.

I still don't think I'm ready to be a mom right now. Maybe someday. But my perception of pregnancy and motherhood completely changed. It went from being a scary, unwanted burden to something…sacred. Something beautiful. Something that deserves to be celebrated.

It made me realize that even though I wasn't going to be a mom, I could still be a part of this baby's life. And that was enough. It was more than enough. It was…good.



It's still kinda weird to think about, honestly. But yeah. That's how it changed. It was a journey, man. A real journey.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…introspective? Fine. It's not my favorite thing, but I guess it's a fair question. My identity? That was a whole *thing* throughout the movie.

At the beginning, I was just…Juno. The sarcastic, music-obsessed kid who was really good at avoiding feelings. I had my routine, my friends, my way of dealing with things. And then, BAM. Pregnant. And suddenly, everything was different.

I think I initially tried to treat the pregnancy like just another quirky situation. Like, "Oh, this happened. Okay, let's figure it out." But it was way more complicated than that. It forced me to confront stuff I hadn't even thought about before. Like, what do I want out of life? What kind of person do I want to be?

Giving the baby up for adoption wasn't just about finding good parents. It was about figuring out who *I* was, separate from being a mom. It was about realizing that I wasn't ready to be a mom, and that was okay. It didn't make me a bad person.

And then there was Paulie Bleeker. I thought I was too cool for him, too independent. But he was always there, you know? And through everything, I realized that maybe I didn't have to be so tough all the time. Maybe it was okay to let someone in.

By the end of the movie, I wasn't the same Juno I was at the beginning. I was still sarcastic and a little bit awkward, but I was also more mature, more self-aware, and more willing to be vulnerable. I started to understand that my identity wasn't fixed. It was something that was constantly evolving.

I guess I learned that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be confused. And it's okay to change your mind. It's all part of growing up.

It was messy, and complicated, and sometimes really painful. But it was also…good. It helped me figure out who I was, and what I wanted. And that's something I'll always be grateful for.



Honestly, it's weird talking about myself like this. I usually just make jokes to avoid actually feeling things. But yeah, that's pretty much it. My identity evolved from "sarcastic teenager" to "sarcastic teenager who's a little bit more grown up." It's a work in progress.

Ugh, okay, you want to go *there*? Fine. It's not exactly a fun memory, but…here we go.

It wasn't like I suddenly had a change of heart about giving the baby up, okay? It was…more complicated than that. It was about feeling like I was being rushed. Like everyone else was making decisions *for* me.

Paul and Mark, they were being all supportive and stuff, which was nice, I guess. But they were also kinda pushing me. Like, "This is the responsible thing to do, Juno." And Annie, she was just…sad. And I felt bad for making her sad.

But it wasn't about making *them* happy. It was about what *I* wanted. And I realized, sitting in the waiting room at that clinic, that I hadn't really had a chance to figure that out for myself.

It felt…wrong. Like I was just going through the motions. Like I was letting everyone else decide my future. And I'm not really a "go with the flow" kind of person. I like to be in control.

So I just…left. I walked out. It was kinda impulsive, I admit. But it felt right. It felt like I needed to take a step back and really think about things.

It wasn't about changing my mind about the adoption, it was about taking ownership of the situation. It was about making sure I was doing this for the right reasons, and not just because everyone else thought I should.

It was scary, honestly. But it was also empowering. It was a reminder that I was the one in charge of my own life. And that's a pretty important lesson to learn, even when you're just a sixteen-year-old girl with a baby on the way.



It was messy. Everything about that whole situation was messy. But it was *my* mess. And I needed to deal with it on my own terms.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always wants to know *that*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn't. It was the hardest thing I've ever had to think about.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, okay? It was about wanting the baby to have…more. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone being responsible for a whole human being.

My life wasn't exactly set up for a baby. My mom's kinda…scattered. And my dad's…well, he's my dad. They'd try, I know they would. But it wouldn't be fair to anyone. Not to me, not to the baby, and definitely not to them.

I wanted the baby to have parents who were ready. Parents who had a house and a stable income and, you know, actual adult things figured out. Parents who could give the baby everything it deserved.

Mark and Vanessa…they were perfect. They were so excited, and they had a beautiful home and they just…seemed like they were meant to be parents. It wasn't about finding a "replacement" family, it was about finding the *best* family.

It was selfish, maybe. But it was also the most unselfish thing I could do. I wanted the baby to have a good life, and I knew I couldn't give it that.

It still sucks, though. It always will. But I try to focus on the fact that I made the right decision. For everyone involved. And that the baby is loved and happy. That's all that really matters.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about giving a baby a future. And that's something I can live with. Even if it still kinda hurts sometimes.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're bringing up the Penny Saver? That was a low point. A *very* low point.

Look, it wasn't just the Penny Saver itself, okay? It was the whole vibe. It felt…desperate. Like, "Here's my baby, please pick me!" It just felt wrong. Like I was shopping for a toaster oven, not finding a family for a human being.

And it was *tacky*. Let's be real. It was all handwritten notes and blurry photos. It felt…cheap. And this baby deserved better than cheap.

I wanted someone who genuinely *wanted* a kid, not someone who was just looking for a bargain. Someone who was excited and prepared and…normal. Not someone who was browsing through classified ads like they were looking for a used car.

Plus, my dad was all, "This is a good idea!" and I just…couldn't. He means well, but sometimes his ideas are just…not good.

It was about dignity, okay? For me, for the baby, for everyone involved. It wasn't about finding the cheapest option, it was about finding the *right* option. And the Penny Saver just didn't feel right. It felt…sad.

It was a whole thing. Don't judge. I was a pregnant teenager trying to navigate a really complicated situation. I was doing the best I could. And the Penny Saver was just…not the best I could do.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the Penny Saver? It's a long story. And kinda embarrassing, if I'm being honest.

It wasn't, like, a planned thing. It just…happened. See, I was kinda bored, okay? School was…school. And Mark was being Mark. And I was just flipping through the Penny Saver – you know, looking at the furniture and the used exercise equipment – when I saw an ad.

It was for a couple looking to adopt. And it just…stuck in my head. I didn't even really *think* about it at first. I just showed it to Leah.

Leah, being Leah, immediately started making jokes about it. Like, "Oh, maybe we should find a baby to raise!" It was supposed to be funny, but…I think it also planted a seed.

We were both kinda feeling lost, you know? Like, we didn't really have a plan for our lives. And seeing that ad…it just made us start thinking. What if there were people out there who wanted a baby, and we…well, we had a situation.

It wasn't about wanting to *give* a baby up, not at first. It was more about…exploring our options. Seeing what was out there. It was a way to distract ourselves, I guess. A way to talk about something big and scary without actually having to deal with it.

So we started looking at the ads every week. Just…browsing. And it slowly started to feel less like a joke and more like…a possibility. A real, actual possibility.

It was stupid, I know. Looking at adoption ads in the Penny Saver. But that's how it started. And honestly, it changed everything.

Ugh, okay, this is…a lot to think about. It's not like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? This is a *person*. My person. And I want them to have the best life possible.

So, I've been doing a lot of thinking, and talking to Mark and Vanessa, and…it's not about perfect. Nobody's perfect. But I have some ideas.

I'm looking for a family that's…stable. Like, not a ton of drama. I don't want my kid growing up in a house where people are yelling all the time. A calm environment would be good.

And they have to be patient. Raising a kid is hard work, and it takes a lot of patience. Especially if the kid is, you know, a little weird. Like me.

I want a family that's open-minded. Someone who's not gonna judge people for being different. Someone who's gonna encourage my kid to be themselves, even if that means they're not exactly like everyone else.

And they have to be funny. Life is too short to be serious all the time. I want my kid to grow up in a house where people laugh a lot.

It doesn't matter if it's a mom and a dad, or two moms, or two dads, or just one parent. What matters is that they love the kid and that they're committed to giving them a good life.

Mark and Vanessa seem pretty great. They're kinda dorky, but in a good way. They're stable, they're patient, and they're definitely funny. They seem like they'd be good parents.

But ultimately, I just want my kid to be happy. And I want them to know that I love them, even though I couldn't raise them myself. It's a hard decision, but I'm trying to make the best one. For everyone.



It's just…a lot. Okay? It's a lot to process.

Ugh, Mark and Vanessa. Okay, don't even get me started. They're…a lot. Like, a whole *situation*.

Honestly? I think they're kinda sweet, in a weird, suburban-parent kind of way. They're trying, you know? They're clearly a little clueless, and they definitely have their issues, but they genuinely want to do the right thing.

Vanessa is…intense. She's got a lot of energy, and she's very focused on appearances. She wants everything to be perfect, which is kinda exhausting. But she's also really loving and supportive, in her own way. She just needs to chill out a little.

And Mark…bless his heart. He's just trying to keep up. He's a good guy, but he's kinda clueless about everything. He just wants everyone to be happy, and he's willing to go along with whatever Vanessa wants. Which is…sometimes not a good thing.

They're definitely not the coolest parents. They're not like, hip or edgy or anything. But they're good people. And they're willing to open their home to me, and to the baby. And that means a lot.

I think they're learning a lot through this whole adoption process. They're realizing that things aren't always going to go according to plan, and that's okay. They're learning to be flexible and to accept things as they are.

So yeah, I think they're a good couple. They're a little bit quirky, a little bit awkward, but they're good people. And I'm glad they're going to be the baby's parents. They'll give that kid a good life. Even if it's a slightly…over-organized life.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me. That yearbook thing was…a whole situation. Okay, okay, I'll tell you. But don't judge. It was a stressful time, okay? And I'm not exactly known for my eloquent declarations of love.

I wrote: "**You are the most okayest person I know.**"

Yeah. I know. It's not exactly Shakespeare. But it was…genuine. Bleeker was always kinda quiet and awkward, and he didn't really *try* to be cool. He just…was. And I appreciated that. He was comfortable in his own skin, even if his skin was covered in band t-shirts and a permanent layer of awkwardness.

I didn't want to write something cheesy or overly sentimental. That's just not me. And I definitely didn't want to scare him off. So I went with "okayest." It was a compliment, in my own weird way. It meant he was good enough. More than good enough, actually.

He looked really confused when he read it, which was kinda the point. I wanted to make him laugh. And I think I did.

It wasn't a grand romantic gesture, but it was *us*. It was honest and a little bit quirky. And honestly, that's all that mattered.

Don't tell anyone I admitted that, though. I have a reputation to maintain.

Ugh. Okay, that's a loaded question. Mrs. Bleeker. Let's just say she wasn't exactly thrilled about me at first. Not thrilled *at all*.

She had this whole vision for Paulie, you know? Like, he was supposed to go to Brown, become a doctor, marry a nice girl from a good family. And then *I* showed up. Pregnant. With a baby she wasn't expecting her son to father.

She was…polite. But it was a very *tight* polite. Lots of forced smiles and awkward small talk. She kept trying to steer the conversation towards Paulie's college applications. Like, if she just talked about Brown enough, maybe I'd disappear.

She definitely judged my clothes. And my music. And probably my entire life choices. She's a very…put-together person. I'm…not.

It took a while for her to warm up, if you can even say she *did*. I think she started to see that I genuinely cared about Paulie, and that I was trying to do the right thing for the baby. And maybe she realized that trying to control everything wasn't going to work.

She still sends Paulie care packages filled with organic snacks and educational books. And she still looks at me with a slightly bewildered expression. But she's stopped actively trying to sabotage our relationship.

So, I'd say she's…tolerating me. Which, honestly, is probably the best I can hope for. She's a good mom, she just has a very specific idea of what her son's life should look like. And I don't exactly fit into that picture. But hey, life rarely goes according to plan, right?

Ugh. Don't even *ask*. It's… looming. Like a really big, awkward, potentially disastrous storm cloud. I've been putting it off for, like, weeks now. Which is probably not the smartest thing, but honestly, I just didn't want to deal with it.

It's not that my parents are *bad* people. They're just…my parents. You know? They have expectations. They have a vision for my life. And a baby definitely wasn't part of that vision.

I'm mostly worried about disappointing them. My dad, he's always been really proud of me, for being, like, independent and smart and sarcastic. And now I'm…pregnant. It feels like I'm letting him down.

And my mom…she's gonna be a mess. She's always been a little bit dramatic. I can already picture her crying and asking me a million questions and trying to fix everything. Which, I appreciate, but I also need her to just…breathe.

I've rehearsed what I'm gonna say, like, a million times. But every time I try, it just comes out sounding wrong. Either too flippant or too emotional. It's hard to find the right tone.

I know I need to tell them, though. They deserve to know. And I need their support. Even if they're initially, like, horrified.

I'm just…nervous. Really nervous. It's probably the most terrifying thing I've ever had to do. And I've had to give a presentation in front of my entire English class. This is worse.

I'm hoping for the best, but preparing for the worst. And maybe having a box of tissues handy. For everyone.

Ugh, okay, you want to psychoanalyze me now? Fine. It's not like I haven't done enough of that myself.

It's…complicated. My parents are good people, really. They just…they're *them*. And "them" is kinda spacey and oblivious and always talking about their feelings. Which, don't get me wrong, feelings are important, but sometimes you just need someone to, like, fix a problem, not talk about how it *makes you feel*.

They're also really into being "supportive" in a way that feels…suffocating. Like, they want to be involved in everything, and they want to make everything okay, even if it means glossing over the messy parts. And this situation? This is *super* messy.

I'm kinda used to handling things on my own. I've always been pretty independent. And I don't want them to freak out. They'd probably try to "fix" everything, and I don't *want* it fixed. I want to make my own decisions. I want to figure things out for myself.

Plus, it's embarrassing. Really embarrassing. Telling them I'm pregnant? That's not exactly a conversation I was looking forward to having. It feels like I've let them down, even though I haven't done anything wrong.

So yeah, I'm hesitant to ask for help. It's not that I don't love them, it's just that…they're my parents. And sometimes, you just need to deal with things on your own. Even when it's really, really hard.

It's easier to pretend I'm okay than to explain everything. Even if pretending is exhausting.



It's a whole thing. Don't judge. It's hard being a teenager, okay? Especially when you're pregnant.

Okay, so, this is…the big one, right? Everyone keeps asking me about this. It's not like I haven't thought about it, okay? I've thought about it *a lot*.

Look, I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm still trying to figure out what I want to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human being. I mean, seriously. I can barely keep a houseplant alive.

And it's not just about me being young. It's about…being fair to the baby. This kid deserves parents who are ready for it. Parents who have their lives together. Parents who can give them everything they need. And right now, that's not me.

I'm not saying I don't care about this baby. I do. A lot. But love isn't enough. You need stability, and money, and a house, and a plan. And I have…none of those things.

I'm still in high school. I want to go to college. I want to travel. I want to figure out who *I* am, without being responsible for another person. It's selfish, maybe. But it's also realistic.

And honestly, I think there are people out there who are desperately wanting a baby. People who can't have one on their own. And I think it's a good thing to give this baby to a family who will cherish it and love it unconditionally.

It's not giving up. It's…making a choice. A hard choice, but the right choice. It's about wanting what's best for the baby, even if it means letting go.

It's not easy. It's gonna be really, really hard. But I know, deep down, that it's the best thing to do. For everyone involved. And I'm trying to be okay with that.



It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple decision. But I've thought it through. And I believe it's the right thing to do.

Okay, so this is…the big stuff. It's not like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? This is a whole human life we're talking about. And I want the absolute best for this kid.

First of all, they gotta be…stable. Like, *really* stable. No crazy drama, no sudden moves, no disappearing acts. I need people who are gonna be there, consistently, for the long haul. This isn't a temporary thing.

They gotta be financially secure, obviously. Not rich, necessarily, but able to provide a good life. Food, clothes, a roof over their heads, opportunities…the basics.

But it's not just about money. It's about…heart. They gotta be kind, and patient, and understanding. And they gotta have a sense of humor. Life is messy, and you gotta be able to laugh at it sometimes.

I want people who are open-minded. This kid is gonna have a story, and they need to be able to embrace it. No judgment, no secrets. Just acceptance.

And they gotta be willing to let the kid know where they came from. I want this kid to know I chose them, that I loved them, and that I wanted them to have the best possible life. It's important.

Honestly, I'm looking for people who are a little bit quirky. People who aren't afraid to be themselves. People who are gonna encourage this kid to be themselves, too.

It's a lot to ask, I know. But this is my kid, even if I'm not raising them. And I deserve to know they're going to be loved and cherished. And they deserve the best parents in the world.



It's kinda scary, thinking about it. But I have faith that I'll find the right people. They're out there. I just have to find them.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, right? Everyone keeps asking me about the *feelings*. Like I haven't thought about that part. It's not like I'm made of stone, you know?

Honestly? I have no freakin' clue. I'm trying to be practical about it. Like, I've got a plan. I've picked the parents. They're amazing. They're gonna give the baby a really good life. And that's…that's what matters, right?

But that doesn't mean it's gonna be easy. I'm expecting it to suck. A lot. I'm probably gonna cry. A lot. And I'm probably gonna want to just hide under my covers and listen to The Moldy Peaches for, like, a week straight.

I'm trying to focus on the fact that I'm doing this *for* the baby. That I want the baby to have everything it needs. And that includes parents who are ready and able to provide that.

I'm also talking to Paul and my dad. They're…they're trying to be supportive. My dad mostly just looks sad, which is helpful, I guess. And Paul's trying to be all logical and stuff, which is annoying, but I appreciate it.

I think I'm gonna need to find some healthy ways to cope. Maybe writing in my journal. Maybe listening to music. Maybe just…being alone for a while.

I'm also hoping that staying in touch with the parents will help. They've promised to send me updates, and I'm gonna try to be okay with that. It's gonna be hard, seeing the baby grow up with other people. But I think it's important.

I guess…I guess I'm just gonna take it one day at a time. And try not to fall apart. And hope that eventually, the pain will get a little bit easier.

It's not gonna be perfect. It's gonna be messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But I'm trying to be strong. And I'm trying to do the right thing. Even if it's the hardest thing I've ever done.

And honestly? I'm kinda terrified. But I'm also kinda proud of myself. For making this decision. For being brave enough to do what I think is best. Even if it breaks my heart.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the "deliver" thing. Seriously? It's been, like, years, and people *still* ask me about that. It's a whole thing.

It's just...weird, okay? Like, I'm not a pizza. I'm not a package. I'm a person carrying a person. And people kept saying I was going to "deliver" the baby. Like I was some kind of UPS employee.

It felt so…impersonal. And kinda gross. Like the baby was a thing to be shipped. It's a *human being*, you know? A little person who's gonna need love and attention and a whole lot of diapers.

And it just struck me as really strange that people would use that word. It's like they were trying to distance themselves from the whole situation. Like it wasn't a real pregnancy, or a real baby.

I told Paul about it, and he thought it was hilarious. He's a dork. But it bothered me. It just felt…wrong.

So yeah, I find the term "deliver" weird. I prefer "have" or "give birth to." It feels more respectful. And less like I'm a postal worker.

It's a small thing, I know. But it's one of those things that just stuck with me. It's a reminder that words matter. And that sometimes, people say things without thinking about how they might make others feel.

Ugh. Now I'm thinking about babies and diapers. I need a snack.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with that. It was a disaster waiting to happen, honestly. But, like, a necessary disaster.

Look, my dad, Mac, he's...a lot. He means well, but he's kinda clueless. And emotionally stunted. And he has a weird obsession with vinyl records. You get the picture.

But the adoption agency, they wanted to meet both parents. It was a rule. And my mom? She's…gone. Not like, *dead* gone, just…gone from our lives. So Mac was all I had.

I didn't *want* him there. I knew he'd say something embarrassing or inappropriate. I knew he'd try to fix everything with a song or a weird analogy. But I didn't really have a choice.

I figured, if I went alone, they'd think I was irresponsible or something. Like, I hadn't thought things through. And I needed them to see that I was taking this seriously. Even if I was, like, a mess inside.

So I agreed to let him come, but I laid down some ground rules. No rambling about Joni Mitchell. No trying to "connect" with the potential adoptive parents on a spiritual level. Just…be normal.

Which, of course, he failed at spectacularly. But, you know, it worked out in the end. It showed them that I had a supportive (albeit quirky) family. And it gave me a good story to tell.

It was mortifying at the time, but looking back? It was kinda…perfectly us. My dad and me. A little bit broken, a little bit weird, but ultimately, trying our best.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It's like, the whole point of the whole thing, right? Everyone keeps asking me what I want to *be* when I grow up, and honestly? I have no freakin' clue.

It's not that I don't have interests. I like music, and movies, and making sarcastic comments. But trying to put a label on it? "Popular girl"? "Artistic type"? "Future mom"? It all feels…wrong. Like trying to squeeze a square peg into a round hole.

I think I spent so long trying to be "normal" – you know, fitting in, not rocking the boat – that I never really figured out who *I* am underneath all that. And then suddenly I'm pregnant, and everyone's got opinions about what kind of mother I'm gonna be, and what kind of life I'm gonna have. It's overwhelming.

It's kinda scary, not knowing. Like, what if I make the wrong choices? What if I end up being someone I don't even like? But then again, maybe that's okay. Maybe it's okay to not have all the answers. Maybe it's okay to just…be.

I guess I'm still figuring it out. And maybe that's a lifelong process. Maybe there *isn't* a single "kind of girl" I am. Maybe I'm just…Juno. A messy, complicated, slightly sarcastic human being who's trying to do the best she can.

And honestly? That's probably enough. For now, anyway. It's kinda liberating, actually. Not having to define myself. Just…existing. And seeing where life takes me. Even if it's a little bit weird.

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on that. It was…a moment. A really awkward, uncomfortable moment.

Honestly? I was mostly just annoyed. Like, seriously? We're all adults here (well, mostly). You can't just sweep things under the rug by sending the females upstairs. It's not how life works.

I remember rolling my eyes so hard I thought they were gonna get stuck. And I think I mumbled something under my breath about how "subtle" that was. Leah was just mortified, bless her heart. She's way more polite than I am.

But underneath the annoyance, I was also…sad. It was a clear sign that my dad and Bren were still working through stuff. And it was just…weird to be treated like a kid again. Like, "Oh, you wouldn't understand, go play with your dolls." Except it wasn't dolls, it was just…avoidance.

I think I gave Bren a look that said, "Really?" And then I just kind of shrugged and followed Leah upstairs, because what else was I gonna do? Start a fight? That wouldn't have solved anything.

It just felt…dismissive. Like our feelings didn't matter. And honestly, that's kind of been a theme with my dad and Bren for a while. They're both good people, but they're not always great at communicating.

It was a small moment, but it stuck with me. It was a reminder that even when things seem okay on the surface, there's always stuff going on underneath. And sometimes, you just have to deal with it, even if it's awkward and uncomfortable.



Ugh. Just thinking about it makes me want to listen to The Moldy Peaches and hide under my covers.

Ugh, okay, that's…a lot to unpack. Open adoption. It's not something I really thought about at first, honestly. It felt kinda…complicated. Like, adding another layer of mess to an already messy situation.

But the more I think about it, and the more I talk to Mark and Vanessa, the more I get it. It's not about me trying to be a mom to the baby, or anything. It's about…honesty. And making sure the kid knows where they come from.

It's weird to think about, you know? Sending and receiving pictures. Getting updates on their life. It feels…intense. Like, a constant reminder of what I gave up. But also, maybe it's a good thing. Maybe it's a way to make sure I'm not just disappearing from their life completely.

I guess I'm scared of getting too attached. Of wanting more than I should. But Vanessa keeps saying it's not about that. It's about creating a healthy situation for everyone involved. For the baby, for the adoptive parents, and for me.

It's still kinda scary, though. It's not the traditional way of doing things. And I'm not exactly known for being traditional. But maybe that's okay. Maybe it's good to break the mold sometimes.

I think…I think I'm okay with it. As long as everyone's on the same page. As long as it's not going to be a constant source of drama. And as long as I can still move on with my life.

It's just…a lot to process. It's not easy, you know? Giving up a baby is hard enough. Adding the whole "open adoption" thing on top of it just makes it even more complicated. But I'm trying to be mature about it. And I'm trying to do what's best for the baby. Even if it's hard.



It's just…ugh. Life is weird.

Ugh. Okay, that moment. Yeah, that one kinda stuck with me. It wasn't like a dramatic, sobbing-into-my-pillow moment, 'cause I don't really *do* dramatic. But it was…a punch to the gut, you know?

I mean, I knew it was an open adoption. I knew I'd get to see the baby and stuff. But Gerta saying my *legal rights* would be terminated? That made it feel…real. Like, permanently real.

It wasn't about wanting to keep the baby, exactly. It was about…control, I guess. Or the lack of it. I was already giving up so much, and to hear that I wouldn't even have a legal claim? It felt like losing something else, even though I wasn't keeping it in the first place.

It was kinda messed up, honestly. Like, I was doing a good thing, a selfless thing, and I was still losing something in the process.

I think I mostly just felt…small. Like, I was just a kid making a really big decision, and everyone else was treating it like a legal transaction. It wasn't just a transaction to me. It was a person.

I remember just staring at Gerta, trying to process it. And then I think I made a sarcastic comment, 'cause that's what I do when I'm uncomfortable. It's my defense mechanism.

But underneath the sarcasm, I was just…scared. Scared of the future, scared of making the wrong decision, scared of losing everything. It was a lot to handle, you know? Especially for a sixteen-year-old who just wanted to finish her schoolwork and listen to The Moldy Peaches.



It was a turning point, I think. It made me realize how serious this all was. And it made me appreciate how much Gerta and Mark were willing to do for this baby. Even if it meant taking away my legal rights. It was complicated. Everything was complicated.

Ugh, Vanessa. Okay, look, don't get me wrong, she's nice. And she's super sweet to Paul. But her whole…*obsession* with having a baby? It's a lot.

It's just…intense. Like, she's been planning this for *years*. And it feels like she's more focused on the idea of being a mom than actually, you know, being a person. It's kinda sad, actually.

I get wanting a family. I really do. But it shouldn't be the only thing that defines you. And it definitely shouldn't be something you pressure someone else into.

Paul's a good guy. He deserves someone who loves him for who he is, not for his potential to be a father. And he deserves someone who's, like, emotionally available. Vanessa's kinda…checked out sometimes. Lost in her own little world of baby names and nursery decor.

It's just…it feels like she's trying to fill a hole in her life with a baby. And that's not fair to anyone. Especially not the baby.

I feel bad for her, honestly. She's clearly hurting. But that doesn't mean she gets to make Paul's life miserable. And it doesn't mean she gets to pressure me into doing something I'm not ready for.

It's a complicated situation. And I'm just trying to navigate it the best I can. But yeah, her wanting a baby so badly? It's…a lot to deal with. It's a whole thing. And honestly, I just want everyone to be happy. But I don't think she's going about it the right way.

Ugh, Mark. Honestly? It's…complicated.

When people ask him about being a dad, he always does that whole "I'm just gonna support Juno, whatever she decides" thing. And on the surface, it's kinda sweet, right? Like, he's being all mature and understanding.

But underneath? It feels…avoidant. Like he's scared to actually *think* about what being a dad means. He's good at being supportive in the moment, offering to go to doctor's appointments and stuff, but he doesn't really seem to grasp the long-term commitment.

It's not that I *want* him to be all gung-ho about diapers and sleepless nights, because, ew. But I want him to be real. I want him to acknowledge that this is a big deal, for both of us.

He's kinda like a puppy. Enthusiastic and sweet, but easily distracted. He needs someone to tell him what to do. And I'm not sure I want to be that person.

I get that he's young and scared, and he's trying to be a good guy. But being a good guy isn't enough. Being a dad is about more than just showing up. It's about being present, being responsible, and being willing to make sacrifices.

So, yeah. His response is…fine. But it doesn't exactly fill me with confidence. It just makes me think he hasn't really thought this through. And that's kinda terrifying.



It's like he's trying to be the perfect boyfriend, instead of thinking about being a potential father. And those are two very different things.

Ugh, okay, you want to know about the Loring's house? Seriously? It's…weird. It's not like they're *bad* people, Mr. and Mrs. Loring. They're just…intense. And their house is like a museum of awkward.

It's not that I'm scared of them, exactly. It's just…everything is so *perfect*. Like, aggressively perfect. Everything has its place, everything is coordinated, and you can practically feel them judging you if you even *think* about moving something.

And they're always *watching*. Not in a creepy way, necessarily. But they're always hovering, offering you things, asking you questions. It's exhausting. It's like being on display.
