Plus, their whole aesthetic is just…not me. It's all floral prints and antique furniture and porcelain dolls. It's like stepping back in time to a really stuffy tea party. I'm more of a flannel and Converse kind of girl, you know?

I just feel like I have to be…on. Like I have to pretend to be someone I'm not. I can't just relax and be myself. I can't slouch on the couch or listen to The Moldy Peaches without getting a disapproving look.

It's just…suffocating. I need space to breathe, you know? I need to be able to be messy and imperfect without feeling like I'm going to break something.

So yeah, I'm uncomfortable being left unsupervised in the Loring's house. It's just…not my vibe. It's a beautiful house, but it's not a home. Not for me, anyway. It's like a fancy dollhouse, and I'm not a doll. I'm a person. A complicated, messy, sarcastic person. And I need a place where I can be that person without feeling like I'm going to be judged.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. And it's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It's kinda raw.

It's not like I *wanted* to be in this situation, you know? It just…happened. And for a long time, I was just focused on getting through it. On making the best decision for everyone involved. Especially the baby.

But now, thinking about Mark and Vanessa…they're good people. Really good people. They *want* this baby. They've been trying for a long time, and they're gonna be amazing parents. They're gonna give this kid a life I…well, I couldn't give it right now.

So, yeah, it feels good. It feels…right. Knowing that this little person is going to be loved and cared for. That they're going to have a stable home and a family who will support them. That's a really powerful feeling.

It's not easy, though. It's still kinda weird to think about someone else raising my kid. And there's definitely a part of me that wonders what life would be like if I kept it. But I know I made the right decision.

I guess…it's like giving a really amazing gift. A gift that's gonna bring a lot of joy to someone else's life. And that's…pretty cool. It's a little bit sad, but mostly it's just…good.

It's complicated, okay? Don't ask me to explain it any further. It's just…a lot. But I'm okay with it. I think. Mostly.



It's definitely a lot more complicated than just "giving a gift," but that's the closest I can get to explaining it right now.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the "ASAP" thing? Seriously? That was, like, months ago. But fine, I'll explain. It's not just about the "ASAP," okay? It's about the *way* he said it.

Mark is...well, Mark. He's sweet, he's earnest, he tries really hard. But he's also kinda clueless. And he's always trying to sound cool and mature, and it just comes off as…awkward.

So, he's texting me, right? And he's all, "Can you send me those lyrics ASAP?" Like he's some secret agent or something. "ASAP"? Really? It's not a life-or-death situation, Mark. It's a mix CD.

It just felt…affected. Like he was trying too hard. And it was a perfect opportunity to tease him. Because, let's be honest, teasing Mark is a national pastime.

Plus, it's just a silly acronym. It's not like it adds anything to the conversation. It's just…extra. And I have a low tolerance for extra.

I'm a sarcastic person, okay? It's how I cope. And Mark is a very easy target. It's not mean-spirited, it's just…fun.

He got all flustered, which made it even better. He's so easily flustered. It's adorable.

Don't judge me. It was a harmless joke. And it was funny. And sometimes, you just gotta poke fun at the people you care about. It's a sign of affection, I swear.



Honestly, I probably overreacted. But that's just me. I'm a drama queen. It's a gift and a curse.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking about guitars? This is a surprisingly good question. It shows you pay attention.

Look, I don't *play* guitar, okay? I'm not, like, a musical prodigy or anything. But Paul, you know, my…baby daddy…he's really into music. And I've spent a lot of time around his guitars.

And honestly? I'm partial to **Fender Telecasters**.

They're just…classic. They're not flashy or pretentious. They're just solid, reliable, and they sound good. They're the kind of guitar that doesn't need to prove anything. It just *is*.

Paul has a vintage one, a sunburst color, and it's beautiful. It's got all these little scratches and dings, and it tells a story. It's not perfect, but that's what makes it cool.

I like that they're versatile too. You can play pretty much any kind of music on a Telecaster. Country, rock, blues…it can do it all.

Plus, they just look…right. They look like a guitar should look. Simple, functional, and a little bit rebellious.

So yeah, Fender Telecasters. They're my preferred brand. Even though I can barely strum a chord. It's a good guitar for a good guy. And that's all that really matters, right?

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the Melvins? That was, like, months ago. And honestly, it was a moment of weakness. A desperate attempt to impress Paul. Don't judge.

Look, Paul is…was…really into music. Like, *really* into music. And the Melvins are, like, legendary. He was talking about them, and I just…panicked. I didn't want him to think I was a total cultural void.

So I said I knew them. I said I'd seen them play at this tiny club in Minneapolis. Which was a complete lie. I'd never even *heard* of the Melvins before that conversation.

It was stupid. I know it was stupid. But in the moment, it felt like the right thing to do. I wanted him to like me. I wanted him to think I was cool.

And it worked! For a little while, anyway. He was all impressed and started talking to me about their discography and stuff. I just nodded and pretended to know what he was talking about. It was excruciating.

Eventually, he found out I was lying. He didn't get mad, exactly. He just looked…disappointed. And that was worse.

It taught me a lesson, though. Don't try to be someone you're not. Just be yourself. Even if yourself is a little bit awkward and doesn't know anything about obscure indie bands.

It was a dumb lie. A really dumb lie. And I still cringe when I think about it. But hey, everyone makes mistakes, right? Even me. Especially me.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so describing that is…complicated. It wasn't like, a grand romantic gesture kind of thing, you know? It wasn't all sparkly and dramatic. It was…comfortable. And kinda surprising.

Before all the baby stuff, I mostly just saw him as this quiet, kinda dorky guy who hung around Paulie. He was always sketching in his notebook or strumming his guitar. I didn't really *see* him, if that makes sense.

But when we started playing music together…it was different. It was like, we could just…understand each other. Without having to say a lot. He'd start playing something, and I'd just kinda fall into it. It wasn't about being perfect or showing off. It was just about making something that sounded good.

And singing with him…that was weirdly nice. He wasn't trying to impress me or anything. He just let me be me. And I felt like I could be honest with him, even when I was being a total mess.

It wasn't like I was suddenly head-over-heels or anything. It was more like…a connection. A quiet understanding. Like we were both a little bit lost, and we found a way to connect through the music.

It was a safe space, I guess. A place where I didn't have to be witty or sarcastic or pretend to be okay. I could just be…Juno. And he didn't judge me for it.

It was a good thing. A really good thing. Even if I didn't fully understand it at the time. And honestly, I still don't. It just *was*. And that's okay. Sometimes things don't need to be explained. They just are.



Ugh, I'm terrible at explaining feelings. It's way easier to just write a sarcastic essay. But yeah. That's kinda how it was with Mark and the music.

Ugh, okay, so everyone *always* asks about Roosevelt. It's a legitimate question, I guess, but it's kinda embarrassing to explain.

Well, it started with my dad. He was obsessed with Theodore Roosevelt. Like, seriously obsessed. He had books about him, pictures of him, he even tried to grow a mustache like him (it did not go well). He thought Roosevelt was a total badass. A man of action. A progressive. You know, all that stuff.

And then, when I got the guitar, it just…felt like a Roosevelt kind of guitar. It was sturdy, reliable, a little bit rough around the edges, but with a good heart. It felt…presidential.

Plus, it just sounded good. "Roosevelt" rolls off the tongue. It has a certain gravitas. "This is Roosevelt, and he's gonna lay down some serious chords." It just felt right.

It's also a little bit of a tribute to my dad. He's…complicated. But he loves me, and he always encouraged me to pursue my passions. And Roosevelt is a part of that.

So yeah, that's why I named my guitar Roosevelt. It's a little bit historical, a little bit personal, and a whole lot of awesome. Don't judge me. It's a good name for a guitar.

Ugh, okay, so the whole keeping Vanessa and Mark in the loop thing? It's…complicated. It's not like I *want* to keep them in the dark, but it's also not like I'm exactly thrilled about having to explain everything to them, you know?

Vanessa's cool, mostly. She's my friend, and she's trying to be supportive. But she also has a tendency to get, like, overly emotional. And I'm not really built for emotional displays. It's exhausting. She keeps asking about feelings and stuff, and I'm just like, "I'm processing. Leave me alone with my music."

And Mark…Mark's Mark. He's sweet, but he's also kinda clueless. He means well, but he doesn't really *get* it. He keeps offering to help with "baby stuff," and I'm like, "Dude, I'm not even keeping the baby!" It's weird.

It's just…it feels like they're treating me like I'm fragile or something. Like I can't handle this on my own. And I *can* handle this. I'm a pretty resourceful person. I can figure things out.

But I also know they care about me, and they want to be involved. And I guess it's the right thing to do, to keep them updated. It's just…awkward. And I'm really good at avoiding awkwardness.

So, I'm trying to find a balance. I'll tell them the basics, but I'm not going to overshare. And I'm definitely not going to let them turn this into a big, dramatic thing. It's my pregnancy, and I'm going to handle it my way.

It's just…ugh. Teenagers. And adults who act like teenagers. It's a lot.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me about this, like it's some huge, dramatic thing I'm agonizing over every second. And yeah, it *is* a big deal. But it's not like I woke up this morning and suddenly decided to give away my baby. It's been…a process.

And honestly? I'm 104% sure because I've thought about it. A lot. Like, obsessively. And I've realized I'm just…not ready. Not even close.

I'm seventeen. Seventeen! I'm still trying to figure out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raise a tiny human. I'm barely responsible enough to remember to feed myself, let alone a baby.

And it's not that I don't love this kid. I do. Already. But love isn't enough. It takes money, and stability, and a whole lot of patience. And I don't have those things. Not yet.

Mark and Vanessa…they do. They're a real couple, they have a nice house, they're excited. They *want* this baby. And they can give it a life I just can't.

It's not about giving up something, it's about giving this baby the best possible start. It's about being selfless, even when it's really, really hard.

And honestly? I think I need to figure out who *I* am before I can be a good mom. I need to go to college, maybe travel, maybe just…live a little. I need to find my own path.

So yeah, I'm 104% sure. It's the hardest decision I've ever made, but it's the right one. For me, and for the baby. And that's all that matters.

Don't get me wrong, I'm still scared. And sad. But I'm also…okay. Because I know I'm doing the best thing I can. And that's gotta count for something, right?

Ugh. Okay, that's…a complicated one. It wasn't exactly a party in my head, let me tell you.

It was weird, seeing them all…happy. Like, genuinely relieved and excited. And I get it, I *really* do. They'd been wanting a baby for so long, and I was just…the vehicle. The temporary solution.

But it still stung a little. It felt like, as soon as I walked out the door, it was like I hadn't even been there. Like I was just a means to an end. And I know that's probably how it had to be, and I *wanted* them to be happy, but it didn't make it easy.

I remember walking to the bus stop and just…feeling really empty. Like a balloon that had been let go. And hearing them laughing inside, planning the nursery and talking about names…it was a little bit like eavesdropping on someone else's life.

I tried to tell myself it was a good thing. That they deserved to be happy. That I was doing the right thing. But it was hard to shake the feeling that I was just…disposable.

Paul was really good about it, though. He just held my hand and let me be sad. He didn't try to fix it or tell me how I should feel. He just…was there.

I think, eventually, I realized that their happiness wasn't about *replacing* me. It was about finally getting what they wanted. And I could be happy for them, even if it hurt a little.

It was just…a lot. A lot of feelings. A lot of awkwardness. A lot of trying to figure out who I was, and what I wanted, and how to deal with all of it. It wasn't a celebratory mood for *me*, that's for sure. But I hoped, eventually, it would be for them. And for the baby. That was the important part.

Ugh. Seriously? People are *talking*? Like, I haven't noticed the entire school whispering behind their hands or anything. It's just…great. Fantastic. Exactly what a girl needs when she's already dealing with, you know, *gestational complexities*.

Look, it's my life, okay? And my body. And my decision. I don't need everyone and their grandma offering their opinions on what I should do. It's not a spectator sport.

And the rumors? They're mostly wrong. Like, wildly inaccurate. People are filling in the blanks with their own assumptions and judgments, and it's annoying. Really annoying.

I'm not gonna go into all the details, because that's private. But I'm making a plan. A good plan. And I'm doing what I think is best for everyone involved. 

Honestly, I wish people would just mind their own business. But I guess that's too much to ask. It's a small town, and everyone loves a little gossip.

So, how do I *feel* about the rumors? I feel…exhausted. And a little bit angry. And mostly just wanting everyone to leave me alone so I can figure things out.

It's my life, and I'm gonna live it my way. Even if everyone else has something to say about it. And if they don't like it? Well, that's their problem, not mine.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a lot of thinking to do. And maybe a craving for a really large tater tot. Don't judge.

Ugh. Okay. You want the real deal, huh? Not the cute, quirky movie version? Fine.

It sucks. It really, really sucks. Like, a giant, gaping hole in your chest kind of sucks. People keep saying it's the selfless thing to do, and I get that, logically. But logic doesn't really help when you're feeling like someone's ripped out a piece of your insides.

It's not like I *want* to give the baby up. It's just…I can't give it the life it deserves. I'm seventeen, still in high school, and barely able to take care of myself, let alone a tiny human. I'd be setting us both up for failure.

And that's the part that kills me. Knowing I'm doing what's best, but it doesn't *feel* best. It feels like a huge, messy, complicated loss.

I try not to think about it too much. I focus on the practical stuff – finding the right parents, making sure they're good people. But then, at night, when I'm alone, it hits me. And I just…cry. A lot.

It's not a happy feeling. It's not a noble feeling. It's just…sad. And scary. And confusing.

But I'm trying to be strong. For the baby. And for myself. Because I know, deep down, that this is the right thing to do. Even if it's the hardest thing I'll ever have to do.

So, how do I feel about it? I feel like a mess. A complicated, conflicted, hormonal mess. And I'm just trying to get through it one day at a time.



Don't ask me to pretend it's easy. It's not. It's the opposite of easy.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the whole surprise baby gender thing with Mark and Vanessa? It's...complicated. It's not like I had some grand plan, okay? It just kinda *happened*.

Honestly, it was mostly about them. They were so focused on, like, picking out names and decorating the nursery and planning everything perfectly. It was kinda stressing me out, actually. They were treating it like a project, not a person.

And I figured, if they didn't know what they were getting, it would force them to just...deal with it. To be prepared for anything. To love the baby no matter what. 

Plus, it felt kinda nice to have one last little secret. Like, one last thing that was just mine. I was giving them a baby, but I didn't want to give up *everything*. 

It was also a little bit of a test, I guess. To see if they could handle a little bit of uncertainty. To see if they were really ready to be parents.

I know it was a little bit selfish, maybe. But I was a mess at that point, okay? I was trying to do the right thing, but I was also trying to protect myself. And sometimes, those two things don't exactly line up.

It was a weird situation. And honestly, I'm still not sure if it was the right thing to do. But it felt right at the time. And they ended up being really great parents, so I guess it all worked out in the end.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on that woman. Seriously. It was…infuriating. And also, kinda sad.

Like, I get it. She probably sees a lot of girls my age coming in there, all scared and unsure. And maybe she thinks she's being helpful, offering advice. But it wasn't advice, it was judgment. And it was totally uncalled for.

She kept making these little comments, you know? About how "brave" I was, and how "difficult" this was going to be, and how "most girls" change their minds. Like I was some statistic, some case study. Not a person.

It felt like she was already writing my story for me, and it wasn't a very flattering story. She assumed I hadn't thought this through, that I was just some irresponsible kid who got into trouble. And that really stung.

Because I *had* thought it through. A lot. It wasn't a spur-of-the-moment decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make, and I was doing it for the right reasons. For the baby.

And it wasn't about me "giving up" on something. It was about giving the baby the best possible life. A life I couldn't provide right now.

She just didn't get it. She didn't understand that adoption isn't a failure, it's a loving choice.

I wanted to tell her to mind her own business, but I was too shocked to say anything. I just stared at the screen, trying to focus on the little bean inside me, and trying to ignore her judgmental little comments.

It made me feel even more alone, you know? Like everyone was already judging me, before they even knew my story. It was…not a fun day. It definitely made me want to punch something. But I didn't. Because I'm trying to be a responsible adult. Even when it's really, really hard.

Ugh, okay, buckle up. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like in the movies where everything magically works out with a cute montage and a perfectly timed song. It was messy. And awkward. And sometimes, really, really hard.

The biggest challenge, honestly, was just…everyone having an opinion. Like, suddenly *everyone* was an expert on my body and my life. My parents, my friends, even random people at school. Everyone had a suggestion, a judgment, a lecture. It was exhausting. Trying to figure out what *I* wanted, what *I* thought was right, was hard enough without everyone else chiming in.

Then there was the whole dealing-with-the-father thing. Paulie Bleeker is a good guy, don't get me wrong. But he's…Paulie Bleeker. He's sweet and kind of clueless, and he wanted to marry me and raise the baby, and that was…a lot. It was hard to explain to him that I wasn't ready for that, that I had other plans for my life. It hurt his feelings, and that hurt *my* feelings.

And then there were the adoptive parents. Mark and Vanessa Loring. They were amazing, truly. But it was still weird, you know? Giving a baby to someone else. Knowing that I wouldn't be the one raising it. It was a really complicated mix of sadness and hope and relief. I worried constantly if I was making the right decision, if they would be good parents, if the baby would be happy.

There was also the whole societal judgment thing. People looking at me differently, whispering, assuming things. It was like I was suddenly a different person. And trying to navigate high school while being pregnant was…a challenge. Let's just say gym class was awkward.

But honestly, the hardest part was just growing up. I was 16, and suddenly I was forced to confront all these big, adult questions about life and responsibility and what I wanted for my future. It was scary and overwhelming, but it also forced me to figure out who I was and what I believed in.

It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. I made the best decision I could, and I learned a lot about myself along the way. And I think, in the end, that's all anyone can ask for.

Ugh, okay, don't make me get all sappy. But fine. You asked. It's…complicated. This whole thing, getting pregnant and deciding to have a baby with Mark and Vanessa…it's kinda flipped my world upside down.

Before all this, love was, like, movies and songs. Romantic comedies and The Cure. It was all about grand gestures and soulmates and stuff. Now? It's…messier. It's about showing up, even when it's hard. It's about choosing someone, even when they're kinda flawed. It's about Vanessa and Mark, and how they're willing to be parents, even though they're, like, barely adults themselves. It's not always fireworks and butterflies. Sometimes it's just…quiet support. And that's okay. Maybe even better.

Responsibility? Oh god. That one hit me hard. I used to think responsibility was doing your homework and not getting grounded. Now I realize it's about bringing a whole human being into the world and making sure they're okay. It's about sacrificing your own wants and needs for someone else. It's terrifying, honestly. But also…kind of empowering? Like, I'm capable of more than I thought I was.

And growing up…well, that's been the biggest change. I used to think growing up was about getting a driver's license and going to college. Now I realize it's about figuring out who you are and what you want out of life. It's about making tough decisions and living with the consequences. It's about accepting that life isn't always fair, and that you have to make your own happiness.

I still don't have all the answers, okay? I'm still figuring things out. But I'm not the same person I was before. I'm…more aware. More thoughtful. More willing to take risks. And maybe, just maybe, a little bit more grown up.

It's still scary, though. But I think I'm ready. Or at least, I'm trying to be. And that's all anyone can really do, right? Just try.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking about the abandoned living room? It's not like I'm *obsessed* or anything. It's just…weird. And I like weird.

Look, it's a fully furnished living room. Just…sitting there. In the middle of a field. On Centennial Lane. No house attached. No explanation. It's like someone just…dropped it there. And then walked away.

It's unsettling, okay? It's like a movie set for a movie that was never made. Or a really messed up art installation.

Paul thinks I'm being creepy. He says I should just ignore it. But I can't. It's calling to me. It's like it's trying to tell me a story.

I keep imagining who lived there. What their life was like. Why they just left everything behind. Did they run away? Were they abducted by aliens? Did they just…get bored with their furniture?

It's a mystery, okay? And I like mysteries. It's a distraction from…everything else. From the baby, and school, and trying to figure out what I want to do with my life.

Plus, the wallpaper is kinda hideous. I'm judging their decorating choices. It's a coping mechanism.

So, yeah, I'm interested in the abandoned living room. Don't judge me. It's just…a thing. A weird, unsettling, fascinating thing. And I need to know what happened there. Even if it's something I don't want to know.



It's probably nothing. But it could be something. And that's enough to keep me going back.

Ugh. Don't even *start* with the Wizard. That guy was…creepy. Seriously. Still gives me the shivers just thinking about it.

Okay, so, when he whispered "Do you know how long I've wanted this?" it wasn't about the baby, okay? It wasn't about wanting to be a dad or anything normal like that. It was about…control.

He'd been building up this whole fantasy in his head, this perfect little family. And he wasn't thinking about what *I* wanted, or what was best for the baby. He was thinking about fulfilling *his* needs. He wanted to be the hero, the savior, the perfect father. He wanted to control the whole situation.

It was about him wanting a baby to complete *his* life, not about actually caring for a child. He'd been obsessing over it for ages, planning it all out in his head. And he saw me as a means to an end.

It was…gross. And honestly, it was terrifying. It made me realize how messed up he was, and how important it was to get away from him.

He wasn't looking at me, he was looking at the idea of a family. And that's what made it so unsettling. It wasn't about me at all. It was about his own twisted desires.

I still get a bad feeling when I think about that moment. It was a really dark time. And it just reinforced how important it was for me to make my own decisions, and to find a family for the baby who would actually love and care for it, not just use it to fill a void in their own life.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the juice container incident? Seriously? That was a *moment*, okay? A very emotionally charged moment.

Look, it wasn't just about the juice container. It was about everything. It was about being pregnant, and feeling totally out of control, and realizing my life was about to change forever. And the juice was just…the last straw. It was a symbol of all the sugary, processed crap I was putting into my body, and it just felt…wrong.

So yeah, I marched down the street and dramatically threw it in the trash. It felt good, okay? Cathartic.

And then I rushed to Dancing Elk Drug because I needed a pregnancy test. A *new* one. The one I had already taken was…compromised. Let's just say it had a run-in with a rogue sprinkler head. And I needed to confirm things. Again. Because denial is a powerful force, okay?

Plus, Mr. Elk is kinda cute. Not that I was thinking about that. At all. I just…needed a pregnancy test. And maybe to avoid my dad for a little while. He has a way of making everything worse.

It was a whole thing. Don't judge. It was a confusing time. And sometimes, you just need to throw a juice container in the trash and buy another pregnancy test. It's called coping.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. Seriously. That was…a moment. A deeply awkward, profoundly unsettling moment.

Okay, so, there I was, at the drugstore, trying to buy some prenatal vitamins – because, you know, *gestation* – and this girl, this…Tough Girl, just walks up to me. She was, like, intensely muscular and had a lot of piercings. And she just stares at me. For a long time.

And then, out of nowhere, she asks me, in this really blunt voice, "Are those real brown?"

I was completely stunned. I just stared back at her, mouth open, like a fish. I had no idea what she was talking about. And then it hit me. She was looking at my…well, you know. My chest.

I stammered something about it being none of her business and tried to walk away, but she followed me for a few feet, still staring. It was so weird and invasive and just…gross.

Honestly, I have no idea *why* she asked me that. Maybe she was just trying to be shocking. Maybe she was having a bad day. Maybe she just has really strange interests. I don't know. And I don't want to know.

It just goes to show you, people are weird. And sometimes, they say really inappropriate things. And sometimes, you just have to deal with it and try to move on.

It was a really uncomfortable experience, and it definitely made me question my life choices. But hey, at least it's a good story now, right? A really, really awkward story.

Ugh, okay, Leah. That girl. She was…a lot. But also, she was everything. Honestly, I don't think I could have gotten through any of it without her.

Before all the baby stuff, Leah was just…Leah. My best friend since forever. We bonded over music and hating gym class and making fun of everyone else. She was the one who always had my back, even when I was being a total mess.

When I found out I was pregnant, I didn't tell anyone at first. Except Leah. And she didn't freak out. She didn't judge me. She just…listened. And then she started brainstorming adoption agencies and making me hot chocolate.

She was the one who went with me to all the appointments. She sat through all the awkward conversations with the doctors. She helped me pick out baby names (which was surprisingly hard). And she was the one who held my hand when I was scared.

Leah wasn't always *right*. She had her own opinions about what I should do, and sometimes they clashed with mine. But she always respected my decisions, even when she didn't agree with them.

She was also the one who kept me grounded. When I was getting overwhelmed with everything, she'd remind me to just breathe and focus on what was important. And she'd make me laugh, even when I didn't feel like it.

Honestly, Leah was my rock. She was the one person I could always count on, no matter what. And I think she learned a lot too, about what it means to be a good friend and to support someone through a difficult time.

It wasn't always easy. We had our fights, our disagreements. But at the end of the day, we always had each other's backs. And that's what really mattered.

I think our friendship actually *grew* stronger through all of this. It forced us to be honest with each other, to be vulnerable, and to really rely on each other. And I'm so grateful for that. She's the best. Even if she is a little bit weird.

Ugh, okay, that whole thing was…complicated. And honestly, not my finest moment of planning. It wasn't like I had this brilliant, strategic idea. It kinda just…happened.

See, I was feeling really awkward around Mark and Vanessa. They were, like, the perfect couple. All happy and put-together. And I was this mess of hormones and anxiety, carrying their baby. It was weird.

And they kept asking about how things were going, and I kept giving them these vague answers. I was trying to protect them, I guess. Protect myself. I didn't want to ruin their perfect little world.

But it was eating me up inside. I felt like I was keeping this huge secret from them, and it was creating this distance between us.

So, when we were at the doctor's appointment, and the ultrasound tech was all, "Here's your baby!" I just…lost it. I blurted out, "Can we show Mark and Vanessa?" It was impulsive. Totally not thought through.

I think part of me wanted them to see it. To see what was happening. To realize that this wasn't just some abstract decision, it was a real, living baby. And part of me wanted to force them to deal with the reality of the situation.

It was a terrible way to handle things, honestly. It was messy and emotional and probably really uncomfortable for everyone involved. But it worked. It forced us to have a real conversation. It forced them to confront their feelings.

And it ultimately led to them being more supportive and involved.

So, did I have a grand plan? No. Was it a good idea? Probably not. But it was what I did. And sometimes, you just have to go with your gut, even if it's a really bad idea. It's just…how I roll.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *remind* me. That whole situation was a disaster.

My initial reaction when Mark was all, "Vanessa isn't home," wasn't like, shock or anything. It was more…a sinking feeling. Like, a really heavy, awful sinking feeling in the pit of my stomach. 

Because, honestly, I already kinda knew. I mean, the whole vibe was off. He was being weirdly casual, and he kept avoiding eye contact. And the house smelled like…teen spirit and regret.

So, it wasn't a surprise. But it was still really, really bad. It was like, all the carefully constructed walls I'd built up around myself just kinda crumbled. 

I think I just stared at him for a second, trying to process it. And then I probably said something sarcastic, because that's what I do when I'm freaking out. Something like, "Oh, well that's just *great*. So, she's off having a fabulous time while I'm stuck here with you?"

It was a defense mechanism, you know? Trying to make light of a really awful situation. But inside, I was just…completely devastated. It was the moment I realized everything was about to get a whole lot more complicated. And a whole lot more painful.

It was a really crummy moment. I wish I could just erase it from my memory. But, you know, life doesn't work that way.

Ugh, okay, you're digging into the past now? Fine. It's not like I haven't replayed that moment in my head a million times.

Look, it wasn't about *Mark* specifically being a sellout. It was…everything. It was the pressure, the expectations, the feeling like everyone was trying to tell me what to do with my life. And Mark, bless his heart, was just so…enthusiastic about making commercials. Like, genuinely excited about selling things to people.

It felt…wrong. He was this talented musician, and he was using his skills to hawk stuff. It felt like he was compromising his art for money. And I was already feeling pretty compromised, you know? Giving up the baby, dealing with my parents, trying to figure out who I was…it was a lot.

So the joke was a defense mechanism. A way to deflect. A way to make myself feel better about my own choices. If I could make *him* feel a little uncomfortable, maybe I wouldn't feel so uncomfortable about everything else.

It was also just…Mark being Mark. He's a little bit oblivious sometimes. And I like to poke fun at him. It's our thing.

I didn't mean to be mean, okay? I just…I was stressed. And sarcastic. That's what I do.

And honestly, he got over it. We're still friends. He still makes commercials. And I still make snarky comments. It's a whole thing.



It's complicated, okay? Life is complicated. And sometimes, you just say things you regret. But mostly, I regret not just being honest about how I was feeling. But that's me, always overthinking things.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It still kinda stings, honestly.

So, there we were, right? In the ultrasound room. It was weird. Seeing…it. It was just a little blob, but it was *something*. And I was trying to be all cool and detached, like, "Oh, look, a tiny human," but inside I was freaking out.

And Mark…he just kinda stared. Like, he didn't say anything for a really long time. And then he said, "Wow." Just… "Wow." It wasn't a happy "Wow." It was a…confused "Wow." A scared "Wow."

And it just…deflated me. I was expecting…I don't know. Some kind of reaction. Some kind of…support. But he just looked…overwhelmed. And I realized, in that moment, that he wasn't ready. He wasn't ready to be a dad. And maybe he wasn't ready to be with *me*, either.

It made me feel…small. And alone. And really, really scared. Because I was already dealing with giving up the baby, and now I was dealing with the fact that the guy I thought I was connecting with didn't seem to feel the same way.

I tried to play it cool, you know? I made a joke about it looking like a peanut. But inside, I was just…crushed.

It was a turning point, I think. It made me realize that I couldn't rely on him for emotional support. I had to figure things out on my own. And that was…terrifying. But also, kinda empowering.

So yeah. His reaction…it wasn't good. It made me feel a lot of things. Mostly bad things. And it definitely made me question everything. It was…a lot.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a heavy question. And honestly? It wasn't like a lightbulb moment, you know? It wasn't like I was suddenly *totally* okay with it, or *totally* against it. It was just…complicated.

At first, it felt like the easiest option. Like, the most logical thing to do. I was seventeen, I had my whole life ahead of me, and I wasn't exactly prepared to be a mom. Havenbrooke seemed…clean. Efficient. Like it would just *take care* of everything.

But then I actually went there. And it wasn't what I expected. It wasn't just a medical procedure. It was…a place full of people who were hurting. People who were scared. And it made me realize that it wasn't just about me. It was about a life. A potential life.

I remember sitting in the waiting room, and there was this girl who was, like, *really* young. And she was crying. And I just started thinking about what it would be like to be her. Or to be the baby.

It wasn't about being pro-life or pro-choice, or any of that stuff. It was about…feeling responsible. And realizing that I had a choice to make, and that choice would have consequences.

I didn't want to regret anything. And I didn't want to pretend like it hadn't happened.

So, yeah. It was scary. It was confusing. And it was definitely not easy. But ultimately, I realized that giving the baby up for adoption was the right thing to do. It wasn't the easy way out, but it was the best way. For everyone involved.

It still makes me think, sometimes. But I try not to dwell on it. I try to focus on the future. And on making sure that the baby has a good life.



It's not something I talk about a lot. It's…personal. But it's a part of who I am. And it's something I'll never forget.

Ugh. Okay. This is…awkward. You want me to talk about Bleeker? Seriously? It's not like I advertise that stuff. But fine. You asked.

Bleeker and I…we were friends for a long time. Like, since middle school. He was always…there. Kind of quiet, kinda dorky, but really sweet. He was the one who always had my back, even when I was being a total mess. And he was a really good guitar player, which, you know, is a plus.

Our relationship wasn't, like, a whirlwind romance or anything. It was slow. We just…hung out. A lot. We talked about everything and nothing. He knew I was pregnant, and he didn't freak out or anything. He was just…supportive. Which was really important.

Honestly, I didn't really *see* him as anything more than a friend for a long time. I was so focused on the baby and Paul and everything else that was going on in my life. I didn't really have time for romance.

But then…things started to change. We started spending more time alone together, just talking. And I started to realize that he wasn't just a friend. He was someone I really cared about. Someone who understood me. Someone who made me laugh.

As for when we…you know…became intimate? It wasn't a planned thing. It just…happened. After the whole adoption process was pretty much finalized. We were at his house, just talking, and…well, one thing led to another.

It wasn't perfect. It was kinda awkward and messy, to be honest. But it was also…good. It felt right. It was a way of connecting with him on a deeper level.

I don't want to get into all the details. It's personal. But it was a natural progression of our relationship. It wasn't about sex, it was about connection. It was about finding someone who made me feel safe and comfortable and loved.

It wasn't a fairytale romance, but it was real. And that's what mattered.



Look, it's complicated. Relationships always are. But Bleeker and I, we figured it out. We found a way to be happy together. And that's all that really matters.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a fairytale, you know? Like, I wasn't all glowing and happy and nesting. It was…complicated.

At first? Panic. Straight-up, full-blown panic. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about college applications and band practice, not…this. Bleeker was a sweet guy, don't get me wrong. But we were kids. We hadn't even figured out what *we* wanted to do with our lives, let alone raise a human being.

Then there was the awkwardness. Telling my dad was…rough. He tried to be supportive, but you could tell he was freaked out. And my mom, she was just…sad. For me. For everything.

And then there was the decision. Giving the baby up for adoption wasn't what I initially pictured for my life, obviously. It was scary. It felt like giving away a piece of myself. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. I wasn't ready. I wasn't equipped. And there were people who *were* ready. Mark and Vanessa. They were amazing.

So, how did I feel? A mess. Confused. Scared. Sad. But also…determined. I wanted to make the best of a really messed-up situation. I wanted to give this baby the best possible life.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears. A lot of second-guessing. But ultimately, I found strength in my decision. And I learned a lot about myself. About what I wanted. About what I was capable of.

It wasn't a happy ending, exactly. But it was *my* ending. And that's what mattered. It was messy and real and…well, it was me. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even if it was totally terrifying.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on that. Telling Bleeker…it was…a whole thing. It wasn't like some romantic movie moment, okay? It was awkward. And messy. And involved a lot of nervous rambling on my part.

I mean, he was Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless Bleeker. He was still figuring out how to tune his guitar, let alone raise a human being. So, yeah, I was terrified.

I didn't just blurt it out, obviously. I tried to ease into it. I started talking about responsibility, and growing up, and how things change. Which, looking back, was probably a really bad way to start. He just looked confused.

Then I just…said it. "I'm pregnant." It came out kinda squeaky, I think. And he just stared at me. Like, a deer in headlights.

He didn't say anything for a *long* time. Which, honestly, was the worst part. The silence was deafening. I was bracing myself for him to freak out, or run away, or just…disappear.

Then he finally said, "Wow."

Just… "Wow."

It wasn't exactly the reaction I was hoping for. But then he started asking questions. A lot of questions. Like, really basic questions. "How…?" "What does that even mean?" "Are you…okay?"

I tried to answer them as calmly as I could, but I was still a mess inside. I was scared, and confused, and overwhelmed.

He didn't offer to solve everything, or promise to be the perfect dad. He just…listened. And he was genuinely concerned. And that, honestly, was enough.

It wasn't a perfect moment. It was awkward and uncomfortable and a little bit heartbreaking. But it was real. And it was the start of something…complicated. But something.



It was definitely not how I pictured telling anyone I was pregnant. But then again, my life rarely goes according to plan.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, right? Everyone always wants to know about that. It's not like a movie scene, all dramatic and teary-eyed. It was…complicated.

Honestly? At first, I was mostly just annoyed. Like, seriously? This was happening to *me*? I had plans! I was gonna go to college, maybe move to New York, become a writer. A baby was not in the plan. Not even remotely.

But then, as it started to…become real, I got scared. Really scared. I was a kid myself, you know? I wasn't ready to be a mom. I didn't have the money, the support, the…anything.

So, I started thinking about what was best for the baby. And that wasn't me. I knew I couldn't give it the life it deserved. And that was…hard to admit.

Choosing Mark and Vanessa…that was the hardest part. They were…perfect. They were stable, they were loving, they were ready. And I knew they would give the baby everything I couldn't.

When I actually handed the baby over…it wasn't like a Hollywood breakdown. It was…sad. Really, really sad. But it also felt…right. Like I was doing the right thing.

There were definitely moments where I questioned everything. Where I wondered if I'd made a mistake. But then I'd remember Mark and Vanessa, and how much they wanted this baby. And I knew I'd made the best decision I could.

It still stings sometimes. I think about the baby, about what its life is like. But I also know that it's loved and cared for. And that's all that really matters.

It wasn't easy. It wasn't glamorous. It was just…life. And sometimes, life throws you curveballs. And you just have to deal with them the best you can.

It made me grow up, I guess. It forced me to think about things I hadn't thought about before. And it taught me a lot about myself. And about what it means to be a good person.



It's still…a lot to process. But I'm okay. I think. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know my musical tastes? It's…complicated. It's not like I have a super refined playlist or anything. It kinda depends on my mood, you know?

But I'm a big fan of The Moldy Peaches. Obviously. Kimya Dawson is a genius. Her songs are just…real. They're funny and sad and honest all at the same time. They get me.

I also like Belle & Sebastian. They're kinda twee and melancholic, but in a good way. And Death Cab for Cutie. Ben Gibbard is a master of heartbreak songs.

I'm into a lot of indie stuff, I guess. Bright Eyes, Arcade Fire, The Shins…bands that aren't afraid to be a little bit weird.

I also have a soft spot for 80s music. Like, The Cure and New Order. My dad used to listen to them, so it's kinda nostalgic.

And sometimes, when I'm feeling particularly angsty, I just listen to really loud punk rock. Like, Bikini Kill or Sleater-Kinney. It's a good way to release some energy.

I'm not really into mainstream pop music. It's just…too manufactured. I prefer music that feels authentic and genuine.

Basically, I like music that makes me *feel* something. Whether it's happy, sad, angry, or just…weird. It's gotta be real, you know? And it's gotta have good lyrics. I'm a sucker for a good lyric.

So yeah, that's my musical taste in a nutshell. It's a little bit all over the place, but that's okay. I'm a little bit all over the place, too.

Ugh. Okay. "The Wizard of Gore." You're asking *me* about "The Wizard of Gore"? Seriously? You know I'm, like, a relatively normal teenager, right? Not a connoisseur of…that.

Look, I accidentally stumbled across a trailer for that thing online. And it was…intense. Like, aggressively intense. And not in a good way. It's all fake gore and weird, unsettling stuff. It's trying to be shocking, but it just comes across as…cheap.

It's not even scary, it's just…gross. And not in a fun, "let's watch a horror movie with our friends" kind of way. It's in a "I need to scrub my brain with bleach" kind of way.

I get that some people are into that kind of thing. I guess. But it's not my cup of tea. I prefer my horror movies to have, like, a plot and some actual character development. And maybe not so much…splatter.

Honestly, it just feels exploitative. Like it's trying to shock you for the sake of shocking you, without any real artistic merit.

So, my opinion? It's bad. Really bad. Avoid it. Unless you're into that sort of thing, in which case, you do you. But don't expect me to join you. I'll be over here, watching something with a little more…substance. Like, maybe a documentary about penguins. Or a Wes Anderson movie. Anything but "The Wizard of Gore."



Seriously. I need to go wash my eyes now.

Ugh, Madison. Okay. Look, it's not the *worst* name. But it's…so popular. Like, seriously popular. It feels kinda…beige. You know? Like a khaki pants kind of name.

It's not offensively bad, it's just…predictable. It's the kind of name you expect to see on a Starbucks cup. Or on a cheerleader. No offense to cheerleaders. Or people named Madison.

I guess it's a nice-sounding name. It's got a good rhythm. But it just feels…overdone. Like, can't we come up with something a little more original?

I'm more of a fan of names that are a little bit quirky, a little bit different. Like, Beatrice. Or Clementine. Or even just something simple and classic, like Hazel.

But Madison? It's fine. It's just…not my vibe. It feels like the kind of name someone would pick because it's popular, not because they actually *like* it.

Honestly, naming a kid is hard. It's a big responsibility. You want to pick a name that they'll grow into, a name that reflects their personality. And Madison just doesn't feel like it has a lot of personality.

So, yeah. That's my opinion. It's not terrible, but it's not great. It's just…Madison.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, right? It's not something you just *think* about lightly. It's like, the biggest decision of your entire life. And it sucks. It really, really sucks.

Honestly? It's terrifying. It's giving up a piece of yourself. A piece that's growing inside you. It feels…wrong. Like you're failing somehow. Even though you're not.

But it's also…the right thing. For the baby. And for me. I mean, I'm sixteen. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm barely ready to be a *person*. I have my own life to figure out. And this baby deserves parents who are ready, who can give it everything it needs.

It's not like I don't love it. I do. I already do. But love isn't always enough. Sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go.

It's complicated. It's messy. It's heartbreaking. And it's not something anyone should have to go through alone. That's why having Paul and Vanessa…they've been everything. They get it. They don't judge. They just…support me.

It's not a happy ending, exactly. It's just…an ending. And a new beginning. For me, and for the baby. And I have to believe that it's going to be okay. That the baby will be happy. That I'll be okay.

It's not easy. It's probably the hardest thing I'll ever do. But it's my decision. And I'm going to own it. Even if it breaks my heart a little bit. Or a lot.



It's just…it's a lot to process, you know? It's not something you can just explain in a few words. It's a feeling. A complicated, messy, heartbreaking feeling.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know how I…deal with all this? It's not exactly a walk in the park, let me tell you. It's more like stumbling through a minefield while trying to balance a stack of books and avoid getting judged by everyone you know.

Honestly? A lot of it is just…denial. Like, pretending everything is normal, even when it totally isn't. I still hang out with Paul and Leah, I still go to school (mostly), I still listen to The Moldy Peaches. I try to keep things as normal as possible, because if I start thinking about everything all at once, I'll probably just freak out.

But then there are the moments where it hits you, you know? Like, when I feel the baby kick, or when I'm filling out adoption paperwork, or when my dad is trying to be supportive but clearly has no idea what he's doing. Those are the hard moments.

I cope by being sarcastic. It's my defense mechanism. If I can make a joke about it, it feels less scary. And I talk to people. Paul and Leah are amazing. They don't judge me, they just listen. And my dad, even though he's clueless sometimes, he's trying.

I also try to focus on the future. I'm not keeping the baby, but I want to make sure it goes to a good home. I want to find a couple who will love it and take care of it. That gives me a sense of purpose.

It's also about accepting that I'm not perfect. I'm going to make mistakes. I'm going to feel overwhelmed. I'm going to want to hide under the covers and pretend this isn't happening. But I can't. I have to keep going.

It's a lot of responsibility for a sixteen-year-old, I know. But I'm trying to be mature about it. I'm trying to make the best decisions I can. And I'm trying to learn from this experience.

It's not easy. But I'm stronger than I thought I was. And I'm going to get through this. Even if I have to listen to a lot of unsolicited advice from well-meaning adults along the way.

Ugh, okay, that's…a really good question. And a really hard one. It's like, the whole point of being me, I think.

Look, I *like* being in control. I like figuring things out on my own. It feels…safer, I guess. Like, if I can handle everything myself, then nothing bad can happen. Which is obviously a totally ridiculous thought, but it's how I operate.

But then, you know, life throws you a curveball. Like, a *huge* curveball. And suddenly you realize you can't do everything alone. You need people. You need help.

And that's the part that freaks me out. Because asking for help feels like…admitting defeat. Like saying, "I can't handle this." And I *hate* feeling helpless.

But I've learned, slowly, that it's okay to need people. It doesn't make you weak. It makes you human.

Paul and Vanessa, they were…lifesavers. They didn't judge me. They didn't try to tell me what to do. They just…listened. And they helped me when I needed it. And I realized that letting them help didn't take away my independence. It actually *gave* me more freedom. Because I didn't have to carry everything on my shoulders by myself.

It's a balance, I guess. You gotta be strong enough to stand on your own two feet, but also smart enough to know when to lean on someone else. It's about knowing your limits, and being willing to ask for help when you reach them.

And it's about trusting people. Which is hard. Especially when you've been burned before. But it's worth it. Because having people who care about you, who support you, who believe in you…that's the best feeling in the world.

So, yeah. I'm still working on it. It's a process. But I'm learning to embrace the messiness of it all. And to accept that sometimes, you just need a little help. Even if you're a fiercely independent, sarcastic teenager with a baby on the way.

Ugh, okay, Bleeker. That's…complicated. It wasn't exactly a fairytale romance, you know? It started out as, like, a mutual appreciation for sad songs and awkward silences. He was just…there. A constant. And kinda sweet, in a dorky way.

At first, when I found out I was pregnant, I kinda pushed him away. I didn't want him to feel obligated or anything. I was already feeling overwhelmed, and the thought of dragging him into this mess…it was too much. I thought I could handle it all on my own. Which, looking back, was pretty stupid.

But he didn't go anywhere. He just kept showing up. Bringing me snacks, listening to me rant, being generally supportive without being, like, smothering. He didn't try to fix things, he just…was there. And that actually meant a lot.

As the pregnancy went on, and things got more real, I started to rely on him more. He helped me pick out baby names (which was a disaster, let me tell you), he went to doctor's appointments with me, and he even tried to build a crib (which also was a disaster).

It wasn't always easy. We had a lot of awkward conversations, a lot of misunderstandings. He didn't always *get* it, and I didn't always want him to. But we kept talking. And we kept trying.

By the end, he wasn't just my friend, he was…something more. He was someone I trusted, someone I could lean on, someone who genuinely cared about me and the baby. He wasn't the father I originally envisioned, but he was *a* father. And a good one.

It wasn't a grand, sweeping romance. It was messy and imperfect and real. And honestly, that's what made it work. It wasn't about finding "the one," it was about finding someone who was willing to go through this crazy journey with me. And Bleeker was definitely that.

He's still kinda dorky, though. But I wouldn't trade him for anything.

Ugh, okay, this question *always* comes up. It's not like I just randomly picked a name out of a mythology textbook, you know? It's…complicated.

My dad, he's kinda into Greek mythology. Always has been. He's a professor, so he's got a lot of time to think about that stuff. And when my stepmom, Bren, got pregnant with me, he wanted to name me something…significant. Something with meaning.

He said Juno was the goddess of marriage and childbirth. Which, looking back, is kinda ironic, considering how things turned out. But at the time, he thought it was a beautiful name. Strong. Regal.

Honestly, I always thought it was a little pretentious. Like, "Oh, look at me, I'm named after a goddess!" It felt…heavy. And I'm not exactly regal. I'm more of a sarcastic, tater-tot-loving teenager.

But Bren, she really liked the name. And my dad wanted to make her happy. So Juno it was.

I used to hate it. I wanted to be called June, or something normal. But over time, I've kinda grown into it. It's…me. It's a little bit quirky, a little bit different. And it reminds me of my parents, even if they're kinda weird.

So yeah, that's the story. I'm named after Juno, the goddess of marriage and childbirth. It's a long story, and it's a little bit embarrassing, but that's how it happened. Don't judge.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. Honestly? It stung. Like, a lot.

I mean, I knew Vanessa wasn't exactly thrilled about the whole situation. But I thought, maybe, seeing the ultrasound photo, seeing *the baby*, would change things. Make her feel…something. Connection, maybe? Or at least, not actively relieved.

But she was relieved. She was actually *happy* that it wasn't a…a perfect little cherub. That it looked kinda weird. And I just…I didn't get it.

It made me feel like the baby wasn't even a person to her. Just a problem. A thing to be dealt with. And I was trying so hard to be mature about this, to do the right thing, to give this baby a good life. And she was just…glad it wasn't cute?

It made me question everything. Like, was I doing the right thing giving the baby up? Was I just being selfish, wanting to feel like a good person? Was Vanessa right to be scared?

I didn't say anything, of course. What was I gonna say? "Hey, thanks for being happy my baby looks like an alien?" That would've been awkward.

I just kinda…shut down. I think I mumbled something about needing to go to the bathroom and then I just walked away.

It was one of those moments where you realize people are complicated. And sometimes, they don't react the way you expect them to. And sometimes, that really hurts.

It didn't change my decision, though. I still knew giving the baby up was the right thing to do. But it definitely made me feel…sad. And a little bit lonely. And it made me realize that this whole thing was gonna be a lot harder than I thought.

Ugh. Vanessa's mom. Brenda. Okay, that was…a moment. A *very* intense moment. It was like walking into a hurricane of floral print and passive-aggressive comments. Seriously, the woman could weaponize a casserole.

So, I found out she was coming over right as I was trying to explain to Vanessa that maybe, just maybe, running away wasn't the *best* solution to her problems. And then Brenda just…appeared. Like a disapproving ghost.

Her face was like, frozen. And then the questions started. Rapid-fire. "What are you doing here?" "Are you a bad influence?" "Do you even *know* what responsibility is?" It was a full-on interrogation.

I tried to be polite, at first. You know, "Hi, I'm Juno, I'm a friend of Vanessa's…" But she wasn't having it. She was all, "Friend? You look like you barely know which end of a toothbrush to use!" Charming.

So, I switched tactics. I just…started being brutally honest. Not rude, just…direct. I told her I wasn't trying to ruin Vanessa's life, I was just trying to be there for her. I told her that Vanessa was a smart, capable person who deserved to make her own choices. And I told her that maybe, just maybe, she should try listening to her daughter instead of lecturing her.

It didn't exactly *calm* her down, but it did throw her off balance. She sputtered for a minute, then started talking about how hard she'd worked to provide for Vanessa. Which, okay, fair enough. But it didn't excuse her being a total control freak.

I just let her talk. I didn't interrupt. I just listened. And eventually, she ran out of steam. She just…sat there, looking exhausted.

Then Vanessa finally spoke up and told her mom she needed to trust her. And that actually seemed to do the trick. Brenda still wasn't thrilled about me, but she backed off.

Honestly, it was terrifying. But I figured, if I just stood my ground and spoke my mind, I had a chance of getting through to her. And it worked. Sort of. It was definitely a learning experience. Mostly, I learned to avoid Vanessa's mom at all costs.



It was a whole thing. And I needed a really big slice of pie afterwards.

Ugh, okay, here we go. This is…the big one, right? Everyone always wants to know about this. It's not like I hadn't thought about it, you know? It wasn't a snap decision.

Honestly? It was a lot of things. Mostly, it was realizing I wasn't ready. I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being.

I love music, I love drawing, I love hanging out with my friends. I had plans. Not, like, *grand* plans, but plans. And a baby…a baby would change everything. It would derail everything.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby. I wanted that kid to have everything. A stable home, two parents who were ready and willing, a good education, opportunities…things I couldn't guarantee.

Mark, the dad, he was…sweet. But he was also a mess. He was still in high school, he didn't have a job, and he wasn't exactly known for his responsible behavior. I didn't want that for the baby.

Vanessa and Mark, they were…perfect. They were older, they were stable, they were excited. They wanted a baby so badly. And they could give that baby a life I just couldn't.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still is. It's not like I didn't feel anything. I felt *everything*. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about giving a baby the best possible life. And sometimes, that means letting go.

It still sucks, sometimes. But I don't regret it. I really don't. I just hope…I hope that kid knows I loved them, even before they were born.



It's complicated. It's messy. It's not a happy story, exactly. But it's my story. And I'm okay with it. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, you wanna talk about the whole deadbeat lab partner thing? Fine. It's a long story, and it involves a frog, a lot of regret, and Paulie Bleeker being surprisingly judgmental.

See, in biology, we had to dissect a frog. A *real* frog. And I was partnered with this kid, Dave, who was, like, super into science. He had all the tools, he knew all the terms, he was basically a tiny doctor. And I…was not.

I just…couldn’t do it. I stared at that frog, and it just looked so…sad. And then I started thinking about all the things that frog could have been doing, instead of being on a tray in a science classroom. Like, hopping around, catching flies, being a frog.

So I mostly just stood there, making vague noises and pretending to take notes. Dave did all the actual dissecting. He was not pleased. He kept giving me these withering looks, and muttering things under his breath about “equal contribution” and “academic integrity.”

And then, at the end of class, he called me a “deadbeat lab partner.” And it stuck. It was just…so accurate. I totally phoned it in. I let him do all the work. I was a terrible partner.

It wasn’t about being lazy, exactly. It was about…I don’t know. A weird sense of empathy for a dead frog? It was dumb. I know it was dumb. But I couldn’t help it.

Paulie thought it was hilarious, of course. He said I was “philosophically opposed to frog dissection.” Which, I guess, is kinda true.

So yeah, that’s why I consider myself a deadbeat lab partner. It’s a badge of honor, I guess. A reminder that sometimes, I’m just a weirdo who can’t handle a scalpel. And that’s okay. Mostly.

Ugh. Seriously? Another drama explosion? Can't people just, like, *do* the science without turning it into a soap opera? It's a lab, not a therapy session.

Okay, so they're bickering. Let me guess: he mansplained something, she called him out on it, and now everyone's feeling personally attacked? Classic.

I'd probably just roll my eyes and mutter something under my breath like, "Oh, for the love of all that is holy..." Then I'd pointedly focus on the experiment. Like, *really* focus. Stare intensely at the beaker. Pretend I'm conducting groundbreaking research.

If they actually tried to involve me, I'd give them the "look." You know, the one that says, "I have better things to do with my life than mediate your relationship issues."

And if they *still* didn't get the hint, I'd probably say something like, "Look, can we just get this done? I have a life, you know? And frankly, watching you two argue is making my brain hurt."

I'm not a relationship counselor. I'm a teenager trying to pass biology. I don't have time for this.

Honestly, it's probably a power thing. He probably thinks he knows everything, and she's probably tired of being talked down to. It's exhausting.

But whatever it is, I'm staying out of it. Unless it directly impacts my grade, in which case, I might be forced to intervene. But only as a last resort. Because drama is the worst.

Ugh. Okay. You really wanna get into this, huh? It's not "hasty," okay? It's…thoughtful. And complicated. And definitely not something I'm taking lightly.

Look, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm a junior in high school. I collect vintage records and I'm trying to figure out what I want to do with my life. I was not planning on being a mom right now. Like, at all.

It's not that I don't think babies are great. They're cute and stuff. But I'm not ready. I'm not equipped. I'm barely equipped to handle my own life, let alone another human being.

And it's not just about me. It's about the baby, too. It deserves parents who are ready and able to give it everything it needs. And right now, that's not me. Or my dad, honestly. He's…well, he's my dad.

Mark, the…the father, he's a nice guy. But he's also a senior and he's going to college far away. He's not exactly equipped to be a dad either. We talked about it. It's not a good situation for anyone.

So, I'm considering…termination. It's a hard word. But it's the most responsible thing to do. It's not what I *want*, but it's what I think is best.

It's not a decision I made on a whim. I've been thinking about it for weeks. Talking to my friend Leah. And even…talking to Paul and Annie. They're being really supportive, which is good.

It's scary. And sad. And I feel a lot of things. But I'm trying to be practical. I'm trying to make the best decision for everyone involved.

It's my body, my life, and my choice. And it's not something anyone else can tell me what to do.



It's not easy to talk about. Okay? So, please, just…try to understand.

Ugh, okay, you want to know about the Boone's Farm Snow Peak Peach obsession? It's a whole thing. It's not like I *actively* seek out sugary wine coolers, okay? It just…happened.

It started with Paul. He was, like, really into it. Said it tasted like summer and regret. Which, honestly, is a pretty accurate description of a lot of things in my life.

But it's not just the association with Paul. It's the *flavor*. It's not too sweet, it's got a little bit of a tartness to it, and it just…hits the spot. It's like a nostalgic hug in a bottle. It reminds me of being a kid, even though I definitely wasn't drinking Boone's Farm as a kid.

And it's not pretentious, you know? It's not like people are trying to impress anyone with Snow Peak Peach. It's just…a simple pleasure. A little bit trashy, a little bit sweet, and a whole lot of comforting.

Plus, the color is really pretty. It's this pale pink, and it just looks…peaceful. Which is something I could definitely use more of in my life.

Look, I'm not saying it's a sophisticated drink. It's not. But it's *my* drink. And it's the one I reach for when I need to unwind and just…be.

Don't judge me. It's a complicated relationship. And honestly, I don't need to explain myself to anyone. It's Snow Peak Peach. It's good. End of story.

Ugh, okay, you're asking about the whole…situation. Yeah, people are kinda weird about it. It's not like it's a *normal* thing, I guess. A sixteen-year-old getting pregnant? It throws people for a loop.

I think a lot of it is just…shock. Like, they don't know how to react. They're used to things being a certain way, and then BAM, here I am, with a baby on the way. It messes with their expectations.

And then there's the whole adoption thing. People have opinions about that, too. Some people think it's sad, like I'm "giving up" my baby. They don't understand that I'm doing what's best for everyone involved. It's not about me not wanting the baby, it's about wanting the baby to have a life I can't give it right now.

My parents are…complicated. They're trying to be supportive, but they're also kinda freaked out. They're worried about me, and they're worried about what other people will think. They're good people, but they're not always good at dealing with…unconventional situations.

And then there's Paul and Annie. They're amazing, but even they have moments where they're like, "Are you sure about this?" It's not that they don't trust me, it's just that they want me to be happy.

I think people just have a hard time understanding that I've thought this through. I'm not being reckless or irresponsible. I'm making a difficult decision, and I'm doing it with a lot of thought and care.

It's frustrating, honestly. I wish people would just accept my decision and support me. But I guess that's not always how things work. People are gonna judge, people are gonna worry, and people are gonna have opinions. I just have to try to ignore it and focus on what's best for me and the baby.

It's my life, and I'm gonna live it the way I want to. Even if it's not what everyone else expects.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with that. It was…complicated. Bren was right to be concerned, obviously. It was a mess. A total, spectacular mess.

I think…I think I mostly got defensive. Like, immediately. I was all, "He's going through a thing! It's not like we're, like, *dating* dating. It's just…comfort." Which, looking back, was a total lie. And a really lame excuse.

I remember saying something like, "You don't understand! He *gets* me. He actually listens to me, unlike…everyone else." Which was also a lie. Bren listens to me. She always has. I was just…being a stupid teenager.

I tried to downplay it, to make it seem like it wasn't a big deal. I was probably trying to convince myself as much as I was trying to convince her. I kept saying he was separating, that it was almost over. But it wasn't. Not really.

Bren, being Bren, didn't let it go. She called me out on it. She was all, "You're better than this, Juno. You deserve someone who's available, who can actually be with you." And it stung. It really stung. Because she was right.

I think I ended up just…shutting down. I got quiet and moody and avoided her for a while. I was embarrassed and ashamed and just…confused.

It wasn't my finest moment, honestly. I was a mess. And Bren deserved better than to be treated like that. She was a good friend, and I was being a terrible one.

It took me a while to realize she was right, and to actually do something about it. But she was there for me, even when I was being a total idiot. That's Bren. She's the best.



Ugh. Just thinking about it makes me cringe. It was a bad situation. A really bad situation. And I'm glad it's over.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're bringing up the slushie? It was a *moment*, alright? A complicated moment.

Look, it was Mr. Pearly's memorial service. And it was…weird. Everyone was being all sad and quiet and pretending to be super respectful. And honestly? It felt fake. He was a weird guy! He collected porcelain dolls and tried to convince me to get an abortion with a pamphlet about the joys of being child-free. He wasn't exactly a saint.

And I was just…overwhelmed. I was pregnant, I was dealing with Paul and Vanessa, I was trying to figure out my life, and I was stuck at a memorial service for a guy who didn't even really *want* me to be there.

So, yeah, I poured my blue raspberry slushie into the urn. It was a spontaneous act of rebellion. A way of saying, "This is ridiculous! Life is messy and complicated and sometimes you just need a little bit of sweetness to get through it!"

It wasn't about disrespecting Mr. Pearly, it was about…honesty. It was about acknowledging the absurdity of the situation. And it was about finding a little bit of joy in a really sad moment.

Plus, it looked kinda cool. The blue against the gray ashes. It was a statement.

Okay? It was a statement. Don't judge me. You weren't there. It was a whole thing. And honestly, I don't regret it. It was a very Juno thing to do.

Ugh, okay, that's…a loaded question. "Coped" is a strong word. More like…survived. Barely. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like stumbling through a minefield while trying to maintain a semblance of cool.

Honestly, a lot of it was just denial at first. Like, this isn't happening to *me*. This happens in movies, not to sarcastic, indie-music-loving teenagers. But then it started to feel…real. And terrifying.

The biggest thing was probably just…talking. Which, for me, is like pulling teeth. But I had to talk to Paul, and to my dad, and even to Vanessa, which was a whole other level of awkward. They were surprisingly…supportive. My dad, especially. He's a weirdo, but he's *my* weirdo.

And then there was Leah. She was a lifesaver. She just…got it. She didn't judge me, she didn't try to fix me, she just listened. And she made me laugh, which was really important.

It was also about figuring out what *I* wanted. Everyone had an opinion about what I should do with the baby, but ultimately, it was my decision. And that was scary. But it was also empowering.

I leaned on music a lot. It was my escape. My way of processing everything. The Moldy Peaches, especially. They just…understood.

And honestly, a lot of it was just taking things one day at a time. Not thinking too far ahead. Just focusing on getting through the next hour, the next minute, the next second.

It was messy and complicated and confusing. And I definitely wasn't always graceful about it. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself along the way. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And that even when things are really, really hard, there's always hope.

It wasn't easy, but it made me…me. And I guess that's worth something. Even if it involved a lot of awkward conversations and a whole lot of emotional turmoil.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so Mark was…a lot. Not in a bad way, exactly. Just…a lot. He was, like, aggressively wholesome. You know? Like he was trying *too* hard to be a good guy. It was kinda endearing, but also kinda exhausting.

He was super into everything. Like, he was building a treehouse, and he was really excited about it. And he was learning to play the guitar, and he wanted to serenade the baby. It was…a lot of enthusiasm.

He was also really sensitive. Like, he cried during the adoption meeting. Which, okay, I get it, it's emotional. But it was a *lot* of crying. I was trying to be supportive, but I was also kinda uncomfortable. I'm not really a feelings person, you know?

He was really good with Paul, though. They bonded over music and stuff. And he was really respectful of my boundaries, which I appreciated. He didn't try to force anything on me. He just wanted to be a good dad.

Honestly, I was kinda skeptical at first. He just seemed…too perfect. But the more time I spent with him, the more I realized he was just a genuinely good person. He was a little bit dorky, and a little bit awkward, but he had a good heart.

And he made really good pancakes. That's important.

It was weird, though, hanging out with a potential dad. It made everything feel…real. Like, this wasn't just some abstract decision anymore. This was about a real person who was going to raise my baby. It was a lot to process.

But ultimately, I think Mark was a good choice. He was kind, he was stable, and he was ready to be a dad. And that's all that really mattered. Even if he did cry a lot.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on Bleeker. That kid. He means well, I guess, but he's…not always the most tactful.

When he said something about me looking like I was "expanding horizons," or whatever awkward phrasing he came up with? It was…complicated.

Part of me wanted to punch him. Like, seriously. It wasn't exactly a subtle observation, okay? And I was already feeling super self-conscious about everything. My body was changing, and it was weird, and I was trying to process all of it. And he just had to point it out.

But then, another part of me felt…seen. He was the only one who was really acknowledging what was happening. Paul and Mark were trying to be all supportive and normal, but Bleeker was the one who was like, "Whoa, you're actually getting bigger." It was kinda refreshing, in a weird way.

And honestly, it was kinda sweet. He was trying to be funny, and he was clearly nervous about saying the wrong thing. He's just…Bleeker. He's a dork.

So, I mostly just rolled my eyes and made a sarcastic comment back. That's my default setting, you know? It's how I deal with things. But inside, I was probably a little bit touched. And a little bit annoyed. And a whole lot confused.

It was just…another reminder that everything was changing. And that I was changing with it. And that was scary. But also, maybe, a little bit exciting.

Don't tell Bleeker I said that, though. He'll get a big head.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. Like, poking around in the messy parts of my brain. But fine, you asked.

It wasn't the physical stuff, honestly. Morning sickness was gross, sure, but manageable. And people were way more supportive than I expected. It was…the feeling. The feeling of knowing I was doing the right thing, but still feeling like a total failure.

Like, everyone kept saying I was brave and selfless, and I was all, "Yeah, right." It felt more like I was giving up. Giving up on a future I hadn't even really planned for, but still…a future.

And the waiting. Waiting for the adoption to be finalized. Waiting to meet Mark and Vanessa, the couple who were going to raise my kid. It was like my whole life was on hold. And every time I felt the baby kick, it was a reminder of what I was giving away.

But the hardest part, I think, was just…accepting that I wasn't going to be a mom. Not right now, anyway. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, you know? And adding a baby into the mix would have just…complicated things.

It's not that I don't want kids someday. It's just that now isn't the right time. And it was hard to reconcile that with the fact that I was carrying a life inside me.

It's weird. It's sad. It's complicated. And it's something I'm still working through. But I know I made the right decision. For me, and for the baby. And that's what matters, I guess.

It just…doesn't make it any easier.
