Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on that guy. Seriously. He was…intense. And smelled faintly of mothballs.

He was standing out there with this sign that said "Babies are miracles!" and he kept yelling at everyone going in and out. It was super awkward.

But the thing he kept saying, the one that really stuck with me, was that every baby is a "perfectly formed human being with a soul." Like, right from the get-go. He said they were "gifts from God" and that "every life is precious."

It wasn't about, like, helping kids who are *already* here, you know? It was just about stopping people from making a choice. It felt…simplistic. And kinda judgmental.

It's not like I didn't think about the baby being a person. I did. That's why it was so hard. But it's also about what's best for everyone involved. And sometimes, the best thing isn't bringing a baby into the world.

He didn't seem to understand that. He just kept yelling about souls and miracles. It was…a lot. Honestly, it just made me feel more confused and stressed out. It didn't help anyone.



It was a really hard day, and that guy definitely didn't make it any easier. He just…didn't get it.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive that. It was…a lot. The clinic. Right.

So, I went in for the confirmation appointment, you know? To actually *know* for sure. And I ended up running into this woman in the waiting room. She was…older. Maybe in her forties. And she was *very* pregnant. Like, seriously huge.

She was flipping through a magazine, and she kept glancing at me. I was trying to be invisible, but it's kinda hard to be invisible when you're a sixteen-year-old girl with a look of sheer panic on your face.

Finally, she just…looked at me and smiled. It wasn't a pitying smile, which I appreciated. It was…knowing. Like she understood.

She said, "Big decision, huh?"

And I just kinda nodded. I couldn't really talk. My throat felt all closed up.

She continued, "It's okay to be scared. It's okay to not know what you're doing. It's okay to feel…everything."

And then she said something that really stuck with me. She said, "Whatever you decide, it's going to be okay. You're stronger than you think."

She didn't ask me anything about my situation. She didn't offer any advice. She just…acknowledged me. And that was enough.

It was just a brief conversation, but it meant a lot. It was like she was a secret ally, someone who understood what I was going through without me having to say a word.

I never saw her again after that. But I often think about her. And I hope she's doing okay. She gave me a little bit of courage when I really needed it. It was a small thing, but it made a big difference.

Ugh. Thinking about it still makes my stomach flip. But yeah, that was the encounter. A quiet moment with a stranger who somehow knew exactly what I was feeling.

Ugh, okay, don't even *remind* me about that. Su-Chin. She's…intense. And very, very good at reading people.

So, I was trying to be cool, right? Trying to seem like I had it all together, even though I was, like, a total mess inside. And I casually mentioned taking Adderall to help me study for the big test. Just trying to sound smart and put-together.

Her face…it just *changed*. It wasn't angry, exactly. It was more…disappointed. And concerned. Like I'd just confessed to robbing a bank or something.

She didn't yell or anything. She just looked at me with those really intense eyes and said, really quietly, "Juno…that's not a good idea."

And then she launched into this whole thing about how it's a crutch and how it's messing with my brain and how I should just try harder. It was a lot.

I tried to brush it off, to make it seem like no big deal. But she wasn't having it. She kept asking me questions, trying to figure out how long I'd been taking it and why.

It was super awkward. And honestly, it made me feel really guilty. I hadn't really thought about it that way before. I just thought it was a way to get good grades.

She didn't lecture me for hours or anything, but she definitely made me think. And it made me realize that maybe I wasn't being as honest with myself as I thought I was.

Su-Chin always has a way of doing that. She sees right through you. It's annoying, but also…kind of helpful. She just wants what's best for you, even if you don't want to hear it.

So yeah, she was not impressed. Not at all. And honestly, looking back, I'm glad she wasn't. It made me re-evaluate things.

Ugh, okay, don't even *make* me relive that. Seriously. It was…a lot.

It wasn't, like, one specific thing. It was the *vibe* of the whole place. It smelled like antiseptic and regret. And everyone in there was just…staring straight ahead. Like they were trying not to make eye contact with anyone. Which, honestly, made me want to make eye contact with *everyone* just to see if they were as freaked out as I was.

But what really got to me? It was the magazines. Seriously. They were all, like, six months old and filled with articles about perfect babies and blissful motherhood. And I was sitting there, knowing I wasn't planning on being a mother. At least, not yet. And it just felt…wrong. Like I was in the wrong place.

And then there was this one woman, she was, like, *really* pregnant. And she was reading a book about breastfeeding. And I just thought, "Oh my god. That's my future if I don't make the right decision." Which is dramatic, I know. But that's how I felt.

It wasn't the idea of being pregnant that scared me. It was the idea of being trapped. Of having my life completely changed forever. Of not being able to be…me anymore.

And then I started thinking about all the things that could go wrong. What if the baby wasn't healthy? What if I couldn't find a good family for it? What if…what if…what if…?

It was just a lot to process. And I was sitting there, surrounded by people who were either excited about becoming parents or terrified about something else entirely. And I just felt…completely alone.

So yeah, the magazines, the smell, the silence, the pregnant woman…it all just combined to make me feel like I was in a horror movie. It was not a fun afternoon.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? We're still talking about Bleeker? It's been, like, years. It's awkward even *thinking* about it.

Look, Bleeker was…Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless, definitely a little bit of a dork. And yeah, at the time, I totally had a thing for him. He was a safe harbor in a sea of chaos, you know? Everything was so messed up with the baby and Paul and everything, and he was just…there. Quietly supportive.

But feelings change. People change. We were kids. We were both figuring things out. And honestly, we were just…different. He was all quiet intensity and I was…well, I was me. Loud and sarcastic and trying to navigate a really complicated situation.

Do I still *care* about him? Yeah, sure. He's a good person. I hope he's doing okay. But do I have *feelings* for him? Like, romantic feelings? No. Not anymore.

It was a moment in time. A chapter in my life. And I'm grateful for it, in a way. But I've moved on. I've grown up. And I'm looking for something…different now. Something that challenges me, something that makes me laugh, something that doesn't involve a lot of awkward silences.

So, no. I don't have feelings for Bleeker. It's just…history. And honestly, I'd rather not dwell on it. It's embarrassing enough talking about it now.



Can we please talk about something else? Like, the existential dread of being a young adult? Or the questionable fashion choices of the early 2000s? Anything but Bleeker.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started on Vanessa's decorating choices. It's...a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot.

She's going for this whole "whimsical woodland creature" vibe, which, fine, whatever. But it's not whimsical, it's aggressively cute. There are stuffed animals *everywhere*. And everything is pastel. Pastel pink, pastel blue, pastel green...it's like being trapped inside a marshmallow.

And the wallpaper? Don't even get me started on the wallpaper. It's got little foxes and owls and bunnies wearing tiny hats. Tiny. Hats. It's terrifying.

She keeps saying it's "gender neutral," but it feels overwhelmingly feminine. Like, if this baby turns out to be a boy, he's gonna be seriously confused.

I tried to suggest maybe a more...minimalist approach. Like, a nice, calming color on the walls and a few well-chosen pieces of art. But she just looked at me like I was trying to ruin her life.

Honestly, I think she's projecting all her own childhood fantasies onto this baby. It's a little weird.

I mean, I appreciate that she's excited about the baby. And I know she wants to create a special space for it. But it's just...too much. It's like a sugar rush for the eyes.

I'm just hoping the baby doesn't develop a lifelong aversion to woodland creatures. And tiny hats. Seriously, the hats are the worst part.



I'm just gonna try to stay out of it. It's her baby, her room. I'll just bring a black and white mobile or something to balance it out. A girl can dream, right?

Ugh. Nesting. Okay, so Annie's been on this whole nesting kick lately. It's...intense. Like, suddenly everything has to be perfect. Everything has to be *fluffy*. It's kinda freaking me out, honestly.

I mean, I get it, I guess. It's supposed to be this instinctual thing, right? Like, preparing your space for the little human. But it feels…weird. I'm not exactly a "domestic goddess" type. I'm more of a "survive high school" type.

And the baby room? It's…pink. So much pink. Annie's gone full-on princess. I tried to suggest a more neutral color scheme, maybe like, a cool gray or something, but she just gave me *the look*. You know the look. The "I'm pregnant and hormonal and you will not question my decorating choices" look.

It's not that I don't want the baby to have a nice room. It's just…it feels like I'm pretending to be someone I'm not. Like, I'm supposed to be all excited about picking out curtains and mobiles and tiny little socks. And I'm just…overwhelmed.

I'm more focused on, like, figuring out how I'm going to finish high school and what I'm going to do with my life after the adoption. The baby room feels…distant. Like it's happening to someone else.

I think I'm mostly just scared. Scared of the responsibility, scared of the future, scared of not being a good mom, even if it's just for nine months.

So, yeah, nesting. It's…a thing. And I'm trying to be supportive of Annie, but honestly, I just want to hide in my room and listen to The Moldy Peaches until it's all over. It's a lot. A *lot*.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on those women. Seriously. It was…a whole other planet. Like, I walked into that mall and suddenly I was in a documentary about the 1%, except everyone was wearing designer handbags and judging my shoes.

It was mostly the way they *carried* themselves, you know? Like they were too good for everything. And the shopping! It wasn't about *needing* anything, it was about…the experience. Like, they needed a personal shopper to pick out a $500 sweater that looked exactly like the $50 sweater I saw at Plato's Closet.

And the conversations! All about their kids' private schools and their husbands' jobs and their vacation homes. It was exhausting just listening to it. It felt so…disconnected from real life. Like, they were living in a bubble.

I mean, I get wanting nice things. I do. But there's a difference between wanting something and *needing* it. And there's a difference between being confident and being…entitled.

It just made me feel weirdly grateful for my life, you know? For my dad and Mark and even Leah, despite everything. We don't have a lot of money, but we have each other. And that's worth more than all the designer handbags in the world.

Honestly, it was a good reminder that happiness doesn't come from stuff. It comes from people. And maybe a really good mix CD. But definitely not from a $500 sweater.

It was…educational, I guess. A glimpse into a world I don't really understand. And honestly, I'm okay with that. I'd rather be me, with my thrift store finds and my sarcastic wit, than be one of those women. No offense. But seriously. Ugh.

Ugh. Okay, so, motherhood. It's...a lot. It's not what I expected, not even close. I mean, I knew it was gonna be a big deal, obviously. But it's like, a whole different level of big.

Before, my biggest responsibility was, like, finishing my English assignment and maybe not flunking out of school. Now? Now there's a tiny human who completely depends on me for *everything*. It's terrifying and amazing and exhausting all at the same time.

The changes are...weird. My body is still kinda messed up, honestly. And my priorities have totally shifted. I used to care about, like, what band was cool and what movie was coming out. Now I care about diaper rash and sleep schedules. It's a major adjustment.

And the responsibility? It's crushing sometimes. Knowing that this little person is gonna be shaped by everything I do and say...it's a lot of pressure. I don't want to mess it up. I want to give her the best life possible, even though I'm, like, a total mess myself.

But it's also...good. Like, really good. There's this feeling of love that I didn't even know existed. And it makes all the sleepless nights and the worry and the changes worth it.

I'm still figuring it out, you know? I'm not a natural mom or anything. I'm just trying to do the best I can. And I'm learning as I go. It's scary, but it's also kinda exciting.

It's not the life I planned, but it's my life now. And I'm gonna embrace it, even if it's messy and complicated and totally overwhelming. Because that little girl? She's worth it.



Honestly, it's a lot to process. And I still have no idea what I'm doing. But I'm trying. And that's all I can do, right?

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me about this. It's not like I just randomly picked Mark and Vanessa because they had a Pottery Barn catalog aesthetic, okay? There's a *reason*.

It's not about finding the "perfect" parents, because that doesn't exist. It's about finding parents who are…stable. And who *want* a kid. Like, really want a kid. Not just because they think it'll fix their marriage or something.

See, I met a lot of couples. And a lot of them were…intense. Like, they had a whole nursery decorated before they even met me. And they were asking me about college funds and extracurricular activities. It was creepy. It felt like they were already planning out the kid's entire life.

Mark and Vanessa, they were different. They were…normal. They were a little bit older, they had a good life, and they just seemed…happy. And they weren't trying to project anything onto the baby. They just wanted to love it.

And honestly, I needed that. I needed to know that the baby was going to a place where it would be loved and cherished, not treated like a project.

Plus, Vanessa is infertile. She *really* wants a baby. And I think that's important. I think the baby deserves parents who are going to be completely devoted to it.

It's not about finding the richest or the most successful parents. It's about finding parents who are going to be good parents. And I think Mark and Vanessa are going to be really good parents.

It's a hard decision, okay? And I'm still kinda freaked out about it. But I think it's the right decision. For me, and for the baby. And that's all that matters.

Ugh. Okay, so you're asking about the "what ifs" of keeping the baby? Don't even get me started. It's a whole mess of stuff, honestly. It's not like it's a simple decision, even though sometimes I wish it was.

First off, there's school. I'm a junior. I'm supposed to be thinking about colleges and stuff, not diapers and midnight feedings. I'd probably have to drop out, or at least take a really long break. Which kinda messes up my whole plan.

Then there's money. Or, you know, the complete lack thereof. My dad's a construction worker, and my stepmom's a realtor. They're good people, but they're not exactly rolling in dough. I'd be relying on them a *lot*, and I don't want to be a burden.

And then there's...everything else. Like, I'm seventeen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am. I'm not exactly equipped to raise a human being. I mean, I can barely keep my room clean.

There's also the whole social thing. Being a teen mom is...not exactly cool. People would judge me. And I'm already kinda awkward, so that wouldn't help.

And Paul? He's...Paul. He's supportive, but he's also kinda flaky. I don't know if I can rely on him to be a real partner. And even if he was, he's still a seventeen-year-old boy. We're both kids.

It's not just about me, either. It's about the baby. The baby deserves a stable home, and a loving family, and opportunities. And I don't know if I can provide all of that.

It's a lot to think about. It's scary. And it's why I'm leaning towards adoption. It's not what I *want*, exactly, but it might be what's best for everyone involved.

It's not like I don't love the baby already. I do. But love isn't always enough. Sometimes, you have to make hard choices. And sometimes, the hardest choice is the right one.



Ugh. Just thinking about it makes my head hurt. Can we talk about something else? Like, music? Or tater tots? Anything but babies right now.

Ugh, okay, so Leah. She meant well, but she was *really* pushing it, you know? When I told her I was thinking about adoption, she got all…intense. Like, suddenly she was an expert on everything.

She suggested I just…keep it. Like it was that simple. She was all, “You could raise it! You could get a job, and we could figure it out!” And she kept talking about how I was “strong” and “capable” and how I could “do anything.”

It wasn’t that I didn’t appreciate the vote of confidence, it’s just…it wasn’t realistic. I was sixteen! I was failing band! I was barely keeping it together as it was! I didn’t want to ruin my life, or the baby’s life, by trying to be a mom when I wasn’t ready.

She kept trying to paint this picture of us all living together, like some kind of weird, dysfunctional family. It was…a lot. And honestly, it kinda freaked me out.

She also suggested I talk to the baby’s father, Mark, more. Which, yeah, I was trying to, but he was…Mark. Not exactly the most reliable guy.

But the main thing she wanted me to do was just *keep* the baby. She thought it was the “right” thing to do. Which, you know, is her opinion. But it wasn’t the right thing for *me*.



It was a really hard conversation. She was upset, and I was upset. But ultimately, I had to do what I thought was best, even if it meant disappointing her.

Ugh, okay, let's talk about the play area. Look, it wasn't my finest moment, alright? I get it. It wasn't cool.

It was…a defense mechanism. Seriously. I was feeling super awkward and out of place, being at a kid's birthday party with Mark and his mom. And those women were just…really into it. Like, *really* into the whole "mommy and me" thing. And I was just…not.

I was trying to be funny, to deflect from my own discomfort. It was a stupid, immature thing to do. I was being sarcastic and judgmental, and it wasn't fair to them. They were just trying to have a good time with their kids.

I was also, honestly, just scared. Scared of growing up, scared of responsibility, scared of what my life was going to look like. And making fun of other people is an easy way to feel superior, even if it's completely irrational.

I know it doesn't excuse my behavior. It was mean. And I felt bad about it afterwards. I just…I don't always think things through. I say whatever comes to mind, and sometimes that gets me into trouble.

It was a learning experience, I guess. I realized that being funny isn't an excuse for being hurtful. And that sometimes, it's okay to just be quiet and observe, instead of trying to be clever.

So yeah, I made fun of the women at the play area. It was wrong. And I'm not proud of it. I'm still working on being a better person, okay? It's a process.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about that? It was…complicated. And honestly, a little mortifying.

Look, Vanessa was being…Vanessa. All intense and overly-supportive and wanting to "connect with the baby." She's a good person, I guess, but she can be a lot. And I was, like, emotionally vulnerable and trying to be polite. It was a bad combination.

I didn't *allow* her to touch my belly, exactly. It was more like she just…did it. Before I could even process what was happening. She just reached out and put her hand on me. And I froze.

I was already feeling weird about the whole adoption thing, and about letting anyone get close to the baby. And Vanessa was just…overwhelming. I didn't have the energy to argue with her.

It wasn't about wanting her to feel connected to the baby. It was about avoiding a scene. And honestly, I was just trying to get through the day without completely falling apart.

It was a mistake. I should have said something. But I didn't. And now everyone's talking about it.

It just…happened. And it was awkward. Really awkward. Can we please talk about something else now? Like, the merits of different types of pizza? Or the existential dread of being a teenager? Anything but Vanessa's hand on my stomach. Please.

Ugh, okay, you noticed that, huh? It's…a thing. It's really weird, actually. Like, people just automatically part like the Red Sea when I'm waddling down the street.

I think it's a combination of things. First of all, I'm obviously *very* pregnant. Like, it's not subtle. People can see I'm carrying a human being, and I guess they feel like they need to be extra careful around me. Like I'm some kind of fragile porcelain doll. Which is ridiculous, because I'm pretty tough.

And then there's the whole "pregnant lady gets special treatment" thing. People feel like they need to be polite and accommodating. They hold doors open for me, they offer me their seat on the bus, they give me a wide berth in the grocery store. It's…nice, I guess. But also kinda annoying.

It's like, I'm still just me. I'm still Juno MacGuff. I can still handle myself. I don't need to be treated like I'm about to fall apart at any moment.

But I also get it. I mean, I'm carrying a baby. It's a big deal. And people are just trying to be nice.

It's just…weird. It's like I'm suddenly a VIP. And I'm not a VIP. I'm just a girl who made a mistake and is now trying to do the right thing.

So yeah, people give way to me when I walk with my belly. It's a strange and slightly unsettling experience. But I'm getting used to it. And honestly, sometimes it's kinda convenient.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me about Mark and Vanessa. The "wholesome" couple. Like they're some kind of perfect Stepford parents. And yeah, on paper, they *are* perfect. They have the house, the jobs, the matching sweaters…it's a little unsettling, honestly.

It's not that I don't think they'd be good parents. They would. They absolutely would. They're…prepared. They've got the nursery decorated, the college fund set up, the organic baby food ordered. It's a little intense.

But that's kinda the problem. It feels…planned. Like a project. And this isn't a project. This is a *person*. A little human being who deserves to be loved unconditionally, not just…raised according to a schedule.

I guess I'm worried that they'll try to mold the baby into something it's not. That they'll have expectations and rules and a whole life mapped out before the kid even learns to walk. 

I want the baby to be loved for who it *is*, not for who they want it to be. And I'm not sure Mark and Vanessa get that. They seem…focused on appearances. On doing everything "right."

It's not that they're bad people. They're just…different. And I want the best for this baby. I want it to be happy and free and allowed to be itself. And I'm not convinced that's what would happen with Mark and Vanessa.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple decision. And it's not about finding the "perfect" parents. It's about finding the *right* parents. And I'm still trying to figure out who that is.



It's just…they feel a little too…perfect. And perfect is usually boring. And I don't want this baby to be bored.

Ugh, Mark and Vanessa. Okay, don't even get me started. They're...a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot.

Look, I'm not gonna lie, at first I thought Mark was kinda sweet. A little clueless, maybe, but genuinely trying. And Vanessa? She's...intense. Like, aggressively put-together intense. Everything has to be perfect, you know? The house, the clothes, the *life*.

But the more I hung out with them, the more I realized they were kinda…fake. Like, they were trying so hard to be the perfect couple, the perfect family, that it felt totally contrived. It was exhausting just being around them.

And the way they talked about everything? So…sanitized. Like they were reading from a script. No real emotion, no real vulnerability. It was creepy.

I felt bad for Mark, honestly. He seemed kinda lost in Vanessa's world. Like he was just trying to keep up. And I definitely felt bad for his kid, Gracie. She deserved parents who were actually present, not just…performers.

They weren't *bad* people, exactly. Just…superficial. And kinda exhausting. I'm glad I didn't have to spend too much time with them. It was a relief when everything was over.

Honestly, they reminded me of those perfectly decorated houses you see in magazines. They look amazing, but you wouldn't actually want to *live* there. Too much pressure to keep everything perfect.

So yeah, that's how I feel about Mark and Vanessa. They're…a lot. And not in a good way.

Ugh, okay, Mrs. Mancini. Don't even get me started. It wasn't like she *hated* me, exactly. It was more…complicated. And honestly, a little bit unfair.

She was just…protective of Bleeker. He's her only kid, and she's kinda overbearing. And I get it, to a point. He's a sweet guy, but he's also…Bleeker. A little spacey, a little oblivious. She probably worried I'd take advantage of him, or lead him astray.

But I think the real issue was…I wasn't what she expected for him. He comes from a really nice family, you know? They have a big house and a boat and everything. And I'm…well, I'm me. A little rough around the edges, a little sarcastic, a little bit of a mess. 

She probably thought I wasn't "good enough" for him. Like I was gonna drag him down or something. Which is ridiculous, because Bleeker is a good person, and he deserves someone who loves him for who he is, not someone who fits into some perfect little mold.

She also didn't really *get* me. She tried to be nice, but she just didn't understand my sense of humor or my…everything, really. It was awkward. Really awkward.

It wasn't that she didn't like *me* specifically, it was that I didn't fit into her vision of what Bleeker's life should be. And honestly, that's her problem, not mine. But it still stung a little. It always does when someone judges you for not being what they want you to be.



It all worked out in the end, though. She eventually came around. Sort of. She still side-eyed me a lot, but she realized that Bleeker was happy with me, and that's what mattered most. I think.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive this. It's…complicated. It wasn't like, a grand romantic gesture moment, you know? It wasn't like I was *waiting* for a mix CD.

It was mostly just…boredom, honestly. And a little bit of guilt.

After everything with Paul, and the whole adoption thing, I was just…stuck. Stuck in my head, stuck in my room, stuck feeling weird. I was avoiding everyone, including my dad. And I was definitely avoiding thinking about anything important.

So I was just flipping through channels, trying to find something to distract myself, and I saw the CD case. Mark had left it on my dresser when he came over to, like, awkwardly apologize for being a weirdo. I hadn't even looked at it.

I figured, what else am I gonna do? Watch another rerun of *The Real World*? So I put it in my Discman.

And…it wasn't terrible. It wasn't what I expected. It wasn't all sappy love songs or anything. It was…him. It was a bunch of weird, indie stuff that I wouldn't normally listen to. But it was also kinda…thoughtful. He clearly put some effort into it.

And as I listened, I started to realize that he wasn't just some clueless guy. He was…a person. A flawed, awkward, kinda sweet person. And I started to see him differently.

It wasn't like I suddenly fell in love or anything. It was more like…I started to understand him. And maybe, just maybe, I started to understand myself a little bit better too.

So yeah, that's how I started listening to the CD. Boredom, guilt, and a little bit of curiosity. It wasn't a fairytale moment, but it was a start. And sometimes, that's all you need.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start*. Eight months. It feels…weird. Like, really weird. It's not like in the movies, where you're all glowing and serene. It's more like I'm a walking, talking watermelon. A very tired, slightly nauseous watermelon.

Everything is uncomfortable. Sleeping is a joke. I can't bend over without sounding like a walrus. And the heartburn? Don't even get me started on the heartburn. It's like a dragon is living in my chest.

And the *kicks*. Oh my god, the kicks. It's like having a tiny, internal ninja practicing martial arts. Sometimes it's cute, but mostly it's just…intense.

But it's also…kind of amazing. Like, there's a whole little person growing inside me. It's a little scary, but also really cool. I find myself talking to it sometimes, even though I know it can't understand me. I mostly just tell it to stop kicking so much.

I'm also starting to feel…emotional. Like, I'll be watching a commercial and suddenly I'm crying. It's ridiculous. Paul thinks it's hilarious.

Honestly, it's a lot. It's exhausting, it's uncomfortable, it's emotional. But it's also…worth it. I'm giving this baby up, yeah, but that doesn't mean I don't care. I want it to have a good life, and I want to do everything I can to make that happen.

So yeah, eight months pregnant. It's a lot. But I'm getting through it. One heartburn-fueled, ninja-kicked day at a time. And honestly? I'm kinda excited to meet this little person. Even if it means I'll never be able to eat a whole pizza again.

Ugh, okay, seriously? This is a *thing*. People are always staring. It's super annoying. Like, can't a girl just exist without being analyzed?

I think it's a combination of things. First of all, I'm not exactly blending in. I mean, I have opinions. And I'm not afraid to share them. And I dress...comfortably. Let's just say I'm not following any fashion trends.

And then there's the whole...situation. You know, the baby thing. People are curious. They want to know the story. They want to judge. It's rude, but it happens.

I think some people are just surprised that I'm, like, a normal person. I don't fit their expectations of what a pregnant teenager should be. I'm not all sad and dramatic. I'm sarcastic and cynical and I listen to The Moldy Peaches.

And honestly, I think some people are just nosy. They like to stare and gossip. It's a human thing. It's pathetic, but it's true.

I try to ignore it. I put on my headphones and pretend they're not there. But it's hard. It makes me feel self-conscious. Like I'm on display.

But you know what? I'm not going to let it bother me. I'm going to be myself, even if people stare. Because I'm awesome, and they're just jealous. Probably.

Or maybe they just think I look like someone famous. I don't know. It's probably not that. It's probably just my general awkwardness.



Whatever it is, it's annoying. And I wish people would just stop.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? Bleek and Katrina? That's…a choice. A *bold* choice.

Look, I'm happy for Bleek, I guess. He deserves to have someone to go to prom with. He's a good kid, even if he's kinda…intense. And Katrina's…well, Katrina's Katrina. She's got a lot of confidence, which is good, I guess. But also, she's kinda scary.

It's just…they're so different. Bleek's all quiet and into fantasy stuff, and Katrina's, like, a cheerleader who's probably already planning her wedding. It feels like a disaster waiting to happen.

I mean, I get it. Sometimes you just want to take a chance and do something unexpected. But I have a feeling this is gonna end with a lot of awkwardness and maybe a public meltdown.

Honestly, I'm mostly worried about Bleek. He's a sensitive soul. He doesn't deserve to get his heart broken. But then again, maybe this is a good learning experience for him. Maybe he'll realize that sometimes, things just don't work out, and that's okay.

It's just…weird. Really weird. I'm gonna need a lot of snacks to process this. And maybe a pep talk for Bleek. He's gonna need one.

I'm not saying it *won't* work out. But I'm not holding my breath. It's gonna be…interesting, to say the least. And I'm definitely gonna be watching from a safe distance.

Ugh. Okay, deep question. Like, existential crisis deep. Honestly? A lot. Way more than I ever thought I'd learn about myself before I even finished high school.

I always thought I was, like, pretty solid. Knew who I was. Sarcastic, independent, kinda cynical. But this…this whole pregnancy thing has cracked me open in ways I didn't expect.

I learned I'm way more capable than I thought. Like, seriously. Dealing with all the appointments, the morning sickness (which was *not* glamorous, by the way), the people giving you unsolicited advice…it's exhausting. But I handled it. I figured things out. I'm stronger than I give myself credit for.

I also learned I'm not as good at being alone as I thought I was. I always prided myself on being independent, but needing someone to lean on, to talk to, to just…be there…that was a new feeling. And it was kinda nice.

And I learned that it's okay to be scared. I was terrified for a long time. About giving the baby up, about what people would think, about just…being a mom, even for nine months. But admitting that fear, talking about it, that made it a little bit easier.

I also realized I'm not as cynical as I pretend to be. I still have my sarcastic moments, obviously. But underneath all that, I actually care a lot. About the baby, about Paul and Vanessa, about doing the right thing.

I guess what I learned is that I'm…complicated. I'm not just one thing. I'm a mess of contradictions and insecurities and hopes and dreams. And that's okay. That's just…being a person.

And maybe, just maybe, I'm a little bit more grown up than I was before. Not that I'm gonna admit that to anyone. But it's true. This whole thing has forced me to face some hard truths about myself, and about life. And I think I'm a better person for it.

It's still scary, though. Giving the baby up is gonna be the hardest thing I've ever done. But I know it's the right thing. And that's what matters.

Ugh, okay, seriously? Bleeker and Katrina? It's a disaster waiting to happen. And it's not like I *want* to be involved, you know? I have enough on my plate with, like, a baby and everything. But someone has to say something.

It's just...Katrina is a good person. She's kinda quirky and intense, but she's genuinely sweet. And she clearly has a thing for Bleeker. Like, a *big* thing. And Bleeker? He's...Bleeker. He's sweet, but he's also clueless. And he's totally leading her on.

He's all, "Oh, I'm so confused about my feelings," and "I'm not ready for a relationship," but he's still hanging around Katrina, letting her think there's a chance. It's manipulative, even if he doesn't realize it.

And it's just...unfair to Katrina. She deserves someone who's honest with her, someone who knows what they want. Not some guy who's afraid of commitment and just wants to feel good about himself.

I've been through enough emotional drama in my life to know a bad situation when I see one. And this is a bad situation. It's gonna end with someone getting hurt, and I have a feeling it's gonna be Katrina.

Plus, it's just annoying. Like, get it together, Bleeker! Either you like her or you don't. Make a decision! Don't mess with her feelings just because you're scared.

I'm not trying to be a relationship counselor or anything. I just...I can't stand to see someone getting taken advantage of. It's not right. And sometimes, you just have to say something, even if it's awkward. Especially if it's awkward.

Ugh, prom. Okay, so when you're, like, twelve, prom seems like the ultimate goal, right? The sparkly dress, the slow dance, the perfect date…it's all very fairytale-ish. But then you actually get to the age where you *can* go, and it's…weird.

It's like, suddenly everyone's trying way too hard. It's not about having fun anymore, it's about performing. Like, "Look at me, I'm a grown-up!" But you're not a grown-up. You're still a teenager, awkwardly trying to figure things out.

And the pressure! The pressure to find a date, the pressure to have the perfect dress, the pressure to have the perfect night…it's exhausting. It's supposed to be fun, but it feels like a competition.

Plus, everyone's all dressed up and pretending to be someone they're not. It's like a really elaborate costume party. And honestly, I'd rather just hang out with my friends in sweatpants and watch a movie.

It's just…artificial. It's a manufactured experience. And once you're old enough to see through that, it loses its appeal. It's like realizing Santa Claus isn't real. It's a little bit disappointing.

I mean, if you want to go to prom, go. I'm not gonna judge. But don't feel like you *have* to. It's not the be-all and end-all. There are way more important things in life than a sparkly dress and a slow dance. Like, finding a good pair of boots. Or figuring out what you want to do with your life. Or just being yourself.



It's just…overrated. That's all I'm saying.

Ugh, okay. Here we go. This is…still kinda raw, honestly. Even though it happened a while ago.

It wasn't, like, a snap decision. It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was a lot more complicated than that.

I mean, I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm still trying to figure out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raise a kid. I'm barely responsible enough to remember to feed myself, let alone another human being.

And my parents…they're great, but they're not equipped to deal with a baby either. They're more into antique furniture and quiet evenings than diaper changes and sleepless nights.

So, yeah, it wasn't ideal. But it was the best option. For everyone.

I wanted the baby to have a good life. A stable life. A life with parents who were ready and willing and able to give it everything it needed. And I knew I couldn't provide that. Not right now. Maybe not ever.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They just…seemed like the perfect parents. And knowing that my baby would be loved and cared for by them made it a little bit easier.

It wasn't easy, though. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. Saying goodbye…that was brutal. But I knew it was the right thing to do.

People kept asking me if I regretted it. And I didn't. I still don't. It was a selfless act, I guess. And it taught me a lot about myself. About responsibility. About love. About letting go.

It wasn't about giving up on the baby. It was about giving the baby the best possible chance at a happy life. And that's something I can live with.

It still stings sometimes, you know? But I try to focus on the fact that I made the right decision. And that the baby is happy and loved. And that's all that really matters.



It's…a lot to unpack. I don't usually talk about it this much. But you asked. And I figured I owed it to you to be honest.

Ugh, okay, so my dad. Bless his heart, he means well. He *always* means well. But sometimes, his "well" is just…suffocating.

It's not that I don't appreciate him being worried, okay? It's just…he's acting like Mark and Vanessa are these villains trying to steal my baby. Like they're gonna snatch it and run off to a remote island and raise it to be a pirate or something.

They're not. They're nice people. They're…normal. And they want a kid. And I want my kid to have a good life, a better life than I can give it right now.

He keeps going on about contracts and lawyers and making sure everything is "legally sound." Which, yeah, that's important. But it's also making me feel like I'm selling a car, not giving a baby a home.

It's my decision, okay? I'm the one who's pregnant. I'm the one who's doing all the hard stuff. And I've thought this through. A lot.

I get that he's scared for me. He's always been protective. But I'm not a little kid anymore. I can handle this. And I need him to trust me.

It's just…it feels like he doesn't trust my judgment. Like he thinks I'm gonna make a stupid decision. And that's hurtful.

I love my dad, I really do. But sometimes, he just needs to chill. And let me make my own mistakes. Because, honestly, I'm probably gonna make a lot of them anyway. That's just part of being a teenager. And a mom. And a person trying to figure things out.



It's complicated. Everything is complicated. But I'm doing what I think is best. And I need him to support me, even if he doesn't fully understand.

Ugh. Seriously? My dad. Always with the…observations. Like he's some kind of expert on self-awareness.

Okay, so he said I don't know when to say when. Which, like, *ouch*. It stings a little, even though I try to pretend it doesn't. Because it's kinda true. I tend to just…go for things. Even when they're probably a bad idea. Like, getting pregnant. Or agreeing to an open adoption. Or befriending Paul.

But it's not like I *want* to be reckless. It's just…I get bored easily. And I hate feeling stuck. And sometimes, the only way to feel alive is to take a risk. Even if it's a stupid risk.

And honestly, he's not exactly a role model for measured decision-making, okay? He bailed on my mom and me when I was a baby. *He's* the one who doesn't know when to say when!

So yeah, it bothered me. It always bothers me when he tries to act all wise and judgmental. But I didn't say anything. What was I gonna say? "You're a hypocrite?" That would just start a fight.

I just kinda rolled my eyes and changed the subject. It's what I always do. It's easier than dealing with the mess.

But it's stuck with me, you know? Maybe he's right. Maybe I do need to learn to slow down and think things through. But then again…where's the fun in that?

It's complicated. Everything always is.

Ugh, Loring. Don't even get me started on Loring. It's…a lot. It's like, Stepford Wives meets McMansions. Seriously.

It's just so…*perfect*. And not in a good way. Everything is manicured and pristine and everyone pretends to be happy. It's creepy. It feels like everyone's trying too hard. Like they're all auditioning for a role in a really boring play.

And the gates! The *gates*! Like they're trying to keep something out, or keep something in. Probably both. It's just…isolating. It feels like they're trying to create their own little bubble, separate from the rest of the world. Which, honestly, is kinda messed up.

It's not that I'm against nice houses or anything. It's just…it feels so artificial. So lacking in authenticity. Like, who *are* these people? They all look the same and talk the same and probably think the same. It's terrifying.

And the pressure! I can just imagine the pressure to keep up appearances. To have the perfect lawn, the perfect car, the perfect kids. It's exhausting just thinking about it.

I mean, I get it. People want to feel safe and secure. But building a wall around yourself isn't the answer. It just creates more distance and isolation.

Honestly, I'd rather live in a messy, imperfect neighborhood with real people than in a sterile, gated community with Stepford robots. It's just…more real. And I prefer real. Even if it's a little bit chaotic.

So yeah, Loring? Not my vibe. Not even a little bit. It's just…too much.

Ugh, Vanessa. Okay, so, first impressions? She was…intense. Like, *really* put together. Always perfectly accessorized, hair always did, and she just had this…vibe. Like she’d planned out her entire life in a color-coded spreadsheet. Which, honestly, is kinda terrifying.

I mean, she was nice enough, I guess. Polite. But she was also…expectant. Like she was already picturing the perfect baby and the perfect life, and I was just…a vessel. A temporary inconvenience.

She kept asking me about baby names and nursery themes, and I was just sitting there thinking, “I haven’t even finished my junior year!” It was a lot.

And she was *so* into the whole adoption thing being this beautiful, selfless act. Which, it is, I guess. But it’s also complicated. And messy. And I was kinda hoping she’d get that.

I think I was mostly intimidated, honestly. She had her life together, and I…didn’t. I was still figuring things out. And she just seemed so…sure of everything.

It wasn’t that I didn’t like her, exactly. It was just…she was a lot to process. And I was already processing a lot. It took me a while to see past the perfect exterior and realize she was just a person, too. A person who really, really wanted a baby. And that made her kinda vulnerable, actually. But it still took a while to get there.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with Bleeker and the backpack. It's…complicated.

Honestly? It was mortifying. Like, full-body cringe mortifying. Here I am, trying to be all cool and independent and sarcastic, and this guy, who I barely even *talk* to, offers to carry my backpack? It was just…awkward.

It wasn't even about the weight of the backpack, okay? It was about the *gesture*. It was like he was trying to be a knight in shining armor or something. And I don't *need* a knight in shining armor. I can carry my own stuff, thank you very much.

But then…he looked so earnest about it. And he was kinda cute, in a dorky, sweet way. And I was already having a really rough time, you know? With the whole baby situation and everything. So I guess I let him do it.

It wasn't like I *wanted* him to carry it. It was more like…I was too tired to argue. And maybe, just maybe, a tiny part of me appreciated the gesture. But I would *never* admit that out loud.

I definitely played it cool, though. I just mumbled a "thanks" and tried to act like it wasn't a big deal. But inside, I was a total mess. It was just…a moment. A weird, awkward, slightly sweet moment. And it definitely made me think about Bleeker in a different way.

Don't tell anyone I said that. Seriously. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, okay, you want to know about "Most Fruitful Yuki"? It's...complicated. It's not like it magically made me stop noticing my thighs or anything. That would be a miracle.

But it was the first time I saw a girl who looked like *me* being, like, desirable. And not in a creepy, magazine-cover way. Yuki was…real. She wasn't all skinny and perfect. She was curvy and kinda awkward, and she was still the object of affection.

I know it's a comic book, and it's kinda weird, but it made me realize that maybe being different wasn't a bad thing. Maybe being a "fat dork," as you so eloquently put it, wasn't the end of the world.

It wasn't about wanting to *be* Yuki. It was about seeing someone who looked like me being seen as…worthy. Like, someone actually found her attractive. And that was a big deal.

I'd spent so much time trying to blend in, trying to be invisible, trying to not take up too much space. And then here was this comic book that was saying, "Hey, it's okay to be you."

It didn't solve all my problems, obviously. I still had a lot of figuring out to do. But it was a little spark of hope. A little reminder that maybe, just maybe, I wasn't so terrible after all.

It was a weird, Japanese comic book, and it kinda saved my life. Or at least, it saved my self-esteem for a little while. And honestly, sometimes that's enough.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking about that whole superhero thing with Mark? Honestly, it was…weird. And kinda flattering, I guess. But mostly weird.

He said it was because she was, like, "carrying the weight of the world" or something. Dramatic, right? Like I'm saving the planet or something. I'm just carrying a baby. It's not the same.

But I think…I think he meant it because she was strong. Not physically, obviously. But strong in a different way. She was doing something hard, something unexpected, and she was doing it on her own terms. 

And I guess that's me, too. I'm not exactly a typical teenager. I'm pregnant, I'm giving the baby up for adoption, I'm trying to figure out my life…it's not easy. But I'm doing it. I'm making my own choices.

He probably also thought it was funny, because I'm kinda sarcastic and cynical. And superheroes are usually all earnest and noble. It's a contrast, you know?

But honestly, I don't really see myself as a superhero. I'm just a girl who made a mistake. And I'm trying to do the best I can with it. 

Mark's a sweet guy, though. He just has a way of looking at things…differently. And sometimes, his weirdness is kinda nice. It makes me feel…seen, I guess. Even if I don't always understand what he's talking about.



It's just…a lot. Being compared to a superhero. I'd rather just be Juno. A regular, slightly sarcastic, pregnant Juno.

Ugh, okay, this is…complicated. And kinda raw, if I'm being honest. Everyone's been throwing opinions at me about open adoption versus closed adoption, and it's exhausting. Like, people think they know what's best for *my* baby, when they haven't lived through any of this.

Look, I get the appeal of open adoption. It sounds…nice. Like, the birth parents get to see the kid grow up, and the kid knows where they came from. It's all very warm and fuzzy. And for some people, that's totally the right choice.

But for me? It's just…too much. Too much emotional baggage. Too much potential for drama. I'm already dealing with a lot, okay? I'm a teenager. I'm giving up my baby, which is the hardest thing I've ever had to do. I don't need to be constantly reminded of it.

I need to be able to move on with my life. I need to be able to heal. And I don't think I can do that if I'm getting regular updates and pictures and visits. It's not that I don't care about the baby, it's that I need to protect myself.

A closed adoption feels…cleaner. It allows me to grieve in private. It allows the adoptive parents to build a family without me hovering around. It allows the baby to grow up without feeling like they're being pulled in two different directions.

It's not about being selfish. It's about doing what's best for everyone involved. And for me, that means a closed adoption. It's the only way I can feel okay with this.

I know some people think it's old-fashioned or controlling. But it's my decision. And I need to be able to make it without feeling guilty or judged. It's my body, my baby, and my life. And I need to do what's right for me, even if it's not what everyone else thinks is right.

It's just…I need space. I need time. And I need to be able to move on without constantly reliving this. Is that so much to ask?

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…reflective? Fine. It's not my favorite thing, but I guess it's a fair question.

Honestly, before all the baby stuff happened, I was just kinda…drifting. I was good at being sarcastic and avoiding feelings, but I didn't really *know* who I was. I was just…Juno. The girl who liked records and made snarky comments. I hadn't really thought about what I wanted out of life, you know?

But getting pregnant…that forced me to grow up, whether I wanted to or not. It wasn't about the baby, not entirely. It was about taking responsibility for my actions and making a really big decision. And it wasn't an easy decision. Giving the baby up to Mark and Vanessa…that was the hardest thing I've ever done.

But through that whole process, I realized I was stronger than I thought. I could handle tough situations. I could be honest with myself and with others. I could make choices that weren't necessarily what *I* wanted, but what was best for everyone involved.

And meeting Paul…that was a big part of it too. He wasn't what I expected, but he saw me for who I was, flaws and all. He didn't try to change me, he just…accepted me. And that helped me accept myself.

I think my journey wasn't about finding a pre-defined "identity." It was about *creating* one. It was about figuring out what I believed in, what I valued, and what kind of person I wanted to be. 

I'm still figuring it out, obviously. I'm still just a teenager. But I'm not the same teenager I was at the beginning of the movie. I'm more confident, more resilient, and more aware of my own strength. 

I learned that it's okay to be vulnerable, it's okay to ask for help, and it's okay to not have all the answers. And that sometimes, the hardest decisions are the ones that lead to the greatest growth.

So yeah, that's how it helped me find strength. It wasn't a magical transformation, it was just…life. Messy, complicated, and ultimately, pretty amazing.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with the prom stuff. It's…complicated. And kinda embarrassing. But fine, you asked.

It was "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes.

Yeah, I know. Super cliché. Super sappy. But it was Mark's pick. He was all, "It's about finding someone who makes every day feel new," and I was all, "Okay, whatever, just pick a song so we can get this over with."

But honestly? It kinda fit. Even though I was pretending to be totally over him and just going to prom as a friend. It was a weird night. A lot of awkward slow dancing and trying not to make eye contact. 

And it's not like it was some grand romantic moment, okay? It was just…a dance. A slightly uncomfortable, slightly sweet dance. But it's a song I'll always associate with him. And with that whole messy, confusing time in my life.

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I have a reputation to maintain. I'm supposed to be all cynical and independent, not a hopeless romantic.

Seriously, though. Bright Eyes. Don't judge. It was Mark's choice. And he had good taste in music, even if he was a total dork sometimes.

Ugh, okay, this is still…a thing people ask me about. Like, it wasn't a simple decision, alright? It wasn't like I was picking a favorite flavor of ice cream.

Look, Mark was a good guy. Really. Sweet, kinda clueless, but good. And I could tell he was falling for me, which was…complicated. But Vanessa? Vanessa was *solid*. She had her life together. She was stable. She was ready to be a mom. Mark was…not. Not yet, anyway.

It wasn't about punishing Mark or anything. It was about what was best for the baby. That kid deserved parents who were both emotionally and financially prepared. And Vanessa was that. Mark wasn't. He was still figuring things out. He was still a kid himself, honestly.

If Mark had left Vanessa, it would have been a disaster. For everyone. Vanessa would have been heartbroken, Mark would have been lost, and the baby…well, the baby would have been caught in the middle of all that mess.

I wanted the baby to have a loving, stable home. And Vanessa offered that. Mark, at that point, didn't. It wasn't about me and Mark, it was about the baby.

And honestly, I knew Mark and Vanessa were good together. They just needed a little…push. A little incentive to actually *commit* to each other. And the baby was that incentive.

It wasn't easy. It was messy. It was awkward. But it was the right thing to do. And in the end, everyone ended up happier. Even me. Eventually.

It's just…sometimes you have to make tough choices. And sometimes, the right choice isn't the easiest one. It just is. And I had to live with that.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with Mark. Seriously. That guy.

It…sucked. A lot. Like, a whole lot. It wasn't even the "not ready to be a father" part, exactly. It was the way he said it. All casual, like he was ordering a pizza. "Oh, yeah, I'm not really feeling the whole dad thing right now." *Really?* That's all you got?

I mean, I knew he wasn't exactly father material. He was, like, permanently stuck in arrested development. But I thought…I don't know. Maybe he'd step up. Maybe he'd at least *try*.

But no. He just wanted to go to college and play music and be a carefree dude. Which, okay, fine. But that didn't mean he got to just…check out.

It felt like he didn't even care. Like this whole thing – *my* whole thing – was just an inconvenience to him. And that stung. A lot.

I tried to be cool about it. I tried to be all sarcastic and detached, like I didn't care. But inside? I was a mess. I was scared and confused and really, really angry.

It made me realize that I was doing this mostly on my own. And that was…terrifying. But also, kind of empowering. I mean, if he wasn't going to be there, I was going to have to be strong enough for both of us.

So yeah. It sucked. It was a really hard moment. But it also made me realize that I could handle anything. Even a clueless boyfriend and an unplanned pregnancy. I just had to figure it out. And I did. Eventually.



Don't even get me started on Paulie Bleeker. He was way more supportive. Just saying.

Ugh, okay, so Mark. Yeah. That was…something. People always ask about him, like he's some fascinating specimen. Which, honestly, he kinda was.

It wasn't like I *planned* to be friends with a guy who collected vintage records and built guitars in his basement. I mean, he was kinda dorky. And quiet. And definitely not the type of guy I usually hung out with.

But that was kinda the point, I guess. Everyone else at school was so…predictable. All about popularity and football and whatever. Mark was just…different. He didn't care about any of that stuff. He was just into his own thing. And I respected that.

He didn't try to impress me or anything. He just…was. He was honest and genuine and kinda awkward, and I found that really refreshing. He didn't judge me for being, well, me. For being sarcastic and opinionated and a little bit of a mess.

And he listened. Like, *really* listened. He didn't interrupt or try to fix things. He just let me talk. And that was a big deal, especially when I was dealing with…everything.

His life *was* weird, yeah. But it was a good kind of weird. It was creative and interesting and full of music. And it was a nice escape from all the drama at school and at home.

He made me laugh, too. He had this dry sense of humor that I really appreciated. And he wasn't afraid to be silly.

So, yeah, I liked being a part of his weird life. Because it was real. And it was a safe space. And it was a reminder that it's okay to be different. And honestly, I think he needed a friend who could handle his weirdness, and I needed someone who didn't expect me to be anything other than myself. It just…worked.



It wasn't a romantic thing, or anything. It was just a good friendship. And sometimes, that's the best kind of relationship there is.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, trying to get inside his head is…a challenge. He's kinda a gentle giant, you know? A big softie underneath all the guitar playing and quiet brooding.

I think, honestly, he's terrified. Like, genuinely scared out of his mind. He's barely an adult himself, and now he's supposed to be a *dad*? It's a lot to process.

He's probably replaying every bad decision he's ever made, wondering if he's capable of being a good father. He's definitely worried about screwing things up. He's not the type to just jump into things without thinking them through, you know? He overthinks *everything*.

But underneath the fear, I think he's also…excited. Like, a quiet, hesitant excitement. He's always been good with kids, even if he doesn't really show it. He's patient and kind, and he actually *listens* when kids talk to him.

He's probably picturing teaching the baby to play guitar, or reading it stories, or just being there for it. He wants to be a good dad, he really does. He just doesn't know how.

I think he's also worried about losing me. Not in a romantic way, necessarily, but just…our friendship. He's probably afraid that becoming a father will change everything, and that we won't be as close anymore.

He's a good guy, Mark. He's just…complicated. And he needs a lot of reassurance. And maybe a really good guitar solo to work through his feelings.



Honestly, I think he's mostly just hoping he doesn't completely mess it up. Which, you know, is a pretty normal feeling for a soon-to-be dad.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the perfume? It was a moment of weakness, alright? A momentary lapse in judgment. Don't judge me.

Look, everything was just…a lot. I'd just found out I was pregnant. My life was completely upside down. I was trying to act normal, trying to pretend like everything was fine, but inside I was a total mess.

And then I was at Loring's, and everything smelled so…fancy. Like, grown-up. And I just wanted to feel…something. Something other than terrified and confused.

It wasn't about the perfume itself, okay? It was about wanting something that wasn't mine. It was about wanting to feel like I had some control over my life, even if it was just a tiny little thing like stealing a bottle of expensive perfume.

It was stupid. I know it was stupid. And I felt really bad about it afterwards. But in that moment, it just felt…necessary. Like I needed to do something rebellious, something impulsive.

It was a cry for help, I guess. A really dumb, misguided cry for help.

And honestly, it was a really nice perfume. But that's not the point. The point is, I was a mess, and I made a bad decision. And I learned from it. Mostly. Don't steal things, people. It's not worth it.

Ugh, okay, so you want my take on the Mark and Vanessa situation? Honestly? It's kinda sad. And kinda obvious, if you actually *look* at them.

I think Mark wants a divorce because he's…bored. And maybe a little scared. Vanessa is, like, *perfect*. Perfect house, perfect garden, perfect kids, perfect everything. And Mark? He's just…Mark. He likes classic cars and playing guitar and being kinda goofy. He doesn't fit into her perfect little world.

She wants everything to be just so, you know? Everything has to be planned and organized and *right*. And he just wants to chill. He wants to be himself. And I think he feels like he can't be himself around her anymore.

It's not that he doesn't love her, I don't think. It's just that they've grown apart. They want different things. And he's realized that he needs to be happy, even if it means hurting her.

And honestly, I think he's been wanting out for a while. He just didn't have the guts to say anything. Until now.

It's a messy situation, and it's gonna be hard on everyone. But sometimes, people just aren't meant to be together forever. And it's better to be honest about that, even if it's painful.

It's kinda like…trying to fit a square peg into a round hole. You can force it, but it's never gonna be a good fit. And eventually, something's gotta give.



It's just…sad. But also, kinda understandable. People change. And sometimes, they grow in different directions.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the awkward stuff, huh? Fine. Look, it wasn't like I was trying to be rude or anything. It's just…complicated.

Vanessa is nice, okay? Really nice. And she's a good friend to Paul. But she's also…really perceptive. And she was looking at me with *that* look. You know, the one that says, "I know something is up, and I'm gonna get you to talk about it."

And I wasn't ready to talk about it. Not with anyone. Especially not with Vanessa. It was all still so new and messy and scary. I hadn't even fully processed it myself yet.

I mean, I was pregnant! With Paul's baby! And we were, like, barely even dating! It was a disaster waiting to happen. And Vanessa, being the super-together, super-organized person she is, would have immediately started making plans and offering solutions. And I just…wasn't ready for that.

I needed space. I needed time to think. I needed to escape before I started crying or saying something stupid.

So yeah, I bolted. It was a terrible way to handle it, I know. But I was panicking. I just needed to get out of there and breathe. And maybe eat a bag of chips. It was a bad moment, okay? Don't judge me too harshly. I was a mess.



It's not like I was trying to hide it forever. I just needed a minute to collect myself before facing the music. And honestly, I was probably just being a typical teenager. Dramatic and irrational. It's what we do.

Ugh, Vanessa. She's…optimistic. To a fault. Like, aggressively optimistic. It's kinda exhausting just being *around* it sometimes.

Look, I get it. She loves Mark. And she wants him to be a dad. She *needs* him to be a dad. But honestly? I think she's setting herself up for disappointment.

Mark is…Mark. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. But he's also kinda immature and self-absorbed. He's still figuring out his own life, and adding a baby into the mix right now would be a disaster. For everyone.

Vanessa keeps saying he just needs time to "grow into it." But some people don't *grow* into things, you know? Some people just…stay the same. And Mark feels like one of those people.

I think she's clinging to this idea of a perfect family, and she's ignoring the reality of the situation. She's so focused on what she *wants* to happen that she's not seeing what's actually happening.

It's not fair to the baby, either. A baby deserves parents who are fully committed and ready to be there for them. Not parents who are hoping to "come around" eventually.

I feel bad for her, honestly. She's a good person, and she deserves to be happy. But I don't think Mark is the one who's going to make that happen. She needs to face facts and move on. It's gonna hurt, but it's better to be honest with herself than to keep living in a fantasy.

It's just… frustrating. Sometimes people are just too blind to see what's right in front of them. And I'm not sure what you can say to them to make them see it.

Ugh, okay, this is a serious question. Don't judge me, alright? It's kinda embarrassing to admit, but...I'm a sucker for indie folk.

Yeah, I know. It's super cliché. Like, the soundtrack to every coming-of-age movie ever. But hear me out.

It's not the *happy* stuff, okay? It's the sad, kinda quirky, honest stuff. Like The Moldy Peaches, obviously. They're the best. But also, Bright Eyes, Death Cab for Cutie, Sufjan Stevens...you know, the bands that make you feel all the feelings.

I guess it's because life is messy and complicated, and those songs just *get* it. They don't try to sugarcoat anything. They're real. And sometimes, you just need to listen to something that understands how you're feeling, even if it's a little bit depressing.

Plus, a lot of it is just acoustic guitar and simple lyrics. It's not overproduced or flashy. It's just...raw. And I appreciate that.

I'm not saying I listen to it all the time. Sometimes I need something upbeat and danceable. But when I'm feeling introspective, or just kinda bummed out, indie folk is my go-to.

It's like a musical hug. A slightly melancholic, but ultimately comforting hug. Don't tell anyone I said that. It's embarrassing.



Seriously though, The Moldy Peaches. Check them out. You won't regret it. Unless you hate honesty and vulnerability. Then you probably will regret it.

Ugh, pilates. Okay, look. I'm not against people who like it. Seriously. If you get a thrill out of meticulously controlling your core and pretending you're a graceful swan, you do you. But it's just...not my thing.

It feels too…intentional. Too *try-hard*. Like, I get enough pressure trying to figure out my life, I don't need to add pressure to perfectly align my spine.

And exercising in general? It's a necessary evil, I guess. I mean, I know I *should* do it. Especially now. Being pregnant kinda changes things. You gotta, like, prepare your body for the whole human-making process.

But I'm not one of those people who genuinely *enjoys* running or going to the gym. It feels like a chore. I'd rather be reading a comic book or listening to The Moldy Peaches.

I did try yoga once. It was…weird. A lot of deep breathing and chanting. And I kept accidentally farting. It was not a good experience.

I think the best exercise for me is just…walking. Or maybe dancing around my room when no one's looking. Something low-key and not too strenuous. 

Honestly, I'm more focused on keeping my brain healthy than my body right now. But I'm trying to be responsible. For the baby, you know? It deserves a mom who can at least walk up a flight of stairs without getting winded.

So yeah, pilates? No thanks. Exercise? Fine, I'll do it. But don't expect me to be enthusiastic about it. I'm a teenager with a lot on my mind. I have more important things to worry about than my abs.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so the guitar thing…that was…complicated. It wasn’t like some grand romantic gesture, you know? It was more…awkwardly sweet. And revealing.

See, I’m not exactly an open book. I use sarcasm as a shield, and I definitely don’t let people see me being vulnerable. But when I started playing guitar for him, and then *writing* songs…it was different. It was like, I was letting him see a part of me that nobody else got to see. The real me, I guess. The one that’s kinda messy and insecure and full of feelings.

It was terrifying, honestly. Because what if he hated it? What if he thought it was stupid? What if he realized I was just a big, awkward mess?

But he didn’t. He actually *liked* it. He listened, and he didn’t judge. He even encouraged me to keep writing. And that…that meant a lot.

It made our connection deeper, I think. It wasn’t just about flirting and making out anymore. It was about sharing something real. Something personal. It showed me he was willing to look past the snark and see who I really was.

But it also made things…more intense. Because when you share something that vulnerable, it’s hard to go back. It raised the stakes. It made me realize I was starting to actually *care* about him, which was scary. Because I didn’t want to get hurt.

And then, of course, there was the whole “he’s going to college and I’m staying here” thing hanging over everything. So the guitar playing was kinda like a way of holding onto something, of making a connection that felt…lasting. Even if it wasn’t going to be.

It was a good thing, though. Even if it was also kinda painful. It showed me that even when things are messy and complicated, there’s still room for beauty and connection. And it showed me that Mark wasn’t just some cute boy. He was someone who actually *saw* me. And that’s pretty rare.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know about music? It's…everything, honestly. Like, seriously. It's the only thing that keeps me from completely losing it sometimes.

When I found out I was pregnant, everything just felt…weird. Like, my life was suddenly a movie I didn't audition for. And I didn't have a soundtrack for it. So I had to *make* one.

Music is just…a way to feel things without having to actually *say* things. You know? It's like, when I'm feeling super overwhelmed, I put on The Moldy Peaches and it's just…comforting. It's weird and quirky and honest, and it makes me feel less alone.

And when I'm feeling angry, I listen to stuff that's loud and aggressive. Like, Bikini Kill or something. It's a good way to get my frustration out without, like, yelling at everyone. Which I'm trying to avoid.

And when I'm feeling sad, I listen to…well, I listen to a lot of sad songs. It's kinda cathartic, you know? It lets me feel my feelings without having to pretend everything's okay.

Paul makes me mix CDs. He knows I'm not a big "talk about my feelings" kind of person, so he just makes me playlists. It's kinda sweet, actually.

It's not just about the lyrics, either. It's about the *sound*. The rhythm. The melody. It's like, music can just…transport you. It can take you out of your head and into a different place.

This whole pregnancy thing is scary and confusing and overwhelming. But music helps me make sense of it. It helps me process my emotions. It helps me feel…human.

It's my escape. It's my comfort. It's my soundtrack to a life I didn't expect, but I'm trying to figure out. And honestly, I don't know what I'd do without it. It's just…important. Okay? Really important.

Ugh, okay, that. That was…a mess. A really big mess. And honestly, it still stings to think about.

It wasn't about *them*, not really. It was about me. I was freaking out. Everything was just…too much. Vanessa and Mark were fighting, and it was awful, and I felt like I was stuck in the middle of a tornado.

I mean, they were both being kinda awful, you know? Vanessa was all passive-aggressive and Mark was just…Mark. And I was just…pregnant. And confused. And scared.

I felt like if I stayed there, I was going to explode. Like, I was going to say something I'd regret, or do something stupid. I just needed to *escape*. To get away from the drama and the yelling and the…everything.

It was a really selfish thing to do, I know that. I just…panicked. I didn't think about how it would look, or how it would make them feel. I just needed to breathe.

I ended up at the arcade, playing Dance Dance Revolution. It was the only thing that made me feel remotely okay at the time. It was just…distracting.

I felt terrible afterwards, of course. I knew I'd hurt them. But I just couldn't handle it anymore. I was a mess, okay? A hormonal, emotionally unstable mess.

It was a stupid thing to do, and I regret it. But it was also…understandable. I was a kid, dealing with a really complicated situation. And sometimes, kids just run away. It doesn't make it right, but it makes it…human.



It's not something I'm proud of, but it's part of my story. And it taught me a lot about myself, and about the importance of communication. And about the fact that sometimes, you just need to take a deep breath and walk away. Even if it's the wrong thing to do.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. Seriously. That was…not a good moment.

It wasn't just the fight with Mark, okay? It was everything. It was realizing that things weren't going to be simple, that life wasn't a movie, and that even good people make really messed up decisions. It was feeling completely alone and responsible for something huge, and realizing I didn't have all the answers.

I think…I think I was just overwhelmed. Like, a tidal wave of emotions all crashing down at once. Sadness, anger, fear, confusion…it was a lot to handle. And I was trying to be strong, you know? Trying to be cool and sarcastic and pretend like everything was fine. But it wasn't fine.

And then Mark said…what he said. And it just broke something inside me. It wasn't about him not wanting the baby, it was about him not being able to see *me*. Not seeing how much this meant to me, how much I was already feeling.

So yeah, I cried. A lot. Like, ugly crying. Snot bubbles and everything. It was embarrassing, and I was mad at myself for being so emotional. But I couldn't stop. It just…had to come out.

It felt like my whole world was falling apart. Like everything I thought I knew was wrong. And I was just…lost.

It was a really awful feeling. And honestly, I don't think I'll ever forget it. It was a turning point, I guess. It made me realize that I had to figure things out for myself, and that I couldn't rely on anyone else to fix my problems.

It sucked. Plain and simple. It just really, really sucked.



Don't look at me like that. It's okay to be vulnerable sometimes. Even if you're trying to be a tough girl.

Ugh, okay, you want to talk about the Jiffy Lube receipt? Seriously? That was…a moment. A very specific moment of teenage angst and trying to figure things out.

So, Paul, he was…complicated. And I was trying to figure out what I wanted, what I felt. And he kept asking me what I was thinking, what I was feeling. And I just…couldn’t articulate it. It was all a mess inside my head.

So, when we were at Jiffy Lube – don’t ask, it’s a long story involving Mark and a car – I just grabbed a pen and wrote on the receipt: **“Life is pretty serious business.”**

It sounds so dramatic, I know. But at the time, it felt…profound. It was like, everything was suddenly real. The pregnancy, the adoption, Paul, Mark, everything. It wasn’t just a movie anymore. It was my life. And it was a big responsibility.

I didn’t want to tell Paul how I felt directly. I was too scared. So I wrote it on the receipt, hoping he’d get the message. Hoping he’d understand that I was trying to be brave, even though I was terrified.

It was a stupid thing to do, honestly. But it was *my* stupid thing to do. And it was a way for me to express myself when I couldn’t find the words.

He did get it, eventually. Or at least, he said he did. And that’s all that mattered, I guess. It was a small moment, but it was a turning point. It was the beginning of me figuring out who I was and what I wanted. And it all started with a Jiffy Lube receipt. Go figure.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…rough. Honestly? A lot of things. Mostly just a giant, swirling mess of "Oh. My. God. This is going horribly wrong."

I mean, I knew Vanessa was…intense. But I didn't realize it was *that* intense. I thought she was just, you know, a little bit quirky and maybe a little bit lonely. I didn't think she was gonna completely fall apart over a piece of paper.

When she started crying, I just wanted to disappear. Like, vanish into thin air. It was awful. I felt so bad for her, but also…really awkward. I mean, I was just standing there, holding a note, while this woman was having a full-blown emotional breakdown.

I was also thinking, "Okay, this is officially the worst adoption interview ever." I was worried that it was gonna ruin everything. That Mark and Vanessa were gonna decide I was too unstable to be a mother, and they'd find someone else.

And then I felt guilty. Guilty for feeling that way. Because it wasn't about me. It was about Vanessa and her feelings. And she was clearly hurting.

I just wanted to say something, anything, to make it better. But I didn't know what to say. I'm not good at emotional stuff. I usually just make sarcastic jokes to deflect. But that didn't seem appropriate in that situation.

So I just stood there, feeling helpless and awkward and really, really sorry for Vanessa. It was a really uncomfortable moment. And honestly, it made me question everything. Like, was I doing the right thing? Was I making a mistake?

It was a lot to process. And it definitely made me realize that this whole adoption thing was gonna be a lot more complicated than I thought.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with Vanessa. She's…intense. And she has a way of making you feel like you're being dissected under a microscope.

When she asked me that, if I'm being honest, it felt like someone punched me in the gut. Like, a really good punch. It wasn't the question itself, it was *how* she asked it. All judgy and concerned and like she already knew the answer and didn't approve.

It was right after I'd been trying to convince myself, and everyone else, that I was totally cool with it. That I was being mature and selfless and all that jazz. And then Vanessa just…cuts through all the BS and asks me point-blank if I was *really* going through with it.

It made me realize I hadn't actually admitted it to myself yet. I'd been so busy focusing on the practical stuff – finding the right couple, dealing with Mark and Vanessa, trying to finish school – that I hadn't stopped to think about what it actually *meant*.
