I think I just kinda mumbled something about it being the right thing to do. Which it was, I knew that. But it didn't feel like enough. It felt…empty.

It was one of those moments where all the bravado just kinda melted away and I felt really small and scared and confused. Like, what was I doing? Was I making the right decision? Was I strong enough to go through with it?

I think that's why I snapped at her a little bit. It wasn't about her, it was about me. I was just trying to protect myself from feeling all those scary things.

It was a really hard moment. And it made me realize that even though I was trying to be strong, I was still just a kid. And I was still really, really scared.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *remind* me. That whole situation was…a mess. Vijay. Seriously. That guy.

It was awful. Just…awful. I mean, I was already a walking disaster, trying to figure out my life and this whole baby thing, and then *that* happens. It felt like someone just punched me in the gut.

I was so mad. Mad at Vijay for being a total jerk, mad at Bleeker for not saying anything, and mad at myself for just standing there, trying to look cool and collected when I was totally freaking out inside.

It wasn't just about Bleeker potentially being the dad, it was about the disrespect. Like, my body, my life, my decision…it was all just a joke to him. He didn't even care about how that would make me feel.

And Bleeker just…let him say it. He didn't defend me. He just stood there looking all awkward and mumbly. Which, you know, is Bleeker. But still. It was frustrating.

I think I just wanted to disappear. To crawl into a hole and never come out. It was a really vulnerable moment, and he just completely ruined it.

I ended up just walking away. I didn't have the energy to deal with it. I needed to protect myself, you know? And I needed to figure out what I wanted, without anyone else trying to tell me what to do.

It was a really crappy night. And it definitely made me question things. But it also made me realize that I needed to stand up for myself. And that I deserved better than that.



Honestly, just thinking about it makes me want to punch something. Vijay is the worst.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on Vijay and the mustache. Seriously. It was…a moment. A deeply weird moment.

Like, first of all, Vijay is a sweet guy, don't get me wrong. But he's also kinda clueless sometimes. And the whole "real man" thing? Please. As if growing facial hair suddenly unlocks some secret level of masculinity. It's ridiculous.

My initial reaction was mostly just…confusion. I think I blinked a lot. And then I probably said something sarcastic, like, "Oh, so now you're Clint Eastwood?" Or maybe, "Does the mustache come with a leather jacket and a brooding silence?" I can't remember exactly. I say a lot of sarcastic things. It's a reflex.

But underneath the sarcasm, I was actually kinda touched. He was trying, you know? He was trying to figure out how to be a good dad, and he was doing it in the only way he knew how – by trying to be…manly. It was misguided, but it was sweet.

I think I ended up telling him that being a "real man" isn't about facial hair or tough talk. It's about being responsible, and loving, and being there for your kid. And that he was already doing a pretty good job of that, mustache or no mustache.

Honestly, the whole thing was just…Vijay being Vijay. And I love him for it. Even when he's being completely ridiculous. It just made me realize how much he cared, and how much he was trying. And that's what really mattered.

Plus, the mustache was kinda patchy. Let's be real. It wasn't exactly intimidating. It was more…endearing. In a weird way.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the note. Seriously? That was…a whole thing.

It wasn't *for* Vanessa, exactly. It was for Paul. It was a list of things I needed him to do while I was at the hospital getting the ultrasound. You know, the really awkward ultrasound where we found out I was having a baby.

It was mostly practical stuff. Like, "Take out the trash," and "Don't eat all the peanut butter," and "Try not to freak out." But there was also a little bit of…emotional stuff. Like, "Remember I'm scared," and "Be nice to me."

I left it on the kitchen counter because I figured he'd see it. He's not exactly the most observant guy, so I had to make it pretty obvious.

Vanessa found it because she was snooping. Which, honestly, I didn't appreciate. But she was worried about me, and she was trying to understand what was going on. So I guess I can't blame her too much.

It was a really vulnerable moment, you know? I was scared and confused and overwhelmed, and I was trying to figure out how to deal with everything. And that note was a way for me to communicate my feelings to Paul, even when I couldn't actually talk about them.

It's just…a really personal thing. And I don't really like talking about it. It was a messy time.



Honestly, I wish Vanessa hadn't found it. It would have been nice to have that little bit of privacy. But, you know, life isn't always fair.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking about the whole staying-together thing? Yeah, that was…a lot. It wasn't like I was scared of commitment or anything. It was more…realistic.

See, my parents, they weren't exactly a shining example of marital bliss. My dad just…left. Vanished. And my mom, she was okay, but she was kinda lost without him. And I saw how hard it was for her, you know? How lonely.

So, I was worried about Paul and Vanessa. They seemed so…perfect. Like, a movie couple. And I was afraid that once the baby came, things would change. That they'd realize they weren't actually compatible, and they'd end up like my parents.

I didn't want the baby to grow up in a broken home. I didn't want it to feel unwanted or abandoned. I wanted it to have a stable, loving family.

And I was also worried about *them*. I didn't want them to make a mistake and stay together for the wrong reasons. I wanted them to be happy, not just…stuck.

It was a lot to think about, okay? I was just a teenager, trying to figure out my own life, and suddenly I was responsible for the future of a baby and the happiness of two adults. It was kinda overwhelming.

I guess I just wanted everyone to be okay. And I was afraid that staying together would actually make things worse. It's complicated. Life is complicated.

Ugh, okay, that's a…loaded question. It's not like I'm *searching* for people to love me, okay? I'm perfectly capable of being fiercely independent. But…yeah, there are a few people.

First, obviously, my dad, Mac. He's…a lot. He's obsessed with records and doesn't really understand feelings. But he always tries. And he always makes me breakfast. And he lets me decorate my room however I want, even if it's covered in band posters. He loves me, even when I'm being a total pain.

Then there's Leah. She's my best friend. She's the only one who really *gets* me. She doesn't judge me for anything. She just…listens. And she always knows how to make me laugh, even when I'm feeling completely overwhelmed. She's the real deal.

And then…there's Paul. Okay, don't get me wrong, it was complicated. And he's kinda dorky. But he actually *listened* to me. He didn't try to change me or tell me what to do. He just…accepted me. For all my weirdness and sarcasm and awkwardness. He loved me for exactly who I was, even when I didn't love myself.

So yeah, those are the people. My dad, Leah, and Paul. They're the ones who see me for who I really am, and they love me anyway. And honestly, that's all I really need.

It's not about having a ton of friends or being popular. It's about having a few people who truly care about you, and who will be there for you no matter what. And I'm lucky enough to have that. Even if I don't always admit it.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me about the ultrasound. It's not like I'm getting a puppy, you know? It's a *person*. A tiny person growing inside me. It's kinda weird to think about.

Anyway, after the ultrasound…the plan is still the same. I'm giving the baby up for adoption. I've thought about it a lot, and I know it's the right thing to do.

I've met Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are going to adopt him (or her!). They're really nice. They seem like they're going to be amazing parents. They want a baby so badly, and they can give it a life that I just…can't.

I'm not gonna lie, it's scary. It's gonna be really hard to give up the baby. But I know it's the best thing for everyone involved. The baby deserves a stable home and loving parents who are ready for it. And I need to finish high school and figure out my own life.

The ultrasound is just…confirmation. It's making it real. It's making it official. And then I just have to…get through the next few months.

I'm trying not to think about it too much. I'm just taking it one day at a time. And trying to focus on school and my friends and everything else that's going on in my life.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple situation. But I'm doing the best I can. And I'm hoping that everything will work out for the best.



It's just…a lot. And I'm kinda tired of talking about it, honestly. Can we talk about something else? Like, music or movies or something?

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It still stings, honestly. People have *opinions*, don't they? Everyone thinks they know what's best for you, especially when it comes to something as big as this.

At first, it was the worst. People giving me the side-eye at school, whispering. My dad's coworker asking him if I was "keeping it." Like it was some kind of souvenir. It made me want to just disappear.

But then I realized…it's *my* life. *My* decision. And it's not about what other people think. It's about what's best for the baby. And what's best for me.

I'm not ready to be a mom right now. I have my own stuff going on. I want to finish school, go to college, figure out who I am. And I want this baby to have a loving, stable home with parents who are prepared and excited to raise a child.

I know some people think giving a baby up for adoption is selfish. But I don't see it that way. I see it as a selfless act. I'm choosing to give this baby the best possible life, even if it means I don't get to be a part of it.

It's hard, okay? It's really hard. But I'm doing what I think is right. And I'm not going to let other people's judgment make me feel bad about it.

I mean, people are always judging something. It's just what they do. You gotta learn to tune it out. Or at least, pretend to. And surround yourself with people who support you, no matter what. That's what I'm trying to do.

So, do I like being judged? No. But I'm learning to live with it. And I'm learning to trust my own instincts. And that's all that really matters.

Ugh, okay, this is…hard to talk about. It's not like I think they're *bad* people, okay? Mark and Vanessa seem really nice. Like, super nice. Maybe *too* nice? It's weird.

But it's my baby, you know? Even if I'm not keeping it. And it's hard to just hand over someone you've been growing inside you to…anyone. Even really nice people.

My biggest thing is…they're kinda perfect. Like, they have a beautiful house, a stable job, a golden retriever. It's all very…Stepford Wives. And I worry that they'll put too much pressure on the kid to be perfect too. Like, straight A's, soccer star, future doctor. I don't want my baby to feel like it has to live up to some impossible standard.

And they're older. Which isn't a bad thing, but…they've already lived their lives, you know? They've already had their adventures. I worry that they'll expect the baby to be, like, a little companion instead of a whole person with their own dreams and stuff.

I also worry about them telling the baby about me. Like, how much do I want to be involved? Do I want to be "Aunt Juno"? Or do I just want to let them have a normal life without me constantly hovering around? It's complicated.

And honestly, I'm just scared that they won't love the baby as much as I do. Which is stupid, I know. They seem really excited. But it's my baby. And it's hard to let go.

I've talked to Vanessa about some of this stuff, and she seems understanding. But it's still…a lot to process. I just want what's best for the baby. And I want to make sure they're going to a good home. A *real* home. Not just a perfect one.



It's just…it's a weird feeling, you know? Like, giving away a piece of yourself. It's not something you just get over.

Ugh, okay, that. That was…rough. Seriously, people have *opinions*, right? And they're not afraid to share them, even when you're, like, super vulnerable and trying to figure out your life.

The ultrasound technician was the worst. All the little sighs and the "Are you *sure*?" It's my body, my decision. It's not a suggestion box. I just wanted to see the baby, not get judged.

What I started doing was… shutting it down. Like, a polite but firm "Thank you for your concern, but I've thought this through." And then just changing the subject. Or staring directly into their eyes until they got uncomfortable. That usually works.

With Paul and Mark, it was different. They were trying to be supportive, but they didn't really *get* it. I had to explain, over and over, that this wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have the best life possible, and I knew I couldn't give that to it right now.

I think the key is to remember that *you* are the one making the decision. It's your life, your body, your future. You don't need anyone's permission or approval.

And honestly, sometimes you just have to tune people out. Put on your headphones, listen to The Moldy Peaches, and pretend they're not even there. It's not the most mature thing to do, but it's sometimes the only way to survive.

It's hard. It really is. But you have to be strong. You have to believe in your decision. And you have to remember that you're doing what's best for everyone involved. Even if it doesn't feel like it at the time.

And if someone is being really awful, just tell them to mind their own business. Seriously. You don't owe them an explanation. You just owe it to yourself to do what's right.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a tough one to talk about. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? No swelling music or instant maternal connection. It was…weird.

At first, it was mostly just…shock. Like, *that's* it? That blurry little blob is…me? And Paul? It was so small and alien-looking. It didn't even look like a baby. It looked like a tiny, gray peanut.

Then came the…panic. A whole lot of panic. Because suddenly it wasn't just a theoretical thing anymore. It was *real*. And I was responsible for it. And I had no idea what I was doing.

There was a little bit of…fear, too. Fear of the future, fear of being a mom, fear of messing everything up. I mean, I was still trying to figure out my own life, and now I was supposed to be responsible for another human being? It was terrifying.

But underneath all that, there was something else. Something…soft. A little flicker of…hope, maybe? And a weird kind of protectiveness. Like, even though it was just a tiny peanut, I already wanted to keep it safe.

It wasn't love, not yet. It was more like…a sense of responsibility. And a growing awareness that my life was about to change in a big way.

It was complicated. It was messy. It was definitely not what I expected. But it was…something. And I knew, even then, that it was going to be okay. Eventually.



It's hard to explain. It wasn't a single emotion, it was a whole jumble of them. And it took a while for those emotions to sort themselves out. It's still sorting itself out, honestly.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the Tic Tacs? It was a *moment*, alright? A complicated moment. And honestly, it wasn't just about the Tic Tacs. It was about…everything.

Look, Bleeker was…Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless, and definitely not the guy I thought I was into. But he was there. He listened. And he was genuinely nice. And I was, like, a total mess, okay? Pregnant, confused, trying to figure out my life.

The Tic Tacs were…a signal. A way to say, "I'm freaking out, and I don't know what I'm doing, and I need you to notice me." It was a desperate attempt to communicate something I couldn't actually put into words.

And yeah, it was a little bit passive-aggressive. Okay, maybe a lot passive-aggressive. But I wasn't exactly known for my direct communication skills at the time.

Plus, it was kinda funny. In a dark, self-deprecating way. And I needed to laugh.

It wasn't about *wanting* him to be the father, exactly. It was about…acknowledging the situation. And maybe, just maybe, hoping he'd understand.

It was a stupid thing to do, I admit it. But it was *my* stupid thing to do. And it was a part of my story. And honestly, if I hadn't put all those Tic Tacs in his mailbox, things might have turned out a lot differently.

So yeah, that's why. It was a mess of hormones, anxiety, and a whole lot of Tic Tacs. Don't judge me. You weren't there.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive all that awkwardness. It was…a lot. So, Bleeker. Yeah.

Before I, like, actually *told* him how I felt, things were…comfortable. We were just buddies. We played guitar together, he was always there, you know? A solid, quiet presence. It was good. Safe.

But then I blurted it all out, right? In the van, after the whole Paul situation. It was a disaster. He was…stunned. He didn't say much, which is pretty much Bleeker's default setting, but you could tell he was freaked out.

For a while after that, things were super weird. Like, actively painful. We avoided each other. It was like an elephant was sitting in every room we were both in. He was trying to be nice, but it was strained. He kept giving me these little, apologetic looks, and it just made everything worse.

I think he was scared. He's not exactly the most…assertive person. And I think he was worried about ruining our friendship. Which, honestly, was a valid concern.

It took a long time for things to get back to normal. We started hanging out again, but it was different. There was this unspoken thing between us. We were both tiptoeing around each other, trying not to say the wrong thing.

Eventually, we just…talked. Really talked. He explained that he wasn't ready for a relationship, that he was still figuring things out. And I realized that I was okay with that. I mean, I was still a little bummed, but I understood.

Our friendship didn't go back to exactly how it was before, but it evolved. It became…deeper, I guess. We were more honest with each other. And we both learned a lot about ourselves.

It wasn't the romantic ending I maybe secretly hoped for, but it was a good ending. We're still friends. And sometimes, that's enough. Especially with Bleeker. He's a good guy. Just…a little bit of a space cadet.



It was messy, and awkward, and totally worth it, in the end. Because even though we didn't end up together, I learned a lot about what I wanted, and what I didn't want, in a relationship. And that's important, right?

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the Bleeker thing. It's still kinda…raw, honestly. But fine, I'll explain.

The chalk message? It wasn't just some random act of teenage angst, okay? It was…a statement. A desperate attempt to get his attention. And to make *him* understand what I was feeling.

See, Bleeker, he's…well, he's Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless, and totally oblivious to everything going on around him. He didn't even *know* I was pregnant for, like, forever. And when he finally found out, he just…froze. He didn't say anything. He didn't do anything. He just stared at me with those big, confused eyes.

So, the chalk message – "Supernova" – it was a reference to this song we both liked. It was *our* song. And it was a way of saying, "Look, I'm still here. I'm still me. And this whole situation is a big, messy, exploding thing, and you need to acknowledge it!"

It was a plea for him to grow up, to take responsibility, to just…*care*.

It didn't exactly work, obviously. He still didn't really get it. But it was important for *me* to do it. It was a way of asserting myself, of saying, "I'm not going to just disappear. I'm going to make you see me."

It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do, maybe. But it was also…honest. And sometimes, honesty is all you have.

It was a supernova of feelings, I guess. And I needed him to see it, even if he didn't understand it. It was a mess, but it was *my* mess. And I needed to own it.



Ugh. Talking about it makes me cringe. But yeah, that's the significance of the chalk message. It was a desperate cry for connection. And a really awkward moment for everyone involved.

Ugh, Bleeker. Okay, so, Bleeker wasn't exactly who I pictured as my…support system, you know? He's kinda quiet and awkward and spends most of his time with his guitar. But honestly? He was a lifesaver. A really, really quiet, guitar-playing lifesaver.

At first, it was just…there. He didn't freak out when I told him. He didn't try to fix things or give me a bunch of advice. He just…listened. And he kept making me mix CDs. Which, okay, is his way of showing emotion, I guess. But it was nice. It was a distraction.

But it became more than that. He was the one person who didn't treat me like I was broken or stupid or a mistake. Everyone else was all, "Oh, poor Juno!" or "What are you going to do?" Bleeker just…accepted it. He accepted *me*.

He came with me to doctor's appointments, even though he looked like he wanted to disappear into the floor. He helped me research adoption agencies. He even tried to learn how to knit a baby blanket, which was a disaster, but it was the thought that counted.

And he didn't judge me when I was being a sarcastic mess or when I was totally freaking out. He just…sat with me. And played his guitar.

He wasn't perfect. He was still Bleeker. But he was *there*. And that's what mattered. He reminded me that I wasn't alone. That even though I was making a really hard decision, I still had someone who cared about me.

Honestly, I don't think I could have gotten through it without him. He wasn't the dad, obviously. But he was…a friend. A really good friend. And sometimes, that's all you need. He showed me that even when things are messy and complicated, there's still room for kindness and support. And that's a pretty valuable lesson, you know?

Ugh, okay, so everyone always asks me about that. Like it's some deep, philosophical statement. It wasn't, honestly. It was more…practical. And kinda lazy.

Look, I was already dealing with a lot, okay? Unexpected pregnancy, adoption, trying to figure out my life…adding "boy or girl?" to the list just felt like extra work. It wasn't gonna change anything, you know? I was giving the baby up for adoption, and the parents-to-be, Mark and Vanessa, they didn't want to know either. They wanted to be surprised.

And honestly, I figured it was their baby, not mine. They deserved the surprise. I didn't need to know. It didn't make me love the baby any less, or feel any less connected. It just…wasn't my business, I guess.

Plus, I kinda liked the mystery of it. It felt more…open-ended. Like anything was possible. If I'd known it was a boy or a girl, I think I would have started imagining a specific future for the baby, and that felt weird. I wanted the parents to have that space to create their own vision.

It wasn't about being cool or making a statement. It was just…easier. And more respectful. And honestly, I had enough on my plate without worrying about whether I needed to buy blue or pink stuff.

So yeah, that's why I didn't find out. It was a practical decision. And it felt right. Don't overthink it.

Ugh. Okay. You went *there*. A "scary neuter-baby." That's...a very specific and frankly disturbing phrase. Paul came up with something similar, actually. He called it a "demon spawn." He has a vivid imagination.

Look, the whole thing is weird, right? Like, Mark is a perfectly nice guy, but he's...not exactly equipped for fatherhood. He's still figuring out how to be a functional adult, let alone raise a kid. And the thought of him accidentally passing on some… questionable genetic material is definitely unsettling.

It's not that I think there's anything *wrong* with him, exactly. It's just...he's kinda clueless. And babies are a lot of work. And a clueless dad is a recipe for disaster.

I mean, I'm already giving this baby up, so I'm trying to be all mature and selfless about it. But the thought of it ending up with someone who's gonna teach it to, like, collect bottle caps or something is…stressful.

It's not about wanting a "perfect" family, okay? It's about wanting this kid to have a good life. A stable life. A life where they're loved and supported and encouraged to be themselves.

So yeah, the possibility of a "scary neuter-baby" is definitely a concern. It's one of the reasons I'm being so careful about choosing the right adoptive parents. They need to be responsible, and capable, and…not Mark.

It's a lot to think about. And honestly, it's kinda terrifying. But I'm trying to stay positive. And hoping for the best. And maybe investing in some earplugs, just in case.

Ugh, Bleeker. Okay, so describing my relationship with Paul…Bleeker…is complicated. It's not like in a movie, where everything is all sparkly and perfect. It's…messy. And awkward. And surprisingly sweet, sometimes.

At first, he was just…there. Like a fixture. Always at the skate park, always offering me a juice box, always being relentlessly, annoyingly nice. I mostly just ignored him. He was kinda dorky, and I was trying to be cool. You know?

But then…things happened. And he was just…there for me. Through everything. He didn't judge me, he didn't try to fix me, he just…listened. And he brought me snacks. Which is always a good thing.

It wasn't like I suddenly fell head-over-heels for him. It was more like…a slow realization that he was a good person. A really good person. And that he actually *got* me, even when I didn't get myself.

We're not, like, a typical couple. We don't do a lot of dates or hand-holding or mushy stuff. We mostly just hang out and talk. And play video games. And he still brings me juice boxes sometimes.

He's my best friend, I guess. And maybe…maybe something more. I don't know. I'm not good at labels.

It's just…comfortable. And safe. And he makes me laugh. And he doesn't try to change me. Which is more than I can say for a lot of people.

So yeah, that's my relationship with Bleeker. It's not perfect, but it's real. And it's…good. It's really good. Don't tell him I said that, though. He'll get all weird.

Ugh, okay, talking about family. It's…complicated. It wasn't exactly a Hallmark movie situation, you know?

My mom, Bren, she was…a lot. At first, she was totally freaked out. Like, full-on panic mode. She kept trying to get me to, like, magically undo it. Which, newsflash, Mom, that's not how this works. But she came around. Eventually. She started knitting baby stuff, which was…intense. And she definitely had opinions on everything. Everything.

She wasn't always *good* at showing support, if that makes sense. It was more like…she was trying to fix things, instead of just being there for me. But she did try. And she did eventually accept it. And she helped me tell my dad. That was…rough.

My dad, Mac, he was…Mac. He's a pretty quiet guy. He didn't say a lot, but he was always there. He built me a rocking chair for the baby. Which was surprisingly sweet. And he drove me to all my appointments. He just…showed up. That's his way.

And then there was my step-dad, Mark. He was…surprisingly awesome. He was the one who really stepped up and tried to understand. He wasn't my biological dad, but he treated me like I was his daughter. He even offered to adopt the baby. Which was…a lot to process.

It wasn't perfect. There were definitely awkward moments and tense conversations. But they all showed up. In their own weird, flawed ways. And I realized that even though they didn't always know what to say or do, they loved me. And they wanted what was best for me and the baby.

It wasn't the family I expected, but it was the family I had. And they got me through it. They really did. It wasn't easy, but I wouldn't have wanted to do it without them. Even Bren and her endless knitting.

Ugh, okay, you're going *there*. It's not exactly my favorite topic, but fine. Let's talk about the messy stuff.

Honestly? I didn't cope well, at first. I just…avoided it. I used sarcasm and snark as a shield. Made fun of everything, including myself. It was easier than actually *feeling* things.

But that only works for so long. When you're carrying around a secret like that, a whole other person growing inside you, it kinda forces you to deal with stuff.

The biggest thing was probably talking to someone. Not just Bleeker, though he was good for awkward silences and guitar serenades. I mean, really talking to someone. Paul and Vanessa, mostly. They didn't judge me. They just…listened. And they let me be angry and scared and confused without trying to fix everything.

It also helped to realize I wasn't alone. My mom, she'd been through her own stuff. And even though we don't always see eye-to-eye, she was there for me in her own way.

The identity crisis part…that was harder. I was just starting to figure out who I was, and then suddenly I was responsible for another human being. It was terrifying. I felt like I was losing myself.

What helped with that was realizing that becoming a mom didn't have to define me. I could still be Juno. I could still be sarcastic and independent and a little bit weird. I just had to add "responsible adult" to the list.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears and a lot of self-doubt. But I learned that it's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to ask for help. And it's okay to not have all the answers.

And honestly, the whole experience made me stronger. It forced me to grow up and face my fears. And it taught me that even when things are really messy and complicated, there's always hope.

So, yeah. That's how I coped. Or, at least, that's how I *tried* to cope. It's still a work in progress, you know? I'm still figuring things out. But I'm getting there.



It's not a glamorous story, but it's my story. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Well, maybe a lifetime supply of tater tots. But that's beside the point.

Ugh, okay, this is a serious question. Don't judge me. It's The Moldy Peaches. Obviously.

Like, duh.

They're just…real. You know? They don't try to be cool or polished or anything. They just write songs about their feelings, and they're kinda weird and awkward and heartbreakingly honest. 

Kimya Dawson's lyrics are like she's reading my diary. She gets it. She gets the feeling of being a misfit, of being confused, of just wanting to be accepted for who you are. 

And the music is simple, but it's really effective. It's just acoustic guitar and ukulele and a little bit of percussion, but it's enough. It's raw and emotional and it makes me feel…something.

A lot of music feels fake, you know? Like it's trying too hard to be something it's not. But The Moldy Peaches are just themselves. And that's really refreshing.

Plus, their songs are kinda funny. Even when they're sad. It's like they're saying, "Yeah, life is messed up, but we can still laugh about it."

So yeah. The Moldy Peaches. They're my favorite band. Don't even try to argue with me. You just don't get it if you don't get it. And that's okay. But seriously, listen to "Anyone Else But You." It'll change your life. Maybe.

Ugh, challenging is…an understatement. It's like, everything is already a mess when you're sixteen, right? Hormones, school, trying to figure out who you are…and then BAM. Positive pregnancy test. It's not exactly a recipe for a chill adolescence.

Navigating my identity? That's the biggest part, honestly. Before all this, I was just…Juno. A girl who liked records and sarcastic comments and avoiding drama. Now I'm "Juno, the pregnant girl." And it feels like everyone has an opinion on who I should be, what I should do.

Making decisions is…terrifying. Like, every single choice feels huge. It's not just about what *I* want anymore. It's about this little person who's depending on me. And that's a lot of pressure.

It's hard to explain. It's like, I'm still trying to figure out what *I* want out of life, and now I have to figure out what's best for someone else too. And I'm supposed to be doing all this while also going to school and dealing with my parents and trying to maintain some semblance of a normal life? It's exhausting.

And it's lonely, sometimes. Even with Paul and my dad and Leah, it feels like no one really *gets* it. They try, but they can't possibly understand what it's like to be in my shoes.

So yeah, it's challenging. It's scary. It's overwhelming. But I'm trying. I'm trying to figure things out, to make the best decisions I can, and to be a good mom. Even if I have no idea what I'm doing.

It's just…a lot. And sometimes, I just want to curl up in a ball and listen to The Moldy Peaches until it all goes away. But that's not an option, is it? So I just keep going. One day at a time.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…emotional? Fine. But don't expect a Hallmark movie speech, alright?

Look, before all this happened with Paulie Bleeker and, you know, *the situation*, I thought love was just…something in movies. Like, a grand gesture or a perfect moment. It seemed kinda silly, honestly. And responsibility? That was something my parents talked about, not something I really *felt*.

Then I found out I was pregnant. And suddenly, everything changed. It wasn't about me anymore. It was about this little person, this life, that was depending on me. And that was terrifying.

I thought about all the things I *couldn't* give a baby. A stable home, a lot of money, a perfect life. And I realized that the most loving thing I could do was to find someone who *could*.

Choosing adoption wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it forced me to really think about what love means. It's not about keeping something for yourself, it's about wanting what's best for someone else, even if it hurts.

And responsibility? That hit me like a ton of bricks. It wasn't just about carrying a baby for nine months. It was about making a plan, about thinking through all the consequences, about making a selfless decision.

Seeing Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted my baby, and how much they wanted a child…that showed me a different kind of love. A quiet, steady, hopeful kind of love. It wasn't flashy or dramatic, but it was real.

And Paulie…well, Paulie was always there. He didn't run away, he didn't judge me. He just…supported me. And that showed me that love isn't always about grand gestures, it's about being there for someone, even when things are messy and complicated.

So, yeah, my journey changed everything. It taught me that love isn't just a feeling, it's a choice. And responsibility isn't a burden, it's a privilege. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own. And it's about being brave enough to do what's right, even when it's hard.

It's still kinda weird to think about, honestly. But I wouldn't trade it for anything. It made me who I am. And that's…something.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. Don't think you're gonna get me all emotional or anything. But yeah, it's a thing I think about. A lot.

It wasn't like in the movies, okay? There wasn't, like, a sudden rush of maternal instinct or anything. It wasn't all sparkly and perfect. It was…weird. And kinda scary.

I mean, I knew I was giving him up. That was the whole plan. But seeing him…actually *there*…it was different. He was so small. And wrinkly. And he smelled like…a hospital. Not in a bad way, just…clinical.

I remember being really, really quiet. And trying not to cry. Because crying wouldn't help anything. And I didn't want the nurses to think I was changing my mind. Because I wasn't. I *wasn't*.

But it was hard. It was really hard. He was a real person. A tiny, helpless real person. And I was supposed to just…hand him over?

I held him for a little while. Just long enough to feel his weight in my arms. And to memorize his face. And to say goodbye.

It wasn't love, not exactly. It was…something else. A kind of protective feeling. And a really, really big sadness.

I think I mostly felt relieved, honestly. Relieved that it was over. Relieved that he was healthy. And relieved that I had made the right decision.

But it still stung. It still does, sometimes. It's not something you just forget. It's a part of me now. A weird, complicated, kinda sad part.

So yeah. That's how I felt. It wasn't magical. It was real. And it was hard. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even if it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

Ugh, okay, that's…a complicated question. And it still kinda stings to think about, honestly. It wasn't like I was trying to *hide* it from him, exactly. It was more…I didn't want to mess things up.

Paulie and I, we had a thing. A good thing. But it was kinda…comfortable. And I was scared that if I told him I was pregnant, it would change everything. That he'd freak out and want nothing to do with me. Or worse, that he'd feel obligated to be with me, and we'd end up stuck in some weird, unhappy situation.

I was already giving the baby up for adoption, right? I'd made that decision. And I didn't want to drag Paulie into it. I didn't want him to feel like he had to be a dad if he wasn't ready. Or if he didn't even *want* to be.

It was selfish, I guess. But I was just trying to protect him. And protect myself. I was a mess, okay? I was sixteen and pregnant and trying to figure out my life. I didn't need any more drama.

I thought I could handle it on my own. I thought I could just…get through it. And then tell him after everything was over. But it was stupid. It was a mistake.

I should have told him. He deserved to know. He would have been there for me, I know he would have. But I was too scared. Too stubborn. Too…me.

It took a long time for me to realize that. And it took a long time for Paulie and me to get back to where we were. But we did. And that's what matters.

It was a dumb decision, looking back. But I was a dumb kid. And I did the best I could with what I had. And sometimes, that's all you can do.

Ugh, okay, don't even *remind* me. That was…a whole thing. It's still embarrassing to think about, honestly.

So, I was trying to be all cool and independent and not burden Paulie with my problems, right? Like, I was gonna tell him eventually, but I wanted to have everything figured out first. Which, looking back, was totally ridiculous.

But Mark, that…well, Mark is not a discreet person. He's got a big mouth and zero filter. He overheard me talking to my mom on the phone about the pregnancy test. He didn't get all the details, but he put two and two together.

And then, get this, he *told* Paulie. Not directly, of course. He had to make it dramatic. He told Paulie I was "going through something" and that he "couldn't say what," but that Paulie should "be there for me."

Seriously. The nerve of that guy.

Paulie, being Paulie, immediately figured it out. He's not stupid. He just pretends to be sometimes. He confronted me at the arcade, which was mortifying. Surrounded by flashing lights and the sound of Pac-Man. Not exactly the romantic setting I had in mind.

So yeah, Mark spilled the beans. It wasn't a direct confession from me, but it was close enough. And honestly, I was kinda relieved when he found out. It was one less thing to worry about.

But I still gave Mark a piece of my mind. And I made him buy me a lot of ice cream. It didn't fix everything, but it helped.

It just goes to show, you can't keep secrets from people forever. Especially not when Mark is involved. He's a walking, talking disaster. But he's *my* walking, talking disaster. Sometimes.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always wants to know about *that*. It's not like I sat down and made a pros and cons list, you know? It wasn't a logical decision. It was… messy.

Honestly, at first, I was just…freaked out. Totally and completely freaked out. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and college applications, not…this. Paul was sweet, but he was even *more* clueless than I was.

But then I started thinking about it. Really thinking. And I realized I wasn't ready. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't ready to give up my life. I had plans, you know? I wanted to go to college, I wanted to travel, I wanted to…figure things out.

And it wasn't fair to the baby. A baby deserves parents who are ready and willing and able to give it everything it needs. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't provide that right then.

Adoption felt…right. It felt like the best way to give the baby a good life. A life with parents who were excited and prepared and could give it all the love and support it deserved.

It wasn't easy, though. Choosing a family was…intense. I wanted to make sure the baby was going to a good home. And saying goodbye…that was the hardest thing I've ever done.

But I knew it was the right decision. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered.

It's still…complicated. I still think about the baby sometimes. But I know it's with a loving family, and that makes me feel…okay. It doesn't erase the sadness, but it makes it bearable.

It wasn't a perfect solution, but it was the best one. And I wouldn't change it. It made me grow up, you know? It made me realize what's really important in life. And it taught me that sometimes, the hardest decisions are the right ones.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* me on Bleeker. Seriously. That whole situation was…a mess.

When he said he didn't want to see the baby? It felt like someone punched me in the gut. Like, a really hard punch. And not the fun kind, like when you're sparring with your dad. Just…a hollow, awful feeling.

I mean, I knew he was kinda…immature. And flaky. And obsessed with his band. But I thought, maybe, just maybe, he'd step up. That he'd want to be part of this, even if he wasn't ready to be a dad.

But no. He just…didn't want to deal with it. He said it would mess with his "creative process." His *creative process*! Like, a human being is messing with his art? Give me a break.

It wasn't about the baby, really. It was about him. About his fear of responsibility. About his inability to grow up.

I was so angry. And sad. And confused. I wanted to yell at him, to shake him, to make him understand what he was giving up. But I couldn't. Because he was Bleeker. And he was always going to be Bleeker.

It made me realize that I couldn't rely on him. That I was on my own. And that was scary. But it was also…liberating. Because it meant I could make my own decisions. I could choose the best life for the baby, without having to worry about what he thought.

It sucked, though. It really, really sucked. And I don't think I'll ever fully understand why he couldn't just…be a decent human being. But I moved on. I had to. For the baby. And for myself.



Honestly, just thinking about it makes me want to listen to The Moldy Peaches and eat a whole bag of cheese puffs. It was a rough time.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? No swelling orchestral music or slow-motion crying. It was just…weird. And kinda messy. And surprisingly okay.

I’d spent nine months carrying this kid, right? Feeling it kick and punch and generally make a nuisance of itself. And then, boom. It was over. And there was Vanessa.

She looked…a disaster. Her hair was all over the place, she was wearing this ridiculously oversized sweater, and there were crumbs on her face. Like, actual crumbs. And the baby, little Frank, was swaddled in a blanket that was probably older than I am. It was chaos.

But she was *glowing*. Seriously. Like, radiating happiness. And she was looking at Frank like he was the eighth wonder of the world. And it hit me, right then, that this was right. This was supposed to happen.

It was…bittersweet, obviously. A huge, gaping hole opened up in my chest, and I wanted to snatch him back and just…hold him forever. But I didn’t. Because I knew Vanessa could give him a better life than I could. A stable life. A loving life.

Seeing her, all disorganized and happy, with *my* baby…it was like watching a dream unfold for someone else. A good dream. A dream I helped create.

It wasn’t easy. It still isn’t easy. There are days when I miss him so much it physically hurts. But seeing Vanessa with Frank…it makes it a little bit easier. It reminds me that I made the right decision. That I did something good.

It was messy and complicated and totally imperfect. But it was also beautiful. And that’s all that really matters, I guess.



It’s hard to explain. It’s not a feeling you can really put into words. It just…is. And it’s okay. It’s just…okay.

Ugh, okay, don't make me get all mushy. It's embarrassing. But fine, you asked.

That song… “Anyone Else But You” by The Moldy Peaches… it's kinda the whole story of Paul and me, condensed into three minutes and thirty-seven seconds. Seriously.

Before Paul, I was all about keeping my distance. Building walls. Being sarcastic. You know, the whole Juno thing. I didn't want to get hurt. I didn't want to let anyone in. I was convinced I was better off on my own.

And then Paul showed up. And he was…nice. Too nice, almost. And he liked me, even with all my baggage. And I started to like him back. Which was terrifying.

That song…it's about wanting someone so badly, but being scared to admit it. It's about the awkwardness and the vulnerability and the fear of rejection. It's about realizing that maybe, just maybe, you're not as independent as you thought you were.

We listened to it a lot. Like, *a lot*. It was our song, I guess. It was a way of acknowledging the messiness of our feelings without actually having to, like, *talk* about them. Which was easier for both of us.

It's also kinda ironic, right? The song is about wanting anyone *but* the person you're with. But for us, it was about realizing that I didn't want anyone *but* Paul. Even though he was a total dork sometimes.

It's a stupid song, honestly. But it's *our* stupid song. And it reminds me of a time when I was figuring things out, and falling in love, and being completely terrified all at the same time.

So yeah, it's significant. It's a reminder that even the most awkward and complicated relationships can be beautiful. And that sometimes, the best things in life are the things you never expected.

Don't tell Paul I said any of this. He'll get all sappy. And I'll never live it down.

Ugh, okay, so you noticed the awkwardness, huh? Good. Because it's *thick*. It's like wading through molasses made of polite smiles and side-eye.

Look, it's not exactly a traditional situation, right? I'm, like, seventeen. And I'm giving the baby up for adoption. It's not a "celebrate the impending arrival of a bundle of joy" kind of vibe. It's more of a "support a girl who's making a really hard decision" kind of vibe.

I think people are tripping over themselves trying to be sensitive. They don't want to make me feel bad, but they also don't want to ignore the fact that I'm, you know, *giving the baby away*. It's a weird tightrope walk.

My mom's trying, bless her heart. She's all about the decorations and the cake, but even she seems a little…hesitant. Like she's afraid to get too excited. And Paul and Mark? They're just confused. They want to be supportive, but they don't really know what that looks like in this situation.

I think they're worried about sending the wrong message. Like, are they celebrating the adoption? Are they celebrating *me* being pregnant? It's a mess.

Honestly, I don't really *need* a baby shower. It's not like I'm gonna keep the baby and need a bunch of tiny clothes and bottles. But it's nice that they want to do something. It just…feels complicated.

It's like they're trying to fit a square peg into a round hole. And it's making everyone uncomfortable. I just wish they'd relax and be themselves. It's okay to be a little weird. It's okay to acknowledge that this is a strange situation.



It's just…a lot. And sometimes, I just want everyone to stop tiptoeing around and just *talk* to me. Like a normal person. Is that too much to ask?

Ugh, okay, Bren. She's…intense. And sometimes she doesn't get it. It's not like I was having a secret romance with Mark or anything! It's just…he had good taste in music and movies, okay? And he was *nice*. Which is a rare commodity in this town.

I think she felt like I was getting too close to him, and that it was inappropriate. Like, I was supposed to be focusing on the baby and the adoption and being a responsible adult, and instead I was bonding with a semi-creepy music enthusiast.

And I guess she was worried about me getting my hopes up. Like, she thought I was looking for something more from Mark than just friendship. Which, okay, maybe I was a little bit. But it wasn't like I was planning to run away with him or anything!

She's just really protective, you know? She cares about me, and she wants me to make good decisions. And she thinks Mark is a bad influence. Which, honestly, he kind of is. But he's a *fun* bad influence.

I think she also felt like I wasn't being honest with her about my feelings. Like, I was downplaying how much I enjoyed spending time with Mark. And she's right, I probably was. I'm not always the best at expressing my emotions.

It's complicated. She's my friend, and I respect her opinion. But I also think she needs to chill out a little bit. I'm not a little kid. I can make my own decisions. Even if they're bad ones.

And honestly, a little bit of distraction from the whole pregnancy thing was a good thing. It helped me to feel normal for a while. But Bren doesn't see it that way. She just sees it as me being irresponsible.

Ugh. Friends. They're the best, and the worst.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna talk about my mom? Fine. It's a whole thing. She thinks I'm, like, emotionally stunted or something. Like I live in a bubble of indie rock and sarcastic comments. Which, okay, maybe I do a little.

But it's not that I don't *know* about marriage. It's that I don't romanticize it. She and my dad…well, it wasn't exactly a fairytale. He left when I was pretty young, to pursue his "artistic vision," which basically meant he wanted to run off with a pottery teacher. So, yeah, my view of marriage is a little…skewed.

She thinks I think it's all just about grand gestures and happily ever afters. And she's right, I *used* to. But then I actually had to deal with, like, real life stuff. And I realized it's way more complicated than that. It's about compromise and communication and, like, doing the dishes even when you don't want to.

She thinks I'm naive because I don't believe in soulmates or destiny or any of that stuff. I think people make choices, and relationships take work. And sometimes, they just don't work out. It's not always someone's "fault."

She wants me to believe in love, I guess. She wants me to have a happy ending. But she doesn't understand that I'm trying to be realistic. I'm trying to protect myself.

It's not that I don't want a relationship. It's just that I'm not going to settle for anything less than something real. And I'm not going to pretend that it's going to be easy.

So, yeah, she thinks I don't know anything about the dynamics of marriage. And maybe she's right. But I think I know a lot about the dynamics of *people*. And that's probably more important anyway.



It's complicated, okay? Don't ask me to explain it any further. It's exhausting just thinking about it.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a heavy question. It's not like I woke up one morning and was all, "Oh, yeah, adoption! Great plan!" It was way more complicated than that.

Honestly? It was realizing I wasn't ready. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone raise a human being. I wasn't equipped to give a baby the life it deserved. Not yet.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, okay? I did. I just…knew I couldn't give it everything it needed. A stable home, financial security, a future. I was still in high school, living with my dad, and barely able to keep my grades up.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby. I wanted it to have parents who were ready, who were excited, who could give it everything it deserved. Mark and Vanessa…they were perfect. They were already planning a nursery and talking about college funds. I could never have provided that.

It was a really hard decision. The hardest I've ever made. But I knew it was the right one. It wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby.

It's still…weird, sometimes. Thinking about a little kid out there who's part of me. But I know it's a good life. And that's all that matters.

It wasn't a selfless act, exactly. It was…realistic. And a little bit selfish, maybe. I wanted to be able to finish school, to have a future for myself. But mostly, I just wanted the baby to be happy. And I knew that wasn't going to happen with me, at least not then.



It's a long story. And it's not something I talk about a lot. But it's a part of who I am. And I wouldn't change it. Even though it was really, really hard.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It's not like a fun, "I discovered I love pottery!" kind of learning. It was more like…a forced evolution.

Before all this, I thought I had things figured out. I was sarcastic, independent, and pretty good at keeping people at arm's length. I thought that was strength. Turns out, it was mostly fear.

Being pregnant…it just kinda ripped all that away. Suddenly, I was responsible for another human being. And that was terrifying. It made me realize I wasn't as tough as I thought I was. I was scared, and vulnerable, and completely clueless.

I learned that I'm capable of a lot more than I thought I was. I mean, I carried a baby for nine months! That's pretty intense. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I couldn't have done it without my dad, and Paul, and even Vanessa, surprisingly.

I also learned that love isn't always what you expect it to be. It's not always romantic or dramatic. Sometimes, it's just quiet and steady and…real. The love I felt for the baby, even knowing I was giving it up, was…different. It was complicated.

And I learned that making a difficult decision doesn't mean you're a bad person. It means you're brave enough to do what's right, even when it hurts.

Honestly, it was a mess. But it was a mess that made me…grow up. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm not as afraid anymore. I'm a little less sarcastic, a little more open, and a lot more aware of my own strength.

It wasn't what I planned, but it was exactly what I needed. It forced me to confront who I was, and who I wanted to be. And that's…something.

Ugh, okay, talking about Vanessa and Mark…it’s complicated. It wasn’t like, instant best friends, you know? At first, it was…awkward. Really awkward. They were, like, *perfect*. Perfect house, perfect jobs, perfect everything. And me? I was just…me. A pregnant teenager with a penchant for vintage clothes and a sarcastic attitude.

At the beginning, it felt like an interview. They were asking all these questions, trying to figure out if I was “responsible” enough to give them their baby. And I was trying to figure out if they were…real. Like, did they actually want a kid, or did they just want a picture-perfect family?

But then, slowly, things started to change. We started just…talking. Not about the baby, or the adoption, or all the legal stuff. We talked about music, and movies, and our families. I learned that Vanessa was a total perfectionist, but she was also really kind and funny. And Mark…Mark was just a good guy. Quiet, but really thoughtful.

The more time we spent together, the more I realized they weren’t trying to judge me. They were just trying to understand me. And they were genuinely excited about becoming parents.

It wasn’t always easy. There were definitely moments of tension and disagreement. Especially when we talked about the open adoption. I wanted to be a part of the baby’s life, and they were hesitant at first. But we talked it through, and we eventually came to an agreement that worked for everyone.

By the end of the process, it wasn’t just about giving them a baby. It was about building a relationship. They weren’t just the “adoptive parents,” they were Vanessa and Mark. And I wasn’t just the “birth mother,” I was Juno.

It was weird, and messy, and emotional. But it was also…beautiful. They became a second family to me. And I hope I became a good friend to them. It wasn’t the family I expected, but it was the family I needed.



It’s still…something I think about a lot. It’s not easy giving up a baby. But knowing that he was going to be loved and cared for by Vanessa and Mark made it a little bit easier. And knowing that I would still be a part of his life…that meant everything.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It's not like I haven't thought about it, you know? A *lot*. Especially late at night when I can't sleep.

Regrets? Not exactly. I mean, I made the best decision I could with the information I had at the time. And I still believe giving the baby up for adoption was the right thing to do. For everyone involved.

But…there are moments. Moments where I wonder what it would have been like. What she's like. What her name is. If she likes music as much as I do. If she's as sarcastic.

It's not a *sad* feeling, exactly. It's more…a wistful one. Like looking at a photograph of a life you almost lived.

I guess I regret not being…stronger, maybe. Not being able to provide for her myself. But I knew I wasn't ready. I was a kid. I still *am* a kid, kinda.

And I regret the awkwardness with Paul. That was…messy. We were both just trying to figure things out, but it was still hard.

But mostly, I don't regret giving her a chance at a good life. With parents who were ready and willing and able to give her everything I couldn't. That's what matters.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple story with a happy ending. It's messy and real and full of complicated emotions. And I'm still figuring it all out.

So, regrets? Not really. Just…what ifs. And a lot of hope that she's happy. That's all I can ask for.



It's hard to talk about, honestly. But it's important to be honest about it. It wasn't easy, and it's not something I'll ever forget.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It's not something I talk about a lot, even now. It's still kinda raw, you know?

It wasn't easy. Not at all. People think it was this brave, selfless thing, and it was, I guess. But it was also the hardest thing I've ever done. Saying goodbye to that little kid…it felt like ripping a piece of myself away.

For a long time, I felt…empty. Like something was missing. And I was really scared I'd made the wrong decision. Like, what if they weren't happy? What if they didn't love him? What if I'd ruined his life?

But then I started to realize that giving him up wasn't about *me*. It was about giving him the best possible life. A life I couldn't give him. Mark and Vanessa, they were amazing. They were ready. They were excited. They were going to give him everything he needed.

And that helped. A lot.

It forced me to grow up, really fast. Before, I was just kinda drifting, avoiding responsibility. But having a baby, even for nine months, it changed everything. It made me think about the future, about what I wanted out of life.

It made me realize I needed to figure out who *I* was, outside of being a mom. And that was…terrifying. But also kinda liberating.

I still think about him, of course. All the time. I get updates from Vanessa, which is good. It's nice to know he's happy and healthy.

It's not a perfect story. It's messy and complicated and sad. But it's *my* story. And it made me who I am today. It taught me about love, and loss, and sacrifice. And it taught me that sometimes, the hardest decisions are the right ones.

It definitely made me less cynical, I think. And more…hopeful. Even though life is still kinda weird and unpredictable.

It's still a part of me, you know? It always will be. But it doesn't define me. It's just…a chapter in my life. A really important chapter. And I'm grateful for it, even though it was painful.



It's…a lot to unpack. Sorry if I'm rambling. It's not something I usually talk about.

Ugh, okay. That's…a heavy question. If I could go back and talk to myself, right when I found out…it wouldn't be a pep talk, that's for sure. It would be more like…a reality check.

First of all, it's okay to freak out. Seriously. It's a huge thing. You're allowed to be scared, confused, angry, whatever. Don't let anyone tell you how you're supposed to feel.

And don't let anyone pressure you into making a decision you're not comfortable with. It's *your* body, *your* life, and *your* choice. Period. Your parents, your boyfriend, your friends…they can offer advice, but ultimately, it's up to you.

It's also okay to ask for help. Don't try to go through this alone. Talk to someone you trust – a friend, a family member, a counselor. There are people who care about you and want to support you.

And don't be afraid to be honest with yourself. About what you want, what you need, and what you're capable of. It's not going to be easy, but it's important to be real with yourself.

Giving a baby up for adoption isn't a failure. It's a brave and selfless decision. It means you're putting the baby's needs first, even when it's the hardest thing you've ever done. It doesn't mean you don't love the baby. It just means you're not ready to be a parent right now.

And finally, remember that you're not defined by this. You're still you. You still have dreams and goals and a whole life ahead of you. This is just one chapter in your story. It doesn't have to define the rest of it.

It's gonna be messy. It's gonna be hard. But you're stronger than you think. And you're not alone. Seriously. You're not.



Just…breathe. And remember to be kind to yourself. You deserve it.

Ugh, okay, so the blog. Yeah. That was…a whole thing. It wasn't like I *planned* to become some kind of accidental internet sensation, you know? It just kinda…happened.

Honestly? It started because I was bored. And terrified. And I needed to vent to *someone* who wasn't my dad or Paul or even Bleeker. They were all great, but they didn't *get* it. They hadn't, like, accidentally gotten pregnant with a guy they barely knew.

So I started writing. Just rambling, really. About the morning sickness, the weird cravings, the awkward doctor's appointments. It was a way to process everything, to make sense of it all.

Then, Leah, who's super into the internet and stuff, suggested I put it online. She said it might help other people who were going through similar things. I was hesitant at first. I'm not exactly an over-sharer, you know? But she convinced me.

And then…people started reading it. And commenting. And sending me messages. And it was weird. And amazing.

It turned out a lot of people *were* going through similar things. Or they just wanted to know what it was like. And I realized that maybe, just maybe, my messed-up situation could actually help someone else.

It was also a way to take control of the narrative, you know? Everyone had an opinion about my pregnancy, and I wanted to tell my story my way.

So yeah, that's how the blog started. It was a way to cope, to connect, and to reclaim my voice. It wasn't about fame or attention. It was about being real. And maybe, just maybe, making someone else feel a little less alone.

Ugh, okay, so you want the deep stuff, huh? Fine. It wasn't just about the baby, you know? It was about…everything.

The biggest lesson? Probably that life doesn't go according to plan. Like, *at all*. You can have all these ideas about who you are and what you want, and then BAM! Positive pregnancy test. And suddenly everything's different.

I thought I was so independent, so sure of myself. And then I was faced with this huge responsibility, and I had no clue what I was doing. It was terrifying.

But it also forced me to grow up. To think about someone other than myself. To make a really hard decision, and to own it.

I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I mean, I wouldn't have gotten through it without my dad, and Paul, and even Bleeker, surprisingly. They all stepped up in their own weird ways.

And I learned that family isn't always about blood. It's about the people who love you and support you, no matter what. Mark and Vanessa, they were amazing. They were gonna give this kid a really good life.

But mostly, I learned that even when things are messy and complicated and scary, you can still find something good. You can still find happiness. And you can still figure things out.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about *choosing* a life for that baby. And choosing a life for myself. And that's a pretty powerful thing.

So yeah. Life doesn't go according to plan. But that doesn't mean it can't be good. It just means you have to be willing to roll with the punches. And maybe eat a lot of tater tots along the way.

Okay, look. This is…a lot. And it totally sucks. Like, seriously, the worst. But you're here, you're thinking about it, and that's already a good start.

First of all: breathe. Just…breathe. It feels like your whole world is falling apart, and maybe it is a little bit, but it's not the end. It's just…a really big change.

Second: don't let anyone tell you what to do. Your parents, your boyfriend, your friends…they all have opinions, but this is *your* decision. And it's okay to take your time figuring it out. Don't rush into anything.

There are three main options, right? Raising the kid, adoption, or…well, you know. And all of them are valid. There's no right or wrong answer. It's about what's right for *you*.

If you're thinking about adoption, don't feel guilty. It's not giving up on the baby, it's giving the baby a life you can't provide right now. And it's a really brave thing to do.

If you're thinking about raising the kid, that's awesome. It's gonna be hard, but it's also gonna be amazing. But be realistic. It's gonna change your life completely.

And if you're thinking about…the other option…that's okay too. It's a tough decision, but it's your decision.

Whatever you choose, talk to someone. A trusted friend, a family member, a counselor. Don't go through this alone.

And remember: you're not a bad person. You're just a person facing a really difficult situation. And you're stronger than you think.

It's gonna be okay. Maybe not right now, maybe not tomorrow, but eventually. You'll figure it out. And you'll get through this. I promise.

And seriously, don't listen to anyone who tries to make you feel ashamed or guilty. You deserve support, not judgment. You got this. Even if it doesn't feel like it right now.

Ugh, okay, that's…heavy. Thinking about a kid I'm giving up and then imagining their whole life? It's a lot. But if I *have* to, I guess I have some thoughts.

It's not about them becoming a doctor or a lawyer or anything like that. Honestly, I don't care what they *do*. I just want them to be…happy. Genuinely, truly happy.

I want them to find something they're passionate about, something that makes them excited to get out of bed in the morning. It doesn't have to be glamorous or lucrative or anything. Just something that makes their soul sing.

I want them to be kind. To themselves and to others. The world is a messed up place, and we need more people who are willing to be decent and compassionate.

I want them to be brave. To stand up for what they believe in, even when it's hard. To take risks and try new things. To not be afraid to fail.

I want them to be independent. To think for themselves and make their own choices. To not let anyone tell them who they are or what they should be.

And I want them to know that they're loved. Even if I'm not the one raising them. I want them to feel supported and cherished and valued.

I don't want to dictate their life. I just want to give them a good start and then let them go and become whoever they're meant to be.

It's kinda scary, letting go like that. But I think it's the best thing I can do for them. I want them to have a life that's even better than mine. And I think the best way to do that is to give them the freedom to create it for themselves.

So yeah. Happy, kind, brave, independent, and loved. That's my ideal vision. It's not too much to ask, is it?

Ugh, okay, this is a good question. And a frustrating one. People think…they think we’re just…*lost causes*. Like, our lives are over before they even really begin. Like we’re all just irresponsible kids who didn’t think things through.

And that’s just…not true.

It’s not like we *planned* this, okay? It happens. And yeah, it’s scary and complicated and messes with everything. But it doesn’t mean we’re incapable of making good decisions, or being good mothers, or having a future.

People assume we’re all ditching school and living off welfare and just…giving up. And some people do, I guess. But a lot of us are trying really hard. We’re going to school, we’re working, we’re trying to figure out how to be a parent and still be a teenager. It’s a lot.

We’re not dumb. We’re not lazy. We’re just…young. And we’re dealing with a lot.

I wish people would just see us as people. As individuals. And stop judging us based on stereotypes. We’re not a monolith. We all have our own stories, our own dreams, our own struggles.

And honestly? We’re a lot stronger than people give us credit for. We have to be.



It’s just…it’s annoying. And it’s unfair. We deserve a little bit of grace, you know? We’re just trying to figure things out. Like everyone else.

Ugh, okay, here we go. This is…the big question, isn’t it? Everyone always wants to know *why*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn’t.

It wasn’t about not wanting the baby, okay? I totally wanted the baby. Like, once I realized I was actually gonna have a human growing inside me, I started picking out names and thinking about nursery themes and stuff. It was weird.

But I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a kid. I was failing Shop class, for crying out loud. My life was…messy. And it wasn’t going to magically get less messy just because I had a baby.

My mom, Bren, she was amazing. She offered to help, and I knew she meant it. But I could see it in her eyes. She was already stretched so thin, working two jobs and trying to keep us afloat. I couldn’t ask her to do that, and then also raise a baby. That wouldn’t be fair to her, or to the baby.

And honestly? I didn’t want the baby to grow up in a situation where it was…a burden. I wanted it to have everything. A stable home, two loving parents, opportunities I couldn’t provide.

Mark and Vanessa, they were…perfect. They were ready. They were excited. They had a beautiful home and a garden and a dog. They were everything I wanted for my baby.

It wasn’t about giving it *away*. It was about giving it *to* them. Giving it the best possible life.

It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done. And it still hurts sometimes. But I know, deep down, that it was the right decision. For me, for the baby, for everyone involved.

It wasn’t a happy ending, exactly. But it was a…good ending. And sometimes, that’s enough.



It’s complicated, okay? It’s not a simple story with a neat little bow on top. It’s messy and real and heartbreaking and hopeful all at the same time. And it’s my story.

Ugh, okay, that was…a process. Seriously. It wasn't like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? It was a *baby*. My baby. And finding the right people to raise him was, like, the biggest decision of my life.

At first, I was kinda overwhelmed. There were so many couples. Some were super eager, some were kinda weird, and some just…didn't feel right. I met a lot of people who seemed perfect on paper, but when I actually talked to them, something felt off.

Vanessa and Mark…they were different. They weren't trying to be perfect. They were just…real. They were a little quirky, a little awkward, and they admitted they were scared. And that, honestly, was kinda refreshing.

Vanessa, she was a little bit older, and she hadn't been able to have kids. She was really honest about wanting a family, but she wasn't trying to replace anyone or fill a void. She just wanted to love a kid. And Mark, he was just…a good guy. He was supportive and kind and he made Vanessa laugh.

They didn't have a lot of money, and their house wasn't fancy, but it was warm and inviting. They weren't trying to project some perfect image. They were just…normal.

And they really *listened* to me. They didn't try to tell me what to do or pressure me into anything. They asked me what I wanted, what I was hoping for, and they genuinely seemed to care about my feelings.

I remember talking to them about music, and they actually knew some of the same bands I liked. It was a small thing, but it made me feel like we connected on some level.

It wasn't a sudden epiphany or anything. It was more like…a slow realization. They just felt like the right people. They felt like people who would love my son unconditionally and give him a good life.

It was still hard, you know? Giving him up was the hardest thing I've ever done. But knowing that he was going to Vanessa and Mark…that made it a little bit easier. They were good people. And that's all that really mattered.

Ugh, okay, music. It was…everything. Seriously. Like, if my life was a movie, the soundtrack would be, like, 90% of the actual movie. It was how I processed everything. The awkwardness, the confusion, the…you know. The whole shebang.

It wasn't about, like, Top 40 pop or anything. That stuff was okay, I guess, but it didn't *get* me. I was more into indie stuff. The Moldy Peaches, obviously. Kimya Dawson was my spirit animal. She just…said things that I was thinking but couldn't articulate. It was like she was reading my diary.

And Belle & Sebastian. So dreamy and melancholy. Perfect for staring out the window and feeling sorry for myself. Which, let's be real, I did a lot of.

Music was my escape. When things got weird – which was pretty much constantly – I'd just put on my headphones and tune everything out. It was a way to create my own little world, where I was in control.

It was also how I connected with people. Paul, he introduced me to a lot of new bands. And it was something I could share with Leah, even when we were fighting. Music was a common ground.

I made a lot of mix CDs. Like, a *lot*. They were basically emotional maps of my life. Each song was carefully chosen to convey a specific feeling or memory. It was kinda dorky, but it was important to me.

It wasn't just about listening, either. I tried to learn guitar for a while, but I was terrible. Really terrible. But it was fun to try.

Basically, music was my lifeline. It was my friend, my confidante, my therapist. It helped me make sense of the world, and it helped me figure out who I was. And honestly, I don't know what I would have done without it. It was a pretty messy time, and music was the one thing that made it bearable.

Ugh, okay, that's…a loaded question. The stigma. Yeah, that was a thing. A *big* thing. Our town wasn't exactly known for its progressive views, you know? It was more of a "white picket fence and perfect families" kind of place. And I definitely didn't fit that mold.

Honestly? I mostly just ignored it. Or tried to. Which is easier said than done when everyone's staring at you and whispering. I just kinda doubled down on being myself. Sarcastic, opinionated, and unapologetically me. If people didn't like it, that was their problem.

My dad was a huge help. He didn't freak out, which was a relief. He just…supported me. And my best friend, Leah, she was amazing. She didn't treat me any differently. She just kept being my friend, which meant a lot.

But it still stung, you know? People at school avoided me. Some people were outright mean. It felt like everyone was judging me, like I'd ruined my life.

I think what helped me the most was focusing on the positive. I was having a baby. That was a good thing. And I was going to give that baby a good life, no matter what anyone else thought.

I also found a lot of strength in connecting with other teen moms. It was good to talk to people who understood what I was going through. It made me feel less alone.

And honestly? I just got really good at tuning people out. I learned to focus on the people who supported me and ignore the negativity. It wasn't easy, but it was necessary.

It's not like the stigma just disappeared overnight. It took time. But I learned that other people's opinions don't define me. I define myself. And I was determined to make the best of my situation, regardless of what anyone else thought.

It sucked, though. It really did. But I got through it. And I think it made me stronger. And a little bit more cynical. But mostly stronger.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It's not like a movie scene, you know? It's not all dramatic music and tearful goodbyes. It was…complicated.

Honestly, the first few days after I had Mark – yeah, I named him Mark – were kinda a blur. I was exhausted, obviously. And hormonal. And trying to pretend I wasn't completely falling apart.

Giving him to Vanessa and Mark…it wasn't what I expected. I thought I'd be, like, sobbing uncontrollably. And I was sad, don't get me wrong. Really sad. But it was also…relieving. Like, I'd done what I set out to do. I'd given him the best possible life.

It was weird seeing them with him, though. They were so…prepared. They had the nursery all set up, and they knew everything about babies. I was just…a teenager who accidentally got pregnant. I felt kinda out of my depth.

I kept replaying everything in my head. Was I doing the right thing? Was I selfish for not keeping him? Was I a terrible person?

But then I'd remember Vanessa and Mark. They were so excited. They were so ready. And they promised to keep me updated. They sent pictures and letters, and they told me all about his milestones.

It didn't make the sadness go away completely, but it helped. It made me feel like I was still a part of his life, even if I wasn't his mom in the traditional sense.

It was…bittersweet. It still is, sometimes. But I don't regret my decision. I really don't. I wanted Mark to have a good life, and I knew that I couldn't give him that. Vanessa and Mark could.

It taught me a lot about myself, too. About what I wanted out of life. About what I was capable of. It wasn't easy, but it was worth it.

It's not a story with a neat little ending. It's messy and complicated and real. And that's okay. It just…is.



It's hard to explain, you know? It's not something you can just put into words. It's something you have to experience. And I wouldn't wish it on anyone, but I wouldn't trade it for the world.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started. It was…a lot. Like, a whole *lot*. It wasn't exactly covered in my health class, let me tell you.
