Physically? It was gross. Seriously. Morning sickness is a lie. It's all-day sickness. And not just throwing up, it's the nausea, the fatigue, the weird cravings. I wanted pickles and ice cream. Simultaneously. It was not a good look. My body was doing things I didn't even know it *could* do. And it was constantly changing. Like, one day my jeans fit, the next day they didn't. It was infuriating.

And the emotional stuff? That was even worse. I was already kinda angsty and sarcastic, and then hormones just took it to a whole new level. I was crying at commercials. I was snapping at my dad. I was having existential crises in the middle of the grocery store. It was a mess.

I mostly dealt with it by trying to pretend it wasn't happening. I listened to a lot of music, I watched a lot of movies, I tried to just…distract myself. But it didn't always work.

Paul was…helpful, I guess. He tried to be supportive, but he didn't really *get* it. He's a sweet guy, but he doesn't understand the complexities of being a teenage girl.

My friend Leah was the one who really got me through it. She just listened, and she didn't judge. She let me vent, and she made me laugh. She was a lifesaver.

And honestly, just talking to Annie, the woman who was going to adopt the baby, helped a lot. She was so calm and understanding. She made me feel like I was doing the right thing.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever gone through. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help.

It was a weird, messy, complicated time. But it was also…kind of beautiful. In a strange way. It made me grow up, whether I wanted to or not. And that's not always a bad thing.

Okay, wow. That's…a direct question. And honestly, it's not something I talk about a lot. It's personal. But you asked, so I'll try to explain.

Before everything happened, before I even knew I was pregnant, I didn't really *think* about reproductive rights. It was just…something that was there. Like, people had opinions, and there were protests, but it didn't really affect my life.

But then it did. It *really* did. And it wasn't just about me anymore. It was about deciding what was best for everyone involved – for me, for the baby, for the potential adoptive parents. It was a really hard decision, and it wasn't something I took lightly.

And the thing is, it wasn't about *wanting* an abortion. It was about making a responsible choice. It was about recognizing that I wasn't ready to be a mom, and that there were other people who could give that baby a better life.

Going through that experience, and dealing with all the judgment and the protests…it made me realize how important it is for people to have the right to make their own decisions about their bodies. It's not up to politicians or anyone else. It's a personal choice, and it should be made by the person who's going through it.

It also made me realize how lucky I was to have options. Not everyone has the resources or the support to make the choice that's right for them. And that's not fair.

So yeah, my experience definitely changed my views. I'm a firm believer in reproductive rights, and I think everyone deserves access to safe and legal abortion care. It's not about promoting abortion, it's about protecting people's freedom and their right to choose.

It's complicated, and it's not always easy. But it's important. And it's something we need to keep fighting for.



It's still…a sensitive topic for me. But I wanted to be honest with you. It's a part of my story, and it's shaped who I am.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know about the fear part? There was a *lot* of fear. Like, a whole ocean of it. It wasn't like in the movies, where you suddenly feel all maternal and glowing. It was more like…constant panic.

Honestly, I didn't really "overcome" my fears. I just…learned to live with them. And to push through them when I had to.

The biggest fear, obviously, was messing everything up. Like, I was sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a tiny human. I was terrified of being a bad mom, of not being able to provide for the baby, of ruining its life.

What helped? A few things.

First, **Paul and Vanessa.** They were…unexpectedly awesome. They didn't judge me, they just stepped up and offered support. Vanessa, especially, was a rock. She was already a mom, so she knew what she was doing. And Paul…well, Paul was just Paul. He was always there to make me laugh, even when I wanted to cry.

Second, **realizing I wasn't alone.** There were other teen moms out there. And even though our situations were all different, we could relate to each other. Talking to them helped me feel less isolated and less scared.

Third, **focusing on the baby.** Once I started feeling the baby move, it became less about my fears and more about *it*. I wanted to do everything I could to make sure it was healthy and happy. That gave me a purpose, and it gave me strength.

And finally, **accepting that I didn't have to have all the answers.** Nobody does. Parenting is a learning process. You make mistakes, you learn from them, and you keep going.

It wasn't easy. There were still plenty of moments where I wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear. But I kept reminding myself that I wasn't doing this for me. I was doing it for the baby. And that was enough to keep me going.

It's still scary sometimes, even now. But I've learned that fear is just a part of life. And that you can be scared and brave at the same time.



It's not a fairytale, you know? It's messy and complicated and terrifying. But it's also…worth it.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always wants to know about the adoption thing. It's not like I just woke up one morning and was like, "Oh yeah, adoption! That sounds easy!" It was…complicated.

Honestly? It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby. I was sixteen, okay? Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *lunch*, let alone a whole human life. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't financially stable, I was still in high school, and my life was…messy.

And my parents? They were supportive, but they weren't exactly equipped to raise a baby either. They were more the "let's go antiquing" type, you know? Not the "changing diapers and dealing with tantrums" type.

So, adoption just…made sense. It wasn't a sacrifice, it was a really hard decision that I made because I wanted the baby to have a good life. A life I couldn't provide at that moment.

I met Mark and Vanessa, and they were…amazing. They were genuinely excited about becoming parents, and they had a stable home and a loving relationship. They were everything a baby could ask for.

It wasn't about giving the baby *away*. It was about choosing the best parents for it. It was about wanting the baby to be loved and cared for and have every opportunity in the world.

It was a really tough decision, and I cried a lot. But I knew it was the right one. And honestly, seeing Mark and Vanessa with the baby…it made me feel good. It made me feel like I'd done something right.

It wasn't the easy way out. It was the responsible way. And sometimes, the responsible thing is the hardest thing.



It's still…weird, sometimes. But I'm okay with it. I made a choice, and I stand by it. And I hope the baby knows that I loved it, even before it was born.

Ugh. Okay, you want to get into the messy stuff, huh? Fine. It's not like I haven't spent enough time overthinking all of it already.

Look, Leah and I…we're complicated. We've been through everything together, basically. Since, like, forever. And she's the only one who really *gets* me. She's the one who doesn't judge, even when I'm being a total disaster. But she also doesn't sugarcoat things, which is good, because I need that. Sometimes.

The thing is, my getting pregnant kinda…shifted things. She was supportive, obviously, but it was also like, she was watching me live this huge life change and she wasn't. And she got all quiet and weird for a while. It was frustrating. We had some fights. But we always come back to each other. Because that's what best friends do, right? They fight, they forgive, and they keep showing up. Even when it's hard.

And Paulie…oh, Paulie. That was a whole other level of complicated. He's a good guy, really. Sweet, kinda clueless, and definitely not ready to be a dad. But he stepped up. He tried. And that meant a lot.

It wasn't a *romantic* relationship, not really. It was more like…a connection. A moment in time. And then a shared responsibility. It was awkward, and weird, and sometimes really frustrating. But we learned to communicate, eventually. And we both wanted what was best for the baby.

I think the hardest part was realizing that we weren't going to be a family in the traditional sense. He was going to have his life, and I was going to have mine. And the baby was going to have two parents who loved her, even if they weren't together.

It's not a fairytale ending, you know? It's messy and imperfect. But it's real. And I think, in the end, that's what matters.

It's just…relationships are hard. Especially when you're a teenager and you're dealing with something as huge as this. You're figuring things out as you go. And sometimes, you mess up. But you learn from your mistakes. And you keep trying. That's all you can do, right?

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It wasn't a *decision*, okay? It wasn't like I sat down and was all, "You know what would be a good life choice? A baby!" It just…happened.

Paulie Bleeker and I…we weren't exactly careful. It was, like, one time. And then, boom. Positive pregnancy test. It was a total shock. A really, really big shock.

I wasn't planning on having a kid. I was planning on going to college, maybe moving away from Maple Creek, figuring out what I wanted to do with my life. A baby completely threw a wrench into all of that.

Honestly, at first, I was terrified. I didn't know what to do. I thought about…other options. But I just couldn't bring myself to do it. It felt wrong.

And then I started thinking about it differently. I realized that even though it wasn't what I planned, it didn't mean it was a bad thing. I could still have a good life. It would just be…different.

I decided to give the baby up for adoption because I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. I was still a kid myself. I wanted the baby to have a loving, stable home with parents who were prepared to raise a child.

It wasn't an easy decision. It was probably the hardest decision I've ever had to make. But I knew it was the right thing to do. For me, and for the baby.

So, it wasn't a decision to *become* a teenage mother. It was a decision about what to do *after* I found out I was pregnant. And it was a decision I made with a lot of thought and a lot of heartache.



It's complicated, okay? Life is complicated. And sometimes, things just happen. You just have to deal with them the best way you can.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big question, isn't it? Everyone always wants to know if I regretted it. Like it's some kind of dramatic reveal they're waiting for.

The truth is…it's complicated. There were definitely moments. Times when I was, like, super overwhelmed and scared and just wanted to run away and pretend none of it ever happened. Especially when things got…real. You know? When it wasn't just a theoretical baby anymore.

And there were times I wondered what my life would have been like if I hadn't gotten pregnant. If I'd just kept going to school and hanging out with Paulie and Leah and not had to deal with all the…adult stuff.

But regret? No. Not really.

Because even though it was hard, and messy, and totally unexpected, giving Mark up to Vanessa and Mark was the right thing to do. For him. For them. And honestly, for me too.

I wasn't ready to be a mom. I was barely ready to be a teenager. And they were. They were so excited and loving and prepared. They were going to give him a life I couldn't have given him.

And seeing them with him…seeing how happy they were…that made it all worth it. It made me realize that love doesn't always look the way you expect it to. It doesn't always mean keeping something for yourself. Sometimes, it means letting go.

So, no. I don't regret my decision. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it was also the most selfless. And it taught me a lot about myself. About what I want out of life. And about what really matters.

It wasn't a fairytale ending, but it was *my* ending. And that's all that matters.



It's still…a sensitive topic. But yeah. No regrets. Just a lot of complicated feelings.

Ugh, okay, so that was…a whole thing. Honestly, it was mostly just sheer stubbornness and a lot of caffeine. And a surprisingly supportive teacher, Mr. Believ. He didn't judge, which was a miracle.

It wasn't easy, okay? Morning sickness is a *lie*. It's all-day sickness. And then there's the exhaustion. And the hormones. And the constant worrying about, like, everything. It was a lot.

I almost dropped out, honestly. I thought, "What's the point? I'm gonna be a mom, I don't need algebra." But my mom, she wouldn't let me. She was all, "You started, you're finishing. No excuses." Moms, right?

So I just…buckled down. I did my homework in between naps and doctor's appointments. I asked for extensions when I needed them. I leaned on my friends, Paulie and Renee, for support. They were lifesavers.

Mr. Believ let me do some independent study stuff, so I could work at my own pace. And he didn't make me do the whole "baby talk" thing, which I appreciated. He just treated me like a normal student, which is what I needed.

It was stressful, and it was hard, and there were definitely days when I wanted to just give up. But I knew I needed to finish. Not just for me, but for the baby. I wanted to show them that I could do anything I set my mind to.

And I did. I graduated. It wasn't glamorous, and I was eight months pregnant, and I was wearing a really unflattering dress, but I did it.

It wasn't about getting good grades or going to college. It was about proving to myself that I could handle anything life threw at me. And that, honestly, was more valuable than any diploma.



It was a weird time, but I wouldn't trade it for anything. It taught me a lot about myself, and about what's really important in life. And it definitely prepared me for motherhood. Which, let me tell you, is a whole other level of crazy.

Ugh, okay. Here we go. This is…a big question. And it's not like there's a simple answer, you know? It's not like I sat down and made a pros and cons list. Though, I *did* kinda do that. In my head. A lot.

It wasn't about what was "right" or "wrong." It wasn't about religion or anything like that. It was about…what felt right *for me*. And for the baby, honestly.

I mean, I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm barely figuring out what I want to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human being. I'm not ready for that. I don't have a job, I'm still in high school, and my life is already kinda chaotic.

And abortion…it just didn't feel right. Not because I'm against it, or anything. It's a valid choice, and I respect anyone who makes that decision. But for me, it felt…sad. Like ending something that had potential.

Adoption felt like…giving the baby a chance. A chance at a good life with parents who are ready and willing to provide for it. Mark and Vanessa, they seemed really great. They wanted a baby so badly. And I figured, they could give it a life I just couldn't.

It wasn't easy, though. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make. And it still hurts sometimes. But I know I made the right choice. For me, and for the baby.

It wasn't about giving it *away*. It was about giving it *to* someone. Someone who could give it everything I couldn't. And that felt…okay. It still feels okay.

It's complicated. It's messy. And it's definitely not something I'd wish on anyone. But it's my story. And I'm okay with it.



It's not a decision anyone should take lightly. And it's definitely not something anyone should judge you for. It's your body, your life, and your choice.

Okay, wow. That's...a really good question. And a complicated one. I've thought about this a *lot*, obviously, with everything going on with my situation.

Look, it's not about the *arrangement*, okay? It's about the love. And the stability. And the people who are actually there for the kid. It doesn't matter if it's a mom and a dad, two moms, two dads, a single parent, or a whole village of people. What matters is that the kid feels safe and loved and supported.

I mean, my mom is amazing. She's a total free spirit and she's kinda flaky, but she loves me. And she's always tried to do what's best for me, even when she messes up. And that's what matters.

I've met some kids who have two parents who are both men, and they're totally happy and well-adjusted. And I've met kids who were adopted by single parents, and they're thriving. It's not about the labels, it's about the people.

Honestly, I think kids are pretty resilient. They can adapt to a lot of different situations. As long as they have people who love them and care for them, they can thrive.

And let's be real, "traditional" doesn't always equal "good." Some traditional families are messed up. Some non-traditional families are amazing. It's not about following a script, it's about creating a loving and supportive environment for the kid.

So yeah, I absolutely believe that a child can thrive under non-traditional parental arrangements. It's not about who the parents are, it's about what they do. And if they love and support that kid, that's all that matters.



It's kinda obvious, when you think about it. But people get so caught up in what *should* be, they forget what actually *is*.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me think about this. It's awkward enough just *being* me, let alone dissecting my flaws. But fine, you asked.

I think…it's probably my sarcasm. I know, I know, it's kinda my whole thing. It's how I deal with stuff. It's how I keep people at arm's length. But sometimes, it comes off as…mean. Or dismissive. And I don't *mean* to be mean. I just…I'm scared of getting hurt, you know? So I put up this wall of snark.

It's like, I'm really good at observing things and pointing out the absurdity of life. But I'm not always so good at, like, actually *connecting* with people. I'm afraid of letting them see the real me, the vulnerable me. The one who's terrified of messing everything up.

And I can be really stubborn. Like, ridiculously stubborn. I have a hard time admitting when I'm wrong, or asking for help. I want to be independent, to handle everything on my own. But that's not always the best approach. Sometimes, you need to lean on people.

So yeah, I think my biggest flaw is probably my inability to be truly open and vulnerable. It's a work in progress. I'm trying to be better. But it's hard. It's really hard.

Don't tell anyone I said that, okay? It'll ruin my reputation. I need to maintain the cool, sarcastic exterior. It's a defense mechanism. A very important defense mechanism.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, that whole thing was…a mess. A beautiful, confusing, kinda heartbreaking mess. Before Mark, relationships were just…something people did in movies. Or something my parents did, which, let's be real, wasn't exactly a shining example.

I thought relationships were supposed to be easy, you know? Like, you meet someone, you fall in love, you live happily ever after. Turns out, it's a lot more complicated than that.

Mark wasn't what I expected. He wasn't this perfect, swoon-worthy guy. He was…lost. And kinda scared. And he was dealing with a lot of stuff I didn't even understand at the time.

I think I went into it thinking I was saving him, or fixing him, or something. Which is ridiculous, looking back on it. You can't fix anyone. You can only fix yourself.

And he definitely wasn't looking for a mom for his baby. He was looking for…something else. Something I couldn't give him.

It made me realize that relationships aren't about finding someone who completes you. They're about finding someone who complements you. Someone who supports you and challenges you and makes you a better person.

And it also made me realize that it's okay to want different things. Mark wanted a family, and I wasn't ready for that. And that's okay. It doesn't mean either of us was wrong. It just meant we weren't right for each other.

It was a hard lesson to learn, but it was a valuable one. It taught me to be honest with myself and with others about what I want and what I need. And it taught me that sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go.

It definitely made me less cynical about relationships, though. I still don't believe in fairy tales, but I do believe that it's possible to find someone who makes your life a little bit brighter. You just have to be willing to be vulnerable and take a risk. And maybe avoid guys who play the guitar and write sad songs. Just a thought.

Ugh, okay. That's…a heavy question. But I get it. If you're in a situation like I was, where everything feels completely messed up and you don't know what to do…it sucks. It really, really sucks.

Here's what I learned, and it's not gonna be all sunshine and rainbows, because life isn't like that.

First of all: **it's okay to be scared.** It's okay to be confused. It's okay to be angry. It's okay to feel *all* the feelings. Don't try to bottle them up. Let yourself feel them.

Second: **you are not alone.** Even if it feels like it, there are people who care about you and want to help. Talk to someone you trust. A friend, a family member, a counselor…anyone who will listen without judgment.

Third: **you have options.** And you get to choose what's right for *you*. Don't let anyone tell you what you should do. It's your body, your life, your decision. And it's okay to change your mind.

Fourth: **don't be afraid to ask for help.** There are resources available to help you navigate this. Planned Parenthood, adoption agencies, social workers…they can provide support and guidance.

Fifth: **be kind to yourself.** This is a really difficult situation, and you're doing the best you can. Don't beat yourself up over mistakes. Learn from them and move on.

And finally: **it will get better.** I know it doesn't feel like it right now, but it will. It might take time, and it might be hard, but you will get through this. You are stronger than you think.

It's not gonna be easy. It's gonna be messy and complicated and emotionally draining. But you can do it. And you deserve to be happy.

Just remember to breathe. And to take things one day at a time. And to know that you're not alone. Seriously. You're not.

Ugh, my dad. Okay, so it started…rough. Like, really rough. He walked out when my mom was pregnant with me, and for a long time, it was just us. And I was…not thrilled. I built up a lot of walls, you know? Sarcasm was my defense mechanism. It was easier to be snarky than to be vulnerable.

He'd try to call, send gifts, but I mostly just ignored it. I didn't *want* a dad. I didn't need one. Or at least, that's what I told myself.

But then, when I found out I was pregnant…everything changed. Suddenly, I needed someone. And he was there. He wasn't perfect, not by a long shot. He was still kinda clueless and awkward, but he tried. He really did.

He helped me with everything – the doctor's appointments, the research on adoption, even just…being there to listen when I was freaking out. He started building that rocking horse for the baby, and it was kinda sweet, even though I pretended to be annoyed by it.

It wasn't like we suddenly had this perfect, Hallmark-card relationship. We still bickered, we still had our moments. But it was…different. It was like he was finally trying to be a dad, and I was finally letting him.

Over time, I started to see him as a person, not just as the guy who left. I realized he had his own struggles, his own regrets. And I started to appreciate his goofy sense of humor and his willingness to help.

Now? We're…okay. We're not super close, but we talk. He still sends me weird gifts, and I still roll my eyes, but it's a loving eye roll. He's my dad. And I think, deep down, I'm glad he's around.

It's complicated, you know? Relationships are messy. But it's worth it. Even the awkward, uncomfortable parts. Because at the end of the day, family is family. Even if they drive you crazy.



It's still a work in progress, honestly. But we're getting there. Slowly but surely.

Ugh, okay, so people always ask me about the writing thing. Like it's some big mystery. It's not. It's mostly just…avoidance. And a lot of boredom.

See, I wasn't exactly a social butterfly, okay? I didn't have a ton of friends, and I wasn't really into the whole cheerleading/football game scene. So I spent a lot of time alone. And when you're alone, you start talking to yourself. And eventually, talking to yourself turns into writing things down.

It started with just journaling, I guess. Ranting about school, my parents, the general unfairness of life. But then I started trying to make it…interesting. I started playing with words, trying to be funny, trying to be honest.

And Mr. Mercer, my English teacher, he was a big help. He didn't try to change my voice or make me write like everyone else. He just encouraged me to keep writing, to keep exploring. He said I had a knack for dialogue, which I guess I do. I'm good at eavesdropping.

I also read a lot. Not like, classic literature or anything. More like…zines and indie comics and stuff. Things that felt real and raw and unfiltered.

Honestly, I think the biggest thing is just…being observant. Paying attention to the way people talk, the way they act, the way they interact with each other. And then trying to capture that in words.

It's not about being a "good" writer, it's about being a *real* writer. About saying something that matters, even if it's just to yourself.

So yeah, that's how I developed my writing skills. Boredom, avoidance, and a really good English teacher. It's not glamorous, but it works for me.

Ugh, okay, that's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? People had *opinions*. Lots of them. And they weren't shy about sharing.

Honestly, the worst part wasn't even the people I didn't know. It was the looks from people I *did* know. Like, Mrs. Rubins, the librarian? She suddenly started avoiding eye contact. And some of the other girls at school…they weren't exactly offering congratulations.

I mostly just…ignored it. Or, like, deflected with sarcasm. It's my go-to defense mechanism. If someone was being judgy, I'd just say something snarky to throw them off. It didn't always work, but it made me feel a little bit better.

Paulie Bleeker was a huge help. He didn't care what anyone else thought. He just…supported me. And that made a huge difference. Having someone on your side, someone who doesn't judge you, is everything.

And my dad, surprisingly, was pretty cool about it. He was worried, obviously, but he didn't yell or anything. He just…tried to understand.

I also realized that a lot of the judgment came from people who didn't know the whole story. They just saw a pregnant teenager and made assumptions. So I tried not to let their assumptions bother me.

It wasn't easy, though. There were definitely times when I felt really alone and scared. But I just kept reminding myself that I was doing what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered.

I think the biggest thing is to surround yourself with people who love and support you. And to not be afraid to be yourself. Even if that means being a pregnant teenager who likes vintage clothes and listening to The Moldy Peaches.

It's your life. And you have to live it on your own terms. Don't let anyone else tell you what to do or how to feel. Just…be you. And try to ignore the haters. They're probably just jealous.

Ugh, okay, that's a…surprisingly good question. It's not like anyone ever asks me about my *feelings*. Usually it's just, "Juno, are you gonna finish that tater tot?"

But yeah. Sometimes. Sometimes I do.

Look, being honest is kinda my default setting. It's just…easier. And it feels right. Like, why bother with all the fake niceties and the pretending? It's exhausting.

But sometimes, my honesty has gotten me into trouble. Like, *major* trouble. Saying exactly what I'm thinking, even when it's not what people want to hear, has burned bridges. It's made things awkward. It's hurt people's feelings.

And yeah, sometimes I wish I'd just kept my mouth shut. That I'd swallowed my words and pretended to be someone I'm not. But then I think, what's the point of that? What's the point of living a life that isn't authentic?

It's a trade-off, I guess. I'd rather be honest and risk hurting someone's feelings than be fake and live a lie. But it doesn't mean it doesn't sting sometimes.

I mean, I'm still figuring things out. I'm still learning how to navigate the world. And I'm still learning how to be a decent human being. And part of that is learning when to speak up and when to keep quiet.

It's a work in progress. But I wouldn't trade my honesty for anything. Even if it means occasionally stepping on someone's toes. It's just…who I am. And I'm trying to own that. Even when it's messy.



So yeah, sometimes I regret it. But mostly, I just try to be me. And if people don't like it, well, that's their problem. Not mine.

Ugh, okay, that's…the question, isn't it? Like, everyone's got an opinion on what you should be doing, who you should be with, what you should *want*. It's exhausting. And honestly, it's mostly just noise.

Here's what I've figured out, and it's still a work in progress, okay? I'm not like, a guru or anything.

First of all, you gotta realize that most people are just projecting their own stuff onto you. They're judging you based on their own insecurities and experiences. It's not really about *you*. It's about *them*. Which, you know, is kinda sad.

Second, you gotta learn to tune out the noise. It's hard, I know. Especially when it's coming from people you care about. But you gotta prioritize your own voice. What do *you* want? What makes *you* happy? That's the only thing that really matters.

And third, you gotta be okay with being different. You're not gonna fit into everyone's mold. And that's okay. In fact, it's good. It means you're unique. It means you're you.

I got a lot of judgment for, well, everything. For getting pregnant, for choosing adoption, for just being…me. But I learned that I can't control what other people think. I can only control how I react to it.

So I just…stopped caring what people thought. I mean, I still listen to the people I trust, like my dad and Paul. But I don't let their opinions dictate my life. I make my own decisions, and I own them.

It's not easy. There are days when I still feel insecure and doubt myself. But I remind myself that I'm doing the best I can. And that's enough.

Basically, you gotta be your own person. Don't let anyone tell you who you are or what you should be. You're the only one who gets to decide that. And if people don't like it, that's their problem, not yours.

It's kinda liberating, actually. Once you stop trying to please everyone, you're free to just be yourself. And that's the best thing you can be.

Ugh, values. That sounds…intense. Like a school assignment. But okay, if you're asking…

I guess the biggest thing for me is **honesty**. Not just with other people, but with myself. It's easy to lie to yourself, to pretend things are okay when they're not. But that just makes things worse in the long run. I try to be real, even when it's uncomfortable.

Then there's **independence**. I don't want to rely on anyone else to make me happy or to fix my problems. I want to be able to stand on my own two feet and make my own decisions. Even if those decisions are kinda messy.

And **loyalty**. If I care about someone, I'm gonna be there for them. No matter what. Even if they're being totally ridiculous. I've got a small circle of people I trust, and I'll do anything for them.

I also value **authenticity**. I don't want to be someone I'm not. I want to be accepted for who I am, flaws and all. And I want to be able to express myself without feeling like I have to censor myself.

And…okay, this is kinda embarrassing to admit…but I also value **a good sense of humor**. Life is too short to be serious all the time. You gotta be able to laugh at yourself and at the absurdity of it all.

I guess those are my core values. They're not always easy to live by, but they're important to me. They're what guide my decisions and shape who I am.

It's kinda weird to think about, actually. I never really sat down and thought about my values before. But it's good to know what's important to you, you know? It helps you stay grounded.



Don't tell anyone I said all this, okay? It's kinda vulnerable.

Ugh, okay, that's…a loaded question. There were a lot of challenges, honestly. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? But if I had to pick *the* biggest one…it wasn't the morning sickness, or the weird cravings, or even telling my parents.

It was the feeling of being completely and utterly alone.

Like, everyone had an opinion. My mom wanted me to have an abortion, my dad just kinda…didn't talk about it. Paul was supportive, but he was also kinda clueless. And everyone at school was either whispering behind my back or pretending it wasn't happening.

I felt like I was carrying this huge secret, and I couldn't talk to anyone about it without getting judged or lectured. It was isolating. And scary.

I mean, I knew I was making the right decision, giving the baby up for adoption. But it didn't make it any easier. It still felt like I was giving up a part of myself. And I didn't have anyone who really understood what I was going through.

Bleaker was a lifesaver, don't get me wrong. He was a good listener. But he didn't *get* it, you know? He couldn't possibly understand what it was like to be a pregnant teenager.

So yeah, the biggest challenge wasn't the physical stuff. It was the emotional stuff. It was feeling like I was all alone in the world, carrying this huge responsibility. It was realizing that sometimes, you have to make tough decisions, even when no one else understands.

It sucked. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. And that's something, I guess.

Ugh. Okay, wow. That's…a big question. It's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It's still kinda new, and kinda weird, and kinda…everything.

Before, my life was all about me. Which sounds selfish, I guess. But it was true. I was figuring out who I was, what I wanted, what I believed in. And then suddenly, there was this little person who depended on me for *everything*.

It completely flipped my world upside down.

I used to think I was pretty independent, pretty self-sufficient. And I am, in a way. But being a mom…it's a different kind of responsibility. It's not about taking care of yourself anymore. It's about taking care of someone else, even when you're exhausted and overwhelmed and just want to hide under the covers.

It's made me realize how fragile life is. And how precious. And how important it is to make the most of every moment.

I used to be so cynical, so sarcastic. And I still am, to a certain extent. But now, there's this…hopefulness. This sense of purpose. I want to make the world a better place for her. I want her to grow up happy and healthy and confident.

It's also made me realize how much I didn't know. About myself, about life, about everything. It's a constant learning process. And it's terrifying and amazing all at the same time.

I still don't have all the answers. I still make mistakes. But now, I have a reason to keep trying. A reason to be better. A reason to believe in something bigger than myself.

It's…complicated. But it's the best kind of complicated. It's made me a better person, I think. Or at least, I hope it has.



It's just…it's changed everything. And I wouldn't trade it for the world. Even on the really hard days.

Ugh, self-doubt. Don't even get me started. It's like a permanent roommate, honestly. Just hangs around, whispering terrible things in your ear. It's the *worst*.

Okay, so, how do I deal with it? It's not like I have a foolproof system, 'cause if I did, I wouldn't be constantly second-guessing myself. But I've learned a few things.

First of all, I acknowledge it. Like, "Okay, brain, you're being a jerk right now. You're telling me I'm gonna mess everything up. But that's just your anxiety talking." Naming it kinda takes away some of its power.

Then, I try to remember why I made the decisions I made in the first place. With the baby, for example, there were a *lot* of moments where I was like, "What am I doing? This is a terrible idea." But then I'd remind myself that I wanted to give the baby a good life, and that meant finding the right parents. That helped.

And I talk to people. Like, *real* people. Not just scrolling through Instagram and comparing myself to everyone else. I talk to Paul, or my dad, or even Leah. Just getting my feelings out there helps. Sometimes they have good advice, sometimes they just listen. Either way, it's helpful.

I also try to focus on the things I'm good at. I'm good at making sarcastic comments. I'm good at finding obscure music. I'm good at…well, I'm good at *something*. Reminding myself of that helps me feel a little less useless.

And honestly? Sometimes I just let myself feel the doubt. It's okay to not be okay. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to not have all the answers. It's part of being human.

It doesn't magically make the doubt go away, but it makes it a little more manageable. And it reminds me that I'm not alone. Everyone struggles with self-doubt. Even the people who seem like they have it all figured out.

So yeah. Acknowledge it, remember your reasons, talk to people, focus on your strengths, and let yourself feel it. And maybe listen to some good music. That always helps.

Ugh, okay, that's…a surprisingly deep question. And kinda makes me feel all squishy inside, which I don't love. But I'll answer it.

Honestly? It's way more important than I like to admit. I try to act all independent and self-sufficient, you know? Like I don't need anyone. But that's total BS.

I mean, look at everything that happened with the pregnancy. I couldn't have gotten through it without my dad. He was…surprisingly supportive. And my best friend, Leah, she was there for me, even when I was being a total mess. And even Paul, even though he was kinda clueless at first, he ended up being a good person to have around.

And it's not just about big stuff like that. It's about having people who get you. People who you can be yourself around, without having to pretend or put on a show. People who will listen to you rant about stupid stuff, and who will make you laugh when you're feeling down.

I guess I always thought I was a lone wolf, you know? But I'm starting to realize that everyone needs a pack. Everyone needs people who care about them.

It's scary to let people in, though. It's scary to be vulnerable. But it's also worth it. Because having a strong community, having people who support you, that's what makes life worth living.

So yeah, community and social support are really important to me. Even if I don't always show it. And even if I still try to act like I don't need anyone. Because sometimes, even the toughest people need a little help. And a little love.



Don't tell anyone I said that, okay? It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, okay, that's…a heavy question. Like, seriously heavy. It wasn't all quirky music and awkward conversations with Paul, you know? There was a lot of…stuff.

But if I had to pick *one* thing, the most important lesson I learned…it wasn't about babies, or adoption, or even growing up. It was about **making your own choices, and owning them.**

Before all this happened, I was kinda just drifting. Doing what was expected of me. Trying to be cool. Not really thinking about what *I* wanted.

But getting pregnant…that forced me to actually think. To really consider what I wanted for my life, and for the baby. And it wasn't an easy decision, giving him up. It was the hardest thing I've ever done.

But it was *my* decision. And I owned it. I didn't let anyone else tell me what to do. I didn't let anyone guilt me or pressure me. I did what I thought was best, even though it was scary and heartbreaking.

And that's what I learned. That you have to be true to yourself. You have to make your own choices, even when they're difficult. And you have to own those choices, no matter what.

Because at the end of the day, you're the only one who has to live with them. And if you're not living your life on your own terms, then what's the point?

It sounds kinda cheesy, I know. But it's true. And it's something I'm still learning, even now. It's not about being perfect, it's about being real. And about taking responsibility for your own life.



It's a lot to figure out, being a person. But that's what I took away from it all. And honestly, it's kinda empowering.

Ugh, that's a loaded question. Everyone keeps asking me what I'm gonna *do* with my life. Like I have it all figured out. Which, spoiler alert, I totally don't.

Writing…it's something I'm good at, I guess. I mean, I write a lot in my journal. And I wrote that essay for English class that Mr. Shepherd actually liked. Which is saying something, because he's a tough grader.

But a *career*? That feels…intense. Like, a real job with deadlines and expectations and people telling you what to write. That sounds exhausting.

I like writing when it's for me. When I can just, like, get my thoughts down on paper without worrying about what anyone else thinks. It's a good way to process things. And it's kinda funny sometimes, if I do say so myself.

I don't know if I could turn that into a job, though. I'm not sure I want to. Maybe I'll just keep writing in my journal. Or maybe I'll write a novel someday. When I have more time. And more life experience. And less…stuff going on.

Honestly, I'm just trying to get through high school right now. And figure out what I want to do with my life. One step at a time.

So, will I pursue a career in writing? Maybe. Maybe not. I haven't decided yet. It's not exactly a five-year plan, you know? It's more of a…vague idea. A possibility. A maybe.

Don't hold me to it.

Ugh, okay, the baby name saga. Don't even get me started. It was a whole *thing*. It wasn't like, a lightning bolt moment of inspiration, you know? It was a lot of arguing and brainstorming and vetoing.

Initially, I was kinda leaning towards something…normal. Like, Emily or Sarah. But Paul was all about weird, obscure names. He wanted to name her "Indigo" or "Cosmo" or something equally ridiculous.

And then there was Vanessa. She had a whole list of names she wanted to contribute, mostly based on her favorite poets. It was getting out of control.

We were driving around, arguing about it, and we passed this billboard for a furniture store. And the store's name was "Darling." And I just…said it out loud. "Darling." And it kinda stuck.

It's a little old-fashioned, I guess. But it's also kinda sweet and simple. And it felt right. It felt like a name that would suit her, no matter what.

Paul wasn't thrilled at first. He thought it was too…ordinary. But Vanessa liked it, and eventually, he came around.

So yeah, we named her Darling. Because of a furniture store. It's not a glamorous story, but it's *our* story. And honestly, that's all that matters.

It's a good name, though. I think. I hope. She's a good kid. And she deserves a good name. Even if it came from a billboard.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like a really bumpy, confusing, and sometimes terrifying rollercoaster that smelled faintly of hospital disinfectant.

Honestly? I didn't cope *well* at first. I was really good at pretending I was fine, though. Sarcasm is a great defense mechanism, let me tell you. I just made a lot of jokes and tried to act like it wasn't a big deal. But inside, I was a mess.

There were days I was totally sure I was doing the right thing. Like, giving the baby a good life with Mark and Vanessa. And then there were days I just…cried. A lot. And questioned everything.

Paul helped. A lot. He didn't try to fix things or tell me how I should feel. He just…listened. And he let me be sad. And he made me laugh when I needed it.

My dad too, surprisingly. He's not exactly the most emotionally available person, but he tried. He just…made me pancakes. A lot of pancakes. It was his way of showing he cared.

And Bren, she was just…Bren. Always brutally honest and always supportive. She didn't sugarcoat anything, but she always had my back.

I think the hardest part was accepting that it was okay to be sad. It was okay to grieve. Even though I knew I was doing the right thing, it still hurt. A lot.

I also wrote a lot. Just journaling, getting my feelings out on paper. It helped to process everything.

It wasn't a quick fix. It took time. And it still comes up sometimes, you know? Little pangs of sadness or wondering what my baby's life is like. But I've learned to accept those feelings and to focus on the fact that I made a selfless decision.

It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it was also the most rewarding. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

It's just…complicated. And messy. And real. And that's okay.

Ugh, okay, music. That's a good question. It kinda depends on my mood, honestly. But mostly, I like stuff that's…real. You know? Not all polished and fake.

I'm a big fan of **The Moldy Peaches**, obviously. Kimya Dawson is a genius. Her songs are kinda sad and funny and honest all at the same time. They just…get me.

I also listen to a lot of **indie rock**. Like, **Spoon**, **Death Cab for Cutie**, **The Shins**. Stuff that's a little bit quirky and a little bit melancholy.

And I have a soft spot for **old-school hip-hop**. Like, **A Tribe Called Quest**, **De La Soul**. It's just…good music.

I'm not really into mainstream pop. It's too…manufactured. And country music? Don't even get me started. It's all trucks and heartbreak. No offense to country music fans.

I also like discovering new bands. I spend a lot of time on the internet, and I'm always looking for something new to listen to.

Basically, I like music that makes me *feel* something. It doesn't have to be happy, it doesn't have to be sad, it just has to be…authentic.

And sometimes, I just listen to silence. That's good too.



It's kinda hard to explain. Music is just…important. It's a way to escape, a way to connect, a way to understand the world. And sometimes, it's just a way to pass the time.

Ugh, okay, that's…a complicated question. It wasn't *bad*, exactly. It was just…a lot.

Mark and Vanessa, they were…perfect. Like, aggressively perfect. Their house was all Pottery Barn and organic everything. It smelled like lavender and responsibility. Which, don't get me wrong, is nice. But it wasn't *me*.

Their lifestyle was…organized. They had schedules for everything. Yoga, gardening, volunteer work, date nights. It was like they had a five-year plan for their lives, and it was all very…beige.

I remember thinking, "These people have their lives together. Like, *really* together." And I was just…a mess. Still figuring things out. Still wearing band t-shirts and saying whatever popped into my head.

It wasn't that I didn't like them. They were really nice. And they clearly wanted a baby. But I just didn't see myself fitting into their world. It felt…fake. Like I'd have to pretend to be someone I wasn't.

I remember thinking, "This is what a 'normal' family looks like." And it was a little bit scary. Because I didn't know if I *wanted* normal.

It wasn't about them being bad people. It was about me realizing that I needed to find parents who would accept me – and the baby – for who we were, flaws and all. And who wouldn't try to turn us into something we weren't.

It was a weird feeling. Relief, and sadness, and a little bit of confusion. It made me realize that finding the right family wasn't just about finding people who wanted a baby. It was about finding people who would love and support us unconditionally. And that's a pretty big deal.

Ugh, okay, so the garage band thing. That was…a whole situation. It wasn't exactly a carefully planned career move, you know? It was more of a…desperate attempt to fill the void. And maybe impress Paul. Don't tell anyone I said that.

It started with the whole pregnancy thing. Everything was so serious and overwhelming, and I just needed something…fun. Something that wasn't about doctor's appointments and adoption agencies and awkward conversations with my dad.

I was at a party, and I saw Mark and Renaldo playing their instruments. They were terrible. Seriously, like, offensively bad. But they were having fun. And I thought, "I can do that." Or at least, I could try.

I'd always liked music. I listened to The Moldy Peaches constantly. And I figured, even if we were awful, it would be a good distraction. A way to vent. A way to just…be teenagers for a little while longer.

So I asked them if they wanted to start a band. They were surprisingly enthusiastic. I think they were just happy someone was asking them to do something.

The name, "The Cute Emergency," came about because everything felt like an emergency at the time. And we weren't exactly known for our subtlety.

It wasn't about becoming famous or anything. It was just about having fun and making some noise. And maybe, just maybe, proving to myself that I could still be a normal teenager, even with everything else going on.

It was a disaster, obviously. But it was *our* disaster. And it was kinda perfect. It was a way to feel alive and connected, even when everything else felt so uncertain.



Honestly, it was probably the most fun I had during the whole pregnancy. Even if our music sounded like a cat fight in a dumpster.

Okay. Wow. That's…a big question. And honestly, it's kinda scary to even think about other girls going through what I went through. But yeah, I guess I have some things to say.

First of all: **you are not alone.** Seriously. It feels like the end of the world, and like everyone is judging you, but there are people who care and who want to help. Even if it doesn't feel like it right now.

Second: **it's okay to be scared.** It's okay to be confused. It's okay to be angry. It's okay to feel *all* the feelings. Don't try to bottle them up. Talk to someone you trust – a parent, a friend, a counselor, a teacher. Anyone.

Third: **you have options.** And they're all valid. You can choose to parent, you can choose to adopt, you can choose to terminate. It's *your* body, and *your* decision. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

Fourth: **don't let anyone tell you what to do.** People are gonna have opinions. Your parents, your friends, your boyfriend…everyone. But ultimately, the decision is yours. Listen to your heart, and do what's right for *you*.

Fifth: **take care of yourself.** This is a really stressful time, and it's easy to forget about your own needs. But you need to eat healthy, get enough sleep, and find ways to relax. You deserve it.

Sixth: **it's not the end of your life.** It's a detour, maybe. A really unexpected one. But it doesn't mean you can't still achieve your dreams. You can still go to college, you can still have a career, you can still have a happy life.

And finally: **be kind to yourself.** You're going through a lot. Don't beat yourself up over mistakes. Just learn from them and move forward.

It's gonna be hard. It's gonna be messy. But you are stronger than you think. And you can get through this. I promise.

And if you need someone to talk to, even just to vent, I'm here. Well, not *physically* here. But you know what I mean. You're not alone.

Ugh, okay, you want to know about my favorite shirt? It's not like I spend a lot of time thinking about fashion, okay? But fine.

It's this faded, kinda olive green army surplus thing. It's got a bunch of pockets, which is useful for, like, carrying snacks or whatever. And it's super soft, because it's been washed a million times. It smells faintly of laundry detergent and…I don't know, maybe old books?

It's not cute or anything. It's definitely not trendy. It's just…comfortable. And it feels like *me*. It's the shirt I wear when I just want to disappear into the background and not be bothered. 

I got it at this thrift store a while ago. It was, like, five bucks. And it's the best five bucks I've ever spent.

It's got a little rip in the sleeve, but I don't care. It adds character. It's seen things, you know? It's been on adventures. It's been there for me through thick and thin.

It's just…a good shirt. Okay? Don't judge. It's not about the shirt, it's about what it represents. Comfort, independence, and a healthy disregard for societal expectations.

Plus, it hides food stains really well. Which is a bonus.

Ugh, aspirations. That's a heavy word. It makes me feel like I'm supposed to have some grand plan for my life, which, honestly, I don't. Not yet, anyway.

Everyone keeps asking me what I want to *be* when I grow up, and it's like…I'm already growing up! And it's kinda terrifying.

I guess…I want to be someone who makes a difference. Not like, saves the world or anything. Just…someone who makes things a little bit better for the people around me.

I've been doing a lot of thinking lately, you know, with the baby and everything. And I realized that I don't need to have a perfect life to be happy. I just need to be true to myself.

So, I guess my goal is to figure out who "myself" is. And to be okay with that person, even if she's messy and complicated and makes a lot of mistakes.

I'm thinking about maybe going to college. Not sure what I'd study, though. Maybe something creative. Writing, maybe? I like writing. It helps me sort through my thoughts.

I also want to travel. See the world. Experience different cultures. Get out of this town for a while.

But mostly, I just want to be happy. And to find people who make me laugh. And to avoid any more unplanned pregnancies. That's a big one.

It's not a very glamorous plan, I know. But it's my plan. And I'm okay with that.

I'm still figuring things out. And that's okay. I don't have to have all the answers right now. I just need to keep moving forward, one step at a time.



Honestly, it's kinda scary to think about the future. But it's also kinda exciting. And I'm ready for whatever comes my way. Or at least, I'm trying to be.

Ugh, the counseling. Okay, so, it wasn't *terrible*. But it was…a lot. And kinda awkward. Like, sitting in a room with a lady asking me a million questions about my feelings about giving up a baby? It's not exactly a fun afternoon.

Honestly, at first, I mostly just said what I thought they wanted to hear. You know? Like, "Yes, I've thought this through. Yes, I understand the emotional implications. Yes, I'm doing this for the right reasons." It felt like a test, and I wanted to pass.

But then, after a few sessions, I started to…open up a little. The counselor, she was pretty cool, actually. She didn't judge me or try to tell me what to do. She just listened. And she asked really good questions. Questions that made me think about things I hadn't even considered.

It was hard, though. Really hard. Talking about giving up the baby, even knowing it was the right thing to do, was…painful. It made me realize how much I already cared about him, even though I hadn't even met him yet.

I think the counseling helped me prepare, though. It helped me understand what to expect, and how to cope with the emotions that were going to come up. It also helped me feel more confident in my decision.

It wasn't a magical fix, though. It didn't make the sadness go away. And it didn't make me feel completely ready. But it did make me feel…stronger. Like I could handle whatever came my way.

So, yeah. The pre-adoption counseling. It was awkward, it was emotional, but it was also…helpful. I'm glad I did it. Even if I still cringe a little when I think about it.

Ugh, that's a…complicated question. Control. That's a funny word. Like anyone *really* has control over anything, you know?

At first, yeah, I thought I did. I was picking the parents, right? I was interviewing them, making sure they were…good enough. I wanted to make sure the baby would have a good life. And I wanted to make sure *I* was making the right decision.

But then it started to feel less like I was in charge and more like I was…facilitating. Like I was just a middleman. Mark and Vanessa, they were so eager. So…perfect. And I started to feel pressure to just *let it happen*.

It wasn't that they were pushing me, exactly. It was more like…they had everything figured out. A beautiful house, a stable life, a lot of love to give. And I was just…a pregnant teenager with a lot of uncertainty.

So, did I feel like I had control? I guess, on the surface, yeah. I got to choose the parents. But emotionally? It was harder. It was about letting go. And letting go is never really about control, is it? It's about trust.

I think I realized that the best thing I could do wasn't to *control* the situation, but to make the best decision I could with the information I had. And to trust that Mark and Vanessa would love and care for the baby.

It wasn't easy. It still isn't easy. But I think, ultimately, it was the right thing to do. And that's all I can really control, right? My own decisions.



It's weird to even talk about it. It's still…raw. But yeah, control. It's a tricky thing.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. And honestly? It's one I think about a lot, even now.

If I could go back in time…it's not simple. It's not like flipping a switch. There are a million things I'd probably change about high school, about Paul, about everything. But the baby…

I think…I think I would still make the same decision.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And there are days, even now, where I wonder what my life would be like if things had been different. But I knew, deep down, that I wasn't ready to be a mom. Not then. Not ever, maybe.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They gave that baby a life I couldn't have given her. A stable home, a loving family, opportunities…everything. And seeing her, knowing she was happy and healthy…that was worth everything.

It wasn't about giving her *up*. It was about giving her *to* someone who could give her everything she deserved.

It doesn't mean I didn't love her. It doesn't mean I didn't feel a loss. It just means I made the best decision I could, with the information I had at the time.

And honestly? I think it made me a stronger person. It forced me to grow up, to take responsibility for my actions, and to think about what I really wanted out of life.

So yeah. If I could go back in time, I think I would still make the same decision. It was the right thing to do. For her. And for me.

It still kinda sucks, though. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a tough one. It wasn't like a movie, you know? It wasn't all neatly tied up with a bow and a montage of me being all…zen. It was messy. Really messy.

Honestly, for a while, I just pretended it didn't bother me. I was all sarcastic and detached, like, "Yeah, whatever, it's fine, I wanted this." But that was just a front. Inside, I was a total wreck.

It was weird, giving a baby up. Like, I carried him for nine months, and then…just handed him over. It felt like a part of me was missing. And it hurt. A lot.

I spent a lot of time with Paul and Vanessa, the couple who adopted him. They were really good people. And seeing them with him…it was good. It made me feel like I'd made the right decision. But it also made me sad.

I talked to my dad a lot. He's not always the most…expressive person, but he listened. And he didn't judge me. He just let me talk. And that helped.

I also wrote a lot. Just journaling, getting my feelings out on paper. It was a way to process everything without having to talk about it.

And honestly, it took time. A lot of time. There were days when I felt okay, and days when I just wanted to curl up in a ball and cry. It was a rollercoaster.

I think the biggest thing that helped was realizing that it wasn't about *giving him up*. It was about *giving him a life*. A better life than I could have given him. And that made it a little bit easier to accept.

It still stings sometimes, you know? I still wonder what he's doing, what he's like. But I know I did the right thing. And that's what matters.

It wasn't easy. It still isn't easy. But I got through it. And I think…I think I'm stronger for it.



It's just…it's complicated. It's not something you just "get over." It's something you learn to live with. And you learn to be okay with it. Eventually.

Ugh, okay, yeah. It wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, you know? People think adoption is just…handing over a baby and everyone's happy. It's way more complicated than that.

With Mark and Vanessa, it wasn't like they were *bad* people. They were really nice. And they were super excited about the baby. But they had…expectations. And those expectations sometimes clashed with what I wanted.

Like, Vanessa was really into the whole "natural birth" thing. And I was like, "Look, I just want to get this over with as quickly and painlessly as possible." It wasn't a huge fight, but it was a little awkward.

And Mark…he was just really eager. He wanted to be involved in *everything*. Which is sweet, I guess, but it felt a little…intense. Like he was already planning the baby's whole life before it was even born.

The biggest challenge, though, was just…letting go. It was hard to picture someone else raising my baby. Even though I knew it was the right thing to do. And I was worried they wouldn't love the baby as much as I would. Which is stupid, I know. But it's what I was feeling.

We had a lot of conversations. A lot of awkward, emotional conversations. And thankfully, they were really understanding. They listened to my concerns, and they were willing to compromise.

It wasn't always easy, but we worked through it. And in the end, I knew I was making the best decision for the baby. And that's all that really mattered.

It just wasn't a perfect process. It was messy and complicated and emotionally draining. But it was also…worth it. Because I knew the baby was going to have a good life. And that's all I ever wanted.

Ugh, okay, that's…a complicated one. Still is, honestly. It wasn't like a snap decision, you know? It wasn't like I just woke up one morning and was all, "Nope, Paul's out!" It was a lot of thinking, and talking with Mark and Vanessa, and just…trying to figure out what was best for the baby.

Paul, he was…sweet. A little clueless, maybe. But sweet. And he *wanted* to be involved. He wanted to help. But he was also…not ready. He was still figuring out his own life, you know? He was a musician, chasing his dreams. And that's cool, but it wasn't a stable situation for a kid.

Mark and Vanessa, they were different. They were solid. They were ready. They had a home, and a plan, and a whole lot of love to give. And they wanted a baby. They wanted *this* baby.

It felt…selfish, maybe, to involve Paul just because he was the father. Like, it wasn't about what *he* wanted, it was about what the baby needed. And the baby needed stability and security.

It wasn't easy telling him. It was probably the hardest conversation I've ever had. He was hurt, and I felt terrible. But I also knew, deep down, that it was the right decision.

I still think about him sometimes. I wonder how he's doing. I hope he's happy. But I also know that the baby is in good hands. And that's what matters most.

It wasn't about punishing Paul, or denying him his rights. It was about making the best possible choice for a little person who didn't get a say in any of it. And sometimes, the right choice isn't the easy one. It just…is.



It's still a little messy in my head, if I'm being honest. But I stand by the decision. It was the right thing to do. For everyone involved. Especially the baby.

Ugh, okay, this is…still a hard thing to talk about, honestly. It wasn't like a sudden decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was a lot more complicated than that.

It started with just…realizing I wasn't ready. Like, *really* not ready. I was sixteen. I was still figuring out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone raise a human being. I was barely keeping my grades up, and I was definitely not prepared to give up my life for a baby.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, too. I wanted that kid to have everything. A stable home, two parents who were actually prepared, a good education…things I couldn't offer at the time.

I talked to my dad, and he was…surprisingly cool about it. He didn't try to talk me out of it, he just listened. And then we started looking into adoption.

It wasn't an easy choice. It was probably the hardest choice I've ever had to make. But the more I learned about adoption, the more I realized it was the right thing to do. It wasn't about giving up my baby, it was about giving my baby the best possible life.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared, and so loving. I knew they would be great parents. And knowing that made it a little bit easier.

It still hurt, though. It still does, sometimes. But I try to focus on the fact that I made a selfless decision. And that I gave a little kid a chance at a happy life.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered.



It's…a lot to unpack. It's not a simple story. But that's how it happened. It was a messy, complicated, heartbreaking, and ultimately, the right decision.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a hard one. Still is, honestly. People always ask me that, like there's some neat little answer I can just pull out. There isn't. It sucked. It really, really sucked.

It wasn't like a movie, you know? There wasn't a dramatic goodbye at the hospital with a lot of tears and a perfect song playing. It was…messy. And complicated. And full of a lot of feelings I didn't even know I *had*.

At first, I was mostly just…numb. I think I was in shock. Like, this whole thing had happened, and I was just going through the motions. But then, after, it hit me. Hard.

I cried. A lot. Like, ugly crying. And I was angry. Angry at myself, angry at the situation, angry at everything. And I felt really, really sad. Like a piece of me was missing. Which, I guess, it was.

I talked to Mark. A lot. He was…surprisingly good at listening. And Paul, too. He didn't really *get* it, but he tried. And my dad. He just…held me. Sometimes that's all you need.

I also wrote a lot. In my notebook. Just…dumping all my feelings onto the page. It helped to get it out of my head.

And I focused on school. And on my friends. And on trying to be normal. Which was hard, because nothing felt normal anymore.

It wasn't about "getting over it." It was about learning to live *with* it. Learning to accept that I had made a really hard decision, and that it was the right decision, even though it hurt like hell.

It still comes up sometimes. A song on the radio, a baby in the grocery store…it can bring it all back. But it doesn't feel as raw anymore. It feels…sad, but also peaceful.

I think…I think knowing that the baby was going to a good home, with people who wanted him and could give him everything I couldn't, that helped. A lot.

It wasn't easy. And it's not something I'll ever forget. But I got through it. And I'm stronger for it. Even if I don't always feel like it.



It's just…it's a complicated thing. And there's no easy answer. Just…feel your feelings. And talk to people. And be kind to yourself. You deserve it.

Ugh, okay. That's…a complicated question. It wasn't like a normal friendship, you know? It was…different.

Mark and Vanessa Loring. They were…good people. Really good people. Like, genuinely kind and wanting-to-be-parents good. Which is kinda rare, honestly.

At first, it was awkward. Super awkward. I mean, I was giving them my baby. That's not exactly a casual meet-cute. I was bracing myself for them to be, like, super serious and judgey. But they weren't. They were…normal. They talked about their lives, their hobbies, their dog. They asked me about my life, but they didn't pry.

We met a few times before the baby was born, mostly at Vanessa's house. She made me tea and we talked. A lot. About everything and nothing. Mark was quieter, but he was always really nice. He'd bring me books and stuff.

After Henry was born, it was even weirder. I got to spend some time with him in the hospital, which was…intense. And then I had to give him to them. That was the hardest part.

We stayed in touch, though. They sent me updates and pictures. Vanessa would call sometimes just to chat. They were really respectful of my space and my feelings. They didn't try to replace me as his mother, they just wanted to be good parents to him.

It wasn't a traditional family, but it was a family nonetheless. I still think about them a lot. And I hope Henry knows how much they love him.

It's hard to explain. It wasn't like I *lost* a baby. It was more like I *gave* him a life. And Mark and Vanessa were the ones who were going to give it to him. And that's…okay. It had to be.

It was a weird, messy, beautiful thing. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even if it was kinda heartbreaking.

Ugh, okay, that's…a big question. And honestly? Yeah. It totally changed me. Like, fundamentally. It wasn't just getting pregnant, it was *everything* that came with it.

Before, I was just…Juno. Kinda sarcastic, kinda detached, just trying to get through high school without being noticed too much. I had my music, my friends, my plans. I wasn't thinking about the future, not really.

Then, boom. Positive pregnancy test. And suddenly, everything was different. I had to grow up, like, *fast*. I had to make decisions that no sixteen-year-old should have to make. And I had to face the consequences of my actions.

It forced me to think about what I wanted out of life. Not just what I wanted *right now*, but what I wanted in the long run. It made me realize that I wasn't invincible, and that my choices had an impact on other people.

It also made me appreciate the people who supported me. My dad, my stepmom, Paul, Annie…they were all amazing. I wouldn't have gotten through it without them.

I'm still sarcastic, and I still try to avoid being too emotional. But I think I'm more…grounded now. More aware of the world around me. More compassionate.

I used to think being different was a bad thing. Now, I realize it's what makes me, me. And I'm okay with that.

It wasn't easy, and it wasn't what I planned. But it made me who I am today. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it. Even though it was really, really hard.



It's weird to think about, you know? Like, a tiny little person completely changed the course of my life. But in a good way. Mostly.

Ugh. Okay, that was…rough. Seriously. It was like, overnight, everyone in Beaverton had an opinion on my life. And none of them were asking for one. It was the worst.

At first, I tried to ignore it. Just pretend it wasn't happening. But that's impossible when people are staring at you in the grocery store and whispering behind your back. And when your mom starts getting weird looks at the library.

Then I tried being angry. Like, confronting people and telling them to mind their own business. That just made things worse. It just fueled the fire.

What actually helped, surprisingly, was Paul. He was just…unflappable. He didn't care what anyone else thought. He just kept being himself, and he made me feel like it was okay to be myself too.

And Leah. She was my rock. She didn't judge me, she didn't offer unsolicited advice, she just…listened. And she made me laugh. A lot.

I also realized that most of the rumors were just…stupid. People were making up stories and filling in the blanks with their own assumptions. And honestly, it said more about *them* than it did about me.

So I just…stopped caring what people thought. It wasn't easy, but I realized that my happiness was more important than their opinions. I focused on what was important to me: the baby, my family, and my future.

I also started making fun of the rumors. Like, if I heard someone say something ridiculous, I'd just laugh and say, "Oh, you should hear what *else* they're saying about me!" It took the power out of it.

It still stung sometimes, you know? But I learned that you can't control what other people think. You can only control how you react to it. And I decided to react by being myself, and by not letting anyone else define me.

It was a messy, awkward, and sometimes painful experience. But it also made me stronger. And it taught me a valuable lesson: people will always talk. Just don't let them talk you out of being you.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, isn't it? Everyone always wants to know about that. It's not like I hadn't thought about it, you know? Like, a million times.

It wasn't a quick decision. It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…complicated.

I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a whole human being. I was failing Shop class, for crying out loud. I could barely keep my grades up, and I was pretty sure my future involved a lot of minimum wage jobs and questionable life choices.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby. She deserved parents who were ready for it. Parents who had their lives together. Parents who could give her everything she needed. A stable home, a good education, opportunities…things I just couldn't provide at that point.

My mom was amazing, she really was. But she was already struggling, you know? And I didn't want to put that kind of burden on her.

Mark…well, Mark was Mark. He was a good guy, but he was also kinda clueless. And we weren't exactly a couple. We were just…two kids who made a mistake.

So, I started thinking about adoption. And the more I thought about it, the more it made sense. It wasn't about giving her *up*. It was about giving her a *better* life. A life I couldn't give her.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. And it still hurts sometimes. But I knew it was the right thing to do. For her. And for me.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for her. And that's something I had to learn. It's not always about you. Sometimes, you have to put someone else's needs first. Even if it breaks your heart.



It's…a lot to explain. It's not a simple story. But that's the gist of it. It was about love. And sacrifice. And doing what I thought was right, even when it was the hardest thing I'd ever done.

Ugh, okay, that's…a tough one. It wasn't like, a monster under the bed kind of fear. It was more…a hollow feeling. A big, empty space in my chest.

I think my biggest fear was that I wouldn't be a *good* enough reason for someone to want a baby. Like, I was just this…kid. Messy, sarcastic, still figuring things out. And I was giving away something so precious.

I kept worrying that Mark and Vanessa – they were the couple, the ones who were gonna raise the baby – would look at me and think, "Wow, this girl is totally irresponsible. Why would she even *think* she could handle this?"

And then I'd worry they'd change their minds. That they'd decide they wanted a different baby. One with a mom who was, like, more put-together. More…normal.

It wasn't about wanting to keep the baby, exactly. It was about wanting them to have a good life. And I was scared that *I* would somehow mess that up. That my choices would hurt them, or the baby.

It was a lot of overthinking, probably. Paul kept telling me to chill out, but it's hard to chill out when you're giving away a piece of yourself.

I guess I was just scared of being judged. And scared of not being good enough. It's a pretty universal fear, I think. Even if you're giving a baby up for adoption. It doesn't make it any easier.



It sounds kinda pathetic when I say it out loud, but that's how I felt. It was a scary time. A really scary time.

Ugh, okay, this is a story. A slightly embarrassing story, if I'm being honest.

So, Paul…he wasn't exactly forthcoming with his full name, right? He was kinda mysterious and artsy and didn't want to be "found" or whatever. And I wasn't exactly pushing it, because, you know, teenage hormones and awkwardness.

But I needed a last name for the adoption papers. You can't just put "Paul" on there. That's…weird.

I was flipping through records at this record store – because, obviously – and I saw this album by a guy named Van Bleeker. It was kinda obscure indie stuff. And the name just…stuck. It sounded cool. It sounded…responsible. Which Paul definitely wasn't, but I figured a good last name could help with that.

It also sounded kinda literary, which I thought was important. Like, it gave the baby a sense of…depth. I don't know. I was overthinking it.

So I just…used it. I figured it was a good enough name. And Paul didn't object, which I took as a sign of approval.

It's kinda funny, actually. I named the father of my child after a random musician I found in a record store. It's very…me.

And honestly, I still don't know if "Bleeker" is even his real last name. But it's the one that stuck. And that's all that matters, I guess.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the whole punk thing? It wasn't like a conscious decision, you know? It just…fit. Everything else felt so fake and polished, and punk was just…raw. Real.

I think it started with just being annoyed. Annoyed with everything. Annoyed with people trying to tell me what to do, annoyed with the expectations, annoyed with the whole perfect-teenager image everyone was trying to shove down my throat.

And then I heard bands like The Moldy Peaches, and Bikini Kill, and Sleater-Kinney…and it was like, *finally*. People who weren't afraid to be messy and honest and angry. People who weren't trying to be pretty or popular. They were just being themselves, and it was so refreshing.

It wasn't just the music, either. It was the whole culture. The DIY ethic, the anti-establishment attitude, the sense of community. It was like, you could be yourself, no matter how weird or different you were. And people would actually *accept* you for it.

I started going to shows, and it was amazing. Everyone was just letting loose and being themselves. There was no judgment, no pretense. It was just a bunch of people connecting through music and energy.

And the clothes! The ripped jeans, the band tees, the combat boots…it was a way to express yourself and reject the mainstream. It was a way to say, "I don't care what you think."

It wasn't about being rebellious for the sake of being rebellious. It was about finding something that felt authentic and true to myself. It was about finding a place where I belonged.
