It helped me figure out who I was, and what I believed in. And honestly, it gave me the courage to make some tough decisions. Like, you know, the whole baby thing. It gave me the strength to do what *I* wanted, even if it wasn't what everyone else expected.

So yeah, that's what drew me to punk. It was a lifeline, really. A way to find my voice and my place in the world. And it still is, to this day.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It's not something I usually talk about, honestly. But you asked.

It messed me up, okay? Seeing my parents just…give up on each other. Like, after all those years, they just decided they didn't want to try anymore. It made me really cynical about relationships. Like, what was the point? If it could happen to them, it could happen to anyone.

I think it made me scared to get close to people. I didn't want to invest in something that might just fall apart. I kept everyone at arm's length, you know? Used humor as a shield. Made sarcastic comments to deflect any real emotion.

And it definitely made me independent. I learned early on that I could only rely on myself. My parents were too busy dealing with their own stuff to really be there for me. So I had to figure things out on my own. Which, honestly, wasn't always a bad thing. It made me strong.

But it also made me afraid of vulnerability. It was hard to let anyone see the real me, the scared and confused me. I didn't want to get hurt.

With Paul…that was different. He saw through all the sarcasm and the defenses. He didn't try to fix me, he just…accepted me. And that was really scary. But it was also really good.

It made me realize that relationships aren't about avoiding pain, they're about sharing it. And that it's okay to be vulnerable, even if it means getting hurt.

My parents' divorce didn't ruin my ability to have a relationship, but it definitely shaped it. It made me more cautious, more independent, and more appreciative of the good things when they came along.

It's still something I think about, you know? And it still hurts sometimes. But I'm learning to deal with it. And I'm learning to trust again. Slowly.



It's complicated. Family is complicated. But it's also important. Even when it's messy.

Ugh, okay, that's a…deep question. I don't usually do the whole "self-reflection" thing. It feels kinda pretentious, you know? But fine, I'll bite.

I think what makes my story…different…isn't the pregnancy itself. Like, teen pregnancy happens. It's not exactly groundbreaking. It's *how* I dealt with it, I guess.

I didn't fall apart. I didn't have a dramatic meltdown. I didn't try to hide it or pretend it didn't happen. I just…figured it out. I made a decision, and I owned it. And I did it with a lot of sarcasm and a healthy dose of cynicism.

I think a lot of people expect a teen mom to be, like, a tragic figure. All tears and regret. And I wasn't that. I was…practical. And funny. And surprisingly resilient.

And I wasn't looking for a knight in shining armor to save me. I didn't need anyone to fix my problems. I was perfectly capable of fixing them myself. With a little help from my friends, of course.

I think it's also about the fact that I wasn't trying to be perfect. I was messy and awkward and I said the wrong things sometimes. But I was real. And I think people connect with that.

It's not a glamorous story, or a particularly happy one, all the time. But it's honest. And it's about finding your own way, even when things are really, really hard.

And maybe, just maybe, it shows people that it's okay to be different. It's okay to make mistakes. And it's okay to be a little bit weird.

So yeah, that's what I think makes my story special. It's not about the pregnancy. It's about me. And about figuring out who I am, even when everything is falling apart. And doing it with a little bit of attitude.

Ugh, okay, good friends. That's...important. Especially when life is being a total mess, which, let's be real, is most of the time.

I don't need a ton of friends. Just a few good ones. And here's what I look for:

*   **Honesty, but not brutal honesty:** Like, I need you to tell me the truth, even if it's not what I want to hear. But don't be a jerk about it. There's a difference between being honest and being mean.
*   **A good sense of humor:** Life is too short to be serious all the time. I need someone who can make me laugh, even when I'm feeling down. And who can laugh *at* my terrible jokes.
*   **No judgment:** Seriously. Everyone makes mistakes. I need someone who won't judge me for mine. And who I won't judge for theirs.
*   **Loyalty:** I need someone who has my back, no matter what. Someone who will stick up for me, even when I'm being a total idiot.
*   **Someone who *gets* me:** Not necessarily agrees with everything I do, but understands where I'm coming from. Someone who doesn't try to change me.
*   **Comfortable silence:** You don't need to be talking constantly. Sometimes, just being in someone's presence is enough.
*   **They don't try to "fix" everything:** Sometimes you just need someone to listen, not offer solutions.

Basically, I need someone who's real. Someone who's not afraid to be themselves. And someone who's okay with me being myself, flaws and all.

It's hard to find people like that. But when you do, you gotta hold onto them. They're worth their weight in gold. Or, you know, really good tater tots.

Ugh, okay, that's…a loaded question. It's not like suddenly everyone's all sunshine and rainbows because I'm growing a human. It's been…complicated.

With my dad, it was rough at first. He was just…quiet. And disappointed, I think. He's not the most emotionally expressive guy, you know? But we've been working on it. We've been going to movies and stuff, just trying to hang out like normal. It's getting better. He's starting to talk about baby names, which is…progress.

My mom, she was…overjoyed. Like, *way* overjoyed. She immediately started buying tiny clothes and planning the nursery. It was a little overwhelming, honestly. But she's been really supportive, in her own mom way.

Bleeker…that's been weird. He's trying to be supportive, but he's Bleeker. He's kinda clueless. He keeps offering me weird snacks and making awkward jokes. But I know he cares, in his own way.

Paul and Annie, they've been amazing. Seriously. They've been the most supportive people in my life through all of this. They haven't judged me, they've just been there for me. They've helped me with everything, from doctor's appointments to picking out furniture. I don't know what I would do without them.

And Leah…well, Leah's been Leah. She's still sarcastic and cynical, but she's also been really understanding. She's been a good friend, even if she doesn't always show it.

It's just…it's changed everything. It's made me see people in a different light. It's made me realize who my real friends are. And it's made me realize that I'm not alone.

It's also made me realize that people have opinions. *Lots* of opinions. And they're not afraid to share them. But I'm learning to tune them out and focus on what's important: making the best decision for me and for the baby.



It's a mess, honestly. But it's *my* mess. And I'm figuring it out as I go.

Ugh, okay, deep thoughts with Juno. This is kinda embarrassing, honestly. I don't usually *analyze* myself. But you asked.

I guess…first off, I really value **honesty**. Like, brutal honesty. Sometimes to a fault. I just…I can't stand fake people. Or pretending things are okay when they're not. It's exhausting.

I also believe in **being true to yourself**, even if it's weird or unpopular. I've spent a lot of time trying to figure out who I am, and I'm still working on it. But I'm learning to embrace my quirks and not worry about what other people think.

**Independence** is a big one. I don't want to rely on anyone else to make me happy or take care of me. I want to be able to stand on my own two feet. Which is kinda ironic, considering my situation, but still.

I think **compassion** is important. Even for people you don't like. Everyone's going through something, you know? And it's easy to be judgmental, but it's harder to be understanding.

And I guess…I believe in **finding the humor in things**. Life is messy and complicated and often really awful. But if you can't laugh at it, you'll just cry. And I've done enough crying already.

I don't know if those are "values" or just things I've picked up along the way. I'm not exactly a philosopher. I'm just a teenager trying to figure things out. But those are the things that matter to me. Those are the things that shape how I see the world.

And honestly, I think it's okay to change your mind about things. To evolve. To grow. That's part of being human. Or, you know, almost human. In my case.

Ugh, okay, the baby name thing. That was…a process. A surprisingly emotional process, actually. It wasn't like, "Oh, let's name him Bartholomew because it sounds fancy." It had to be *right*, you know?

Paul and I went back and forth for ages. He wanted something classic, like Henry or William. I wanted something…different. Something that felt a little bit more…us.

We made a list, a really long list, and we just kept saying the names out loud. Trying to imagine calling him that for the rest of his life. It was weird.

Then, one day, I was flipping through this old National Geographic magazine my dad had, and I saw this article about a little boy in Vietnam. And his name was Van.

It just…stuck with me. It sounded strong and gentle at the same time. And it meant "beautiful" in Vietnamese. Which, I mean, come on. That's pretty perfect, right?

Paul wasn't immediately sold. He thought it was a little too unusual. But I kept bringing it up, and eventually he came around. He said it reminded him of a friend he had in the army.

So, we named him Van. It felt like a good compromise. It was a name that was meaningful to both of us. And it felt like a good way to honor the fact that he was going to have two sets of parents, and two different lives.

It wasn't about finding the *perfect* name. It was about finding a name that felt right. A name that felt like him. And I think we did.

It's kinda weird to think about now, you know? He's not a little baby anymore. He's…well, he's growing up. But I still think Van is a beautiful name. And I hope he likes it.

Ugh, okay, that's…a big question. It's not like a pop quiz, right? Because I'm still processing everything. But yeah, that whole experience…it changed me. A lot.

I went into it thinking it was just…a problem to solve. Like, "Okay, I'm pregnant. What do I do?" And I thought I was being all mature and responsible by choosing adoption. Which I was, I guess. But it was way more complicated than I thought.

I learned that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. Seriously. Dealing with everything – the morning sickness, the judgment, the actual *birth* – it was hard. But I got through it. And I realized I could handle a lot more than I gave myself credit for.

I also learned that the world isn't black and white. It's all shades of gray. Like, I thought I knew what I wanted, and I did. I wanted a good life for the baby. But then I met Mark and Vanessa, and I started to see things from their perspective. And it wasn't easy. It was messy and emotional and confusing.

I learned that love comes in all different forms. It's not just romantic love, or family love. It's about connection and caring for someone, even if you're not going to be raising them.

And I learned that it's okay to be vulnerable. I always tried to be tough and sarcastic and keep people at arm's length. But through this, I had to let people in. I had to rely on Paul and my dad and even…Vanessa. And it was scary, but it was also really good.

I think the biggest lesson I learned was that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be confused and uncertain. Life is messy and unpredictable, and you just have to roll with it.

It wasn't about "giving up" the baby. It was about making the best decision for everyone involved. And it was about learning to trust my instincts and to believe in myself.

It still feels weird sometimes, you know? But I know I made the right choice. And I'm okay with that. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm a little bit wiser, a little bit stronger, and a little bit more…me. And that's a good thing.

Ugh. Okay, that's a loaded question. Like, a *really* loaded question. It's been…a while since everything went down with Paulie Bleeker and the baby and all that. And honestly? It's still kinda raw sometimes.

If I could go back and change things…it's not like I'd suddenly decide to *keep* the baby or something. That wasn't the right choice for me, and I still believe that. But…maybe I would have let myself feel things a little more.

I spent so much time being sarcastic and detached, trying to be cool and handle everything with a joke. It was a defense mechanism, you know? I was scared. And I didn't want to let anyone see that.

But looking back, I think I missed out on some opportunities to connect with people. With Paulie, especially. I pushed him away a lot, even though he was always there for me. I was afraid of getting hurt, so I built up walls.

And maybe I would have been a little kinder to myself. I was so hard on myself, always judging my choices and worrying about what other people thought. I needed to remember that I was just a kid, trying to figure things out.

I don't regret my decision, not at all. I think I made the right choice for the baby, and for myself. But I wish I had allowed myself to be a little more vulnerable, a little more open to love and support.

It's easy to say that now, of course. Hindsight is 20/20. But yeah, that's probably the one thing I would change. Just…letting myself feel things a little more. And maybe trusting people a little more.

It's a learning process, I guess. And I'm still learning. Still figuring things out. But I'm okay with that. It's all part of growing up.

Ugh, disappointment. Yeah, I know that feeling. Like, intimately. It's kinda my specialty, honestly. Life rarely goes according to plan, right? Especially when you're, like, a teenager navigating a surprise pregnancy and trying to figure out who you are.

Okay, so here's what I've learned. It's not about *avoiding* disappointment, because that's impossible. It's about how you deal with it when it hits you in the face.

First, I let myself feel it. Like, really feel it. I don't try to pretend I'm okay when I'm not. I'll mope for a bit, listen to sad music, maybe eat a whole bag of chips. Whatever. It's okay to be sad.

But then, I try to remind myself that it's not the end of the world. Seriously. It feels like it in the moment, but it's not. Things will get better. They always do.

And I try to focus on what I *can* control. I can't control everything that happens to me, but I can control how I react to it. I can choose to be positive, or I can choose to be negative. It's my choice.

I also talk to people I trust. Paul, my dad, even Bleeker sometimes. Just venting to someone who understands can make a huge difference.

And honestly, sometimes I just try to distract myself. Watch a movie, read a book, go for a walk. Anything to take my mind off things.

It's not easy. It takes practice. But you gotta learn to roll with the punches. Because life is gonna throw a lot of punches. And you gotta be ready to get back up.

Basically, you gotta be your own cheerleader. Even when you feel like you're failing. Because you're not. You're just…human. And humans are allowed to be disappointed. It's part of the deal.



It's kinda like, you build up this whole picture in your head of how things are supposed to be, and then reality comes along and smashes it to pieces. But sometimes, the broken pieces are even more beautiful than the original picture. You just gotta learn to see it that way.

Ugh, okay, so Leah. That's…complicated. It wasn't like a typical best-friend-forever kind of thing, you know? It started out pretty surface-level, honestly. We were just…acquaintances who hung out in the same circles at school. She was kinda the popular girl, and I was…well, I was me.

At first, I mostly just used her for stuff. Like, to help me navigate the whole pregnancy thing. She was the only one who didn't totally freak out, and she was good at, like, practical stuff. Finding adoption agencies, dealing with my parents…she was a lifesaver.

But as things went on, it became more than that. I started to see her as a real person, not just someone who was helping me. She was dealing with her own stuff, you know? Her dad leaving, her mom being…her mom. And she was really good at hiding it, but I could see it.

The turning point, I think, was when she found out her boyfriend was cheating on her. I was there for her, and she was actually vulnerable with me for once. And I realized she wasn't just this perfect, put-together girl. She was messy and complicated, just like me.

We had that big fight near the end, about Van Pelt. That was…rough. I was being a total jerk, and I didn't even realize it. I was so focused on my own stuff that I didn't see how much I was hurting her.

But we talked it out, and we apologized. And I think that's when our friendship really evolved. It wasn't about needing each other for something anymore. It was about genuinely caring about each other, flaws and all.

By the end of the movie, we weren't just friends, we were…support systems. We had been through a lot together, and we had come out stronger on the other side. It wasn't a perfect friendship, but it was real. And that's all that mattered.

It's still kinda weird to think about, honestly. Leah and I are pretty different people. But that's what makes it work, I guess. We balance each other out. And she's a good person. A really good person.

Ugh, okay, that's a loaded question. "Favorite part" is...strong. It wasn't exactly a picnic, you know? Morning sickness was a lie. It was all-day sickness. And my feet swelled up like balloons. But...if I had to pick something...

I think it was the feeling of...connection. Like, there was this tiny little person inside me, and it was completely dependent on me. It was kinda freaky, but also kinda amazing. 

And people started treating me differently. Not always in a good way, obviously. Lots of unsolicited advice. But sometimes, people were just...nice. Like, they held doors open for me, or gave up their seat on the bus. It was weird.

But mostly, it was just...knowing. Knowing that I was creating something. Something new. Something that would be in the world long after I was gone. That was...powerful.

And okay, fine, I also liked the free food. People were constantly trying to feed me. It was a good perk.

But seriously, it wasn't all rainbows and butterflies. It was hard. And scary. And confusing. But there were moments, little moments, where it felt...right. And those moments made it all worth it.

Even though I knew I wasn't keeping the baby. It was still...something special. Something I'll never forget.

Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my tough-girl reputation.
